Beliefs on baptism vary among denominations. Differences occur firstly on whether the act has any spiritual significance. Some, such as the Catholic and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_churches" title="Eastern Orthodox churches">Eastern Orthodox churches</a>, as well as Lutherans and Anglicans, hold to the doctrine of <a href="/wiki/Baptismal_regeneration" title="Baptismal regeneration">baptismal regeneration</a>, which affirms that baptism creates or strengthens a person's faith, and is intimately linked to salvation. <a href="/wiki/Baptists" title="Baptists">Baptists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Plymouth_Brethren" title="Plymouth Brethren">Plymouth Brethren</a> view baptism as a purely symbolic act, an external public declaration of the inward change which has taken place in the person, but not as spiritually efficacious. Secondly, there are differences of opinion on the methodology (or mode) of the act. These modes are: by <a href="/wiki/Immersion_baptism" title="Immersion baptism"><i>immersion</i></a>; if immersion is total, by <i>submersion</i>; by <a href="/wiki/Affusion" title="Affusion">affusion</a> (pouring); and by <a href="/wiki/Aspersion" title="Aspersion">aspersion</a> (sprinkling). Those who hold the first view may also adhere to the tradition of <a href="/wiki/Infant_baptism" title="Infant baptism">infant baptism</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[130]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[131]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[132]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[133]</a></sup> the Orthodox Churches all practice infant baptism and always baptize by total immersion repeated three times in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[134]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[135]</a></sup> The Lutheran Church and the Catholic Church also practice infant baptism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olson2017_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-Olson2017-141">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[138]</a></sup> usually by affusion, and utilizing the <a href="/wiki/Trinitarian_formula" title="Trinitarian formula">Trinitarian formula</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[139]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anabaptist_Christian" title="Anabaptist Christian">Anabaptist Christians</a> practice <a href="/wiki/Believer%27s_baptism" title="Believer's baptism">believer's baptism</a>, in which an adult chooses to receive the ordinance after making a decision to follow Jesus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eby_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-Eby-145">[140]</a></sup> Anabaptist denominations such as the <a href="/wiki/Mennonites" title="Mennonites">Mennonites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amish" title="Amish">Amish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hutterites" title="Hutterites">Hutterites</a> use <a href="/wiki/Affusion" title="Affusion">pouring</a> as the mode to administer believer's baptism, whereas Anabaptists of the <a href="/wiki/Schwarzenau_Brethren" title="Schwarzenau Brethren">Schwarzenau Brethren</a> and <a href="/wiki/River_Brethren" title="River Brethren">River Brethren</a> traditions baptize by <a href="/wiki/Immersion_baptism" title="Immersion baptism">immersion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KurianDay2017_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-KurianDay2017-146">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kraybill2010_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kraybill2010-147">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NoltLoewen2010_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-NoltLoewen2010-148">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brackney2012_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brackney2012-149">[144]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prayer">Prayer</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prayer_in_Christianity" title="Prayer in Christianity">Prayer in Christianity</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Canonical_hours" title="Canonical hours">Canonical hours</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1062260506" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:30%; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>"... ‘Our Father in heaven, hallowed be your name. Your kingdom come. Your will be done on earth as it is in heaven. Give us today our daily bread. Forgive us our debts, as we also forgive our debtors. Lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from evil.’"
</p>
</blockquote>
<p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">— The <a href="/wiki/Lord%27s_Prayer" title="Lord's Prayer">Lord's Prayer</a>, Matthew 6:9–13, <a href="/wiki/Evangelical_Heritage_Version" title="Evangelical Heritage Version">EHV</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[145]</a></sup></cite>
</p>
</div>
<p>In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Saint_Matthew" title="Gospel of Saint Matthew">Gospel of Saint Matthew</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a> taught the <a href="/wiki/Lord%27s_Prayer" title="Lord's Prayer">Lord's Prayer</a>, which has been seen as a model for Christian prayer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jordan_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jordan-151">[146]</a></sup> The injunction for Christians to pray the Lord's prayer thrice daily was given in the <i><a href="/wiki/Didache" title="Didache">Didache</a></i> and came to be recited by Christians at 9 am, 12 pm, and 3 pm.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Milavec2003_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-Milavec2003-152">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beckwith2005_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-Beckwith2005-153">[148]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the second century <i><a href="/wiki/Apostolic_Tradition" title="Apostolic Tradition">Apostolic Tradition</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Hippolytus_of_Rome" title="Hippolytus of Rome">Hippolytus</a> instructed Christians to pray at <a href="/wiki/Fixed_prayer_times" title="Fixed prayer times">seven fixed prayer times</a>: "on rising, at the lighting of the evening lamp, at bedtime, at midnight" and "the third, sixth and ninth hours of the day, being hours associated with Christ's Passion."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chadwick1993_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chadwick1993-154">[149]</a></sup> Prayer positions, including kneeling, standing, and <a href="/wiki/Prostration" title="Prostration">prostrations</a> have been used for these seven fixed prayer times since the days of the early Church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lössl2010_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lössl2010-155">[150]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Breviary" title="Breviary">Breviaries</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/Shehimo" title="Shehimo">Shehimo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Agpeya" title="Agpeya">Agpeya</a> are used by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox_Christians" title="Oriental Orthodox Christians">Oriental Orthodox Christians</a> to pray these <a href="/wiki/Canonical_hours" title="Canonical hours">canonical hours</a> while facing in the <a href="/wiki/Direction_of_prayer" title="Direction of prayer">eastward direction of prayer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kurian2020_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kurian2020-156">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Amherst1906_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-Amherst1906-157">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <i>Apostolic Tradition</i> directed that the <a href="/wiki/Sign_of_the_cross" title="Sign of the cross">sign of the cross</a> be used by Christians during the <a href="/wiki/Minor_exorcism_in_Christianity" title="Minor exorcism in Christianity">minor exorcism</a> of <a href="/wiki/Baptism" title="Baptism">baptism</a>, during <a href="/wiki/Ablution_in_Christianity" title="Ablution in Christianity">ablutions</a> before praying at fixed prayer times, and in times of temptation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hippolytus_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hippolytus-158">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Intercessory prayer</i> is prayer offered for the benefit of other people. There are many intercessory prayers recorded in the Bible, including prayers of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apostle_Peter" title="Apostle Peter">Apostle Peter</a> on behalf of sick persons<sup class="nourlexpansion reference"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Acts+9%3A40&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">[Acts 9:40]</a></sup> and by <a href="/wiki/Prophet" title="Prophet">prophets</a> of the Old Testament in favor of other people.<sup class="nourlexpansion reference"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=1Ki+17%3A19%E2%80%9322&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">[1Ki 17:19–22]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Epistle_of_James" title="Epistle of James">Epistle of James</a>, no distinction is made between the intercessory prayer offered by ordinary believers and the prominent Old Testament prophet <a href="/wiki/Elijah" title="Elijah">Elijah</a>.<sup class="nourlexpansion reference"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jam+5%3A16%E2%80%9318&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">[Jam 5:16–18]</a></sup> The effectiveness of prayer in Christianity derives from the power of God rather than the status of the one praying.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NBDprayer_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-NBDprayer-159">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ancient church, in both <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Christianity" title="Western Christianity">Western Christianity</a>, developed a tradition of asking for the <a href="/wiki/Intercession_of_saints" title="Intercession of saints">intercession of (deceased) saints</a>, and this remains the practice of most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox" title="Oriental Orthodox">Oriental Orthodox</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic</a>, and some <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lutheran" title="Lutheran">Lutheran</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglican" title="Anglican">Anglican</a> churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ECCL2007_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-ECCL2007-160">[155]</a></sup> Apart from certain sectors within the latter two denominations, other Churches of the Protestant Reformation, however, rejected prayer to the saints, largely on the basis of the sole mediatorship of Christ.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[156]</a></sup> The reformer <a href="/wiki/Huldrych_Zwingli" title="Huldrych Zwingli">Huldrych Zwingli</a> admitted that he had offered prayers to the saints until his reading of the Bible convinced him that this was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Idolatry_in_Christianity" title="Idolatry in Christianity">idolatrous</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i>: "Prayer is the raising of one's mind and heart to God or the requesting of good things from God."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[158]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Common_Prayer" title="Book of Common Prayer">Book of Common Prayer</a></i> in the Anglican tradition is a guide which provides a set order for services, containing set prayers, scripture readings, and hymns or sung Psalms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[159]</a></sup> Frequently in Western Christianity, when praying, the hands are placed palms together and forward as in the feudal <a href="/wiki/Commendation_ceremony" title="Commendation ceremony">commendation ceremony</a>. At other times the older <a href="/wiki/Orans" title="Orans">orans</a> posture may be used, with palms up and elbows in.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Scriptures">Scriptures</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biblical_canon" title="Biblical canon">Biblical canon</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Development_of_the_Christian_biblical_canon" title="Development of the Christian biblical canon">Development of the Christian biblical canon</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Religious_text" title="Religious text">Religious text</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gutenberg_Bible,_Lenox_Copy,_New_York_Public_Library,_2009._Pic_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Gutenberg_Bible%2C_Lenox_Copy%2C_New_York_Public_Library%2C_2009._Pic_01.jpg/250px-Gutenberg_Bible%2C_Lenox_Copy%2C_New_York_Public_Library%2C_2009._Pic_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Gutenberg_Bible%2C_Lenox_Copy%2C_New_York_Public_Library%2C_2009._Pic_01.jpg/375px-Gutenberg_Bible%2C_Lenox_Copy%2C_New_York_Public_Library%2C_2009._Pic_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Gutenberg_Bible%2C_Lenox_Copy%2C_New_York_Public_Library%2C_2009._Pic_01.jpg/500px-Gutenberg_Bible%2C_Lenox_Copy%2C_New_York_Public_Library%2C_2009._Pic_01.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gutenberg_Bible,_Lenox_Copy,_New_York_Public_Library,_2009._Pic_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a> is the sacred book in Christianity.</div></div></div>
<p>Christianity, like other religions, has adherents whose beliefs and biblical interpretations vary. Christianity regards the <a href="/wiki/Biblical_canon" title="Biblical canon">biblical canon</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Old_Testament" title="Old Testament">Old Testament</a> and the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>, as the <a href="/wiki/Biblical_inspiration" title="Biblical inspiration">inspired</a> word of God. The traditional view of inspiration is that God worked through human authors so that what they produced was what God wished to communicate. The Greek word referring to inspiration in <span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=2Timothy+3%3A16&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">2 Timothy 3:16</a></span> is <i>theopneustos</i>, which literally means "God-breathed".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[160]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some believe that divine inspiration makes present Bibles <a href="/wiki/Biblical_inerrancy" title="Biblical inerrancy">inerrant</a>. Others claim inerrancy for the Bible in its original manuscripts, although none of those are extant. Still others maintain that only a particular translation is inerrant, such as the <a href="/wiki/King_James_Version" title="King James Version">King James Version</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[161]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[162]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[163]</a></sup> Another closely related view is <a href="/wiki/Biblical_infallibility" title="Biblical infallibility">biblical infallibility</a> or limited inerrancy, which affirms that the Bible is free of error as a guide to salvation, but may include errors on matters such as history, geography, or science.
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Books_of_the_Bible" title="Books of the Bible">books of the Bible</a> accepted by the Orthodox, Catholic, and Protestant churches vary somewhat, with Jews accepting only the Hebrew Bible as canonical; however, there is substantial overlap. These variations are a reflection of the range of <a href="/wiki/Tradition" title="Tradition">traditions</a>, and of the <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_council" title="Ecumenical council">councils</a> that have convened on the subject. Every version of the Old Testament always includes the books of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tanakh" title="Tanakh">Tanakh</a>, the canon of the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a>. The Catholic and Orthodox canons, in addition to the Tanakh, also include the <a href="/wiki/Deuterocanonical_books" title="Deuterocanonical books">deuterocanonical books</a> as part of the Old Testament. These books appear in the <a href="/wiki/Septuagint" title="Septuagint">Septuagint</a>, but are regarded by Protestants to be <a href="/wiki/Biblical_apocrypha" title="Biblical apocrypha">apocryphal</a>. However, they are considered to be important historical documents which help to inform the understanding of words, grammar, and syntax used in the historical period of their conception. Some versions of the Bible include a separate Apocrypha section between the Old Testament and the New Testament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[164]</a></sup> The New Testament, originally written in <a href="/wiki/Koine_Greek" title="Koine Greek">Koine Greek</a>, contains 27 books which are agreed upon by all major churches.
</p><p>Modern scholarship has raised many issues with the Bible. While the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authorized_King_James_Version" title="Authorized King James Version">King James Version</a> is held to by many because of its striking English prose, in fact it was translated from the Erasmus Greek Bible, which in turn "was based on a single 12th Century manuscript that is one of the worst manuscripts we have available to us".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ehrman209-183_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ehrman209-183-170">[165]</a></sup> Much scholarship in the past several hundred years has gone into comparing different manuscripts in order to reconstruct the original text. Another issue is that several verses are considered to be forgeries. The injunction that women "be silent and submissive" in 1 Timothy 2<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[166]</a></sup> is thought by many to be a forgery by a follower of Paul. A similar phrase in 1 Corinthians 14,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[167]</a></sup> which is thought to be by Paul, appears in different places in different manuscripts and is thought to originally be a margin note by a copyist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ehrman209-183_170-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ehrman209-183-170">[165]</a></sup> Other verses in 1 Corinthians, such as 1 Corinthians 11:2–16 where women are instructed to wear a <a href="/wiki/Christian_head_covering" title="Christian head covering">covering over their hair</a> when they pray or prophesy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[168]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scroll2022_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scroll2022-174">[169]</a></sup> contradict this verse.
</p><p>A final issue with the Bible is the way in which books were selected for inclusion in the New Testament. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gnostic_Gospels" title="Gnostic Gospels">Other gospels</a> have now been recovered, such as those found near <a href="/wiki/Nag_Hammadi" title="Nag Hammadi">Nag Hammadi</a> in 1945, and while some of these texts are quite different from what Christians have been used to, it should be understood that some of this newly recovered Gospel material is quite possibly contemporaneous with, or even earlier than, the New Testament Gospels. The core of the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Thomas" title="Gospel of Thomas">Gospel of Thomas</a>, in particular, may date from as early as AD 50 (although some<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words" title="Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words"><span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too vague attribution or weasel words. (July 2022)">which?</span></a></i>]</sup> major scholars contest this early dating),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[170]</a></sup> and if so would provide an insight into the earliest gospel texts that underlie the canonical Gospels, texts that are mentioned in Luke 1:1–2. The Gospel of Thomas contains much that is familiar from the canonical Gospels—verse 113, for example ("The Father's Kingdom is spread out upon the earth, but people do not see it"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[171]</a></sup> is reminiscent of Luke 17:20–21<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[173]</a></sup>—and the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_John" title="Gospel of John">Gospel of John</a>, with a terminology and approach that is suggestive of what was later termed <i>Gnosticism</i>, has recently been seen as a possible response to the Gospel of Thomas, a text that is commonly labeled <i>proto-Gnostic</i>. Scholarship, then, is currently exploring the relationship in the early church between mystical speculation and experience on the one hand and the search for church order on the other, by analyzing new-found texts, by subjecting canonical texts to further scrutiny, and by an examination of the passage of New Testament texts to canonical status.
</p><p>Some denominations have <a href="/wiki/Religious_text#Additional_and_alternate_scriptures" title="Religious text">additional canonical holy scriptures</a> beyond the Bible, including the <a href="/wiki/Standard_works" title="Standard works">standard works</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latter_Day_Saints_movement" title="Latter Day Saints movement">Latter Day Saints movement</a> and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Divine_Principle" title="Divine Principle">Divine Principle</a></i> in the <a href="/wiki/Unification_Church" title="Unification Church">Unification Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[174]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Catholic_interpretation">Catholic interpretation</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:View_of_saint_Peter_basilica_from_a_roof.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/View_of_saint_Peter_basilica_from_a_roof.jpg/220px-View_of_saint_Peter_basilica_from_a_roof.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/View_of_saint_Peter_basilica_from_a_roof.jpg/330px-View_of_saint_Peter_basilica_from_a_roof.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/View_of_saint_Peter_basilica_from_a_roof.jpg/440px-View_of_saint_Peter_basilica_from_a_roof.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:View_of_saint_Peter_basilica_from_a_roof.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica" title="St. Peter's Basilica">St. Peter's Basilica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a>, the largest church in the world and a symbol of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a>.</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_theology_of_Scripture" title="Catholic theology of Scripture">Catholic theology of Scripture</a></div>
<p>In antiquity, two schools of exegesis developed in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/School_of_Alexandria" title="School of Alexandria">Alexandria</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/School_of_Antioch" title="School of Antioch">Antioch</a>. The Alexandrian interpretation, exemplified by <a href="/wiki/Origen" title="Origen">Origen</a>, tended to read Scripture <a href="/wiki/Allegory" title="Allegory">allegorically</a>, while the Antiochene interpretation adhered to the literal sense, holding that other meanings (called <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theoria" title="Theoria">theoria</a></i>) could only be accepted if based on the literal meaning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[175]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic</a> theology distinguishes two senses of scripture: the literal and the spiritual.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[176]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <i>literal</i> sense of understanding scripture is the meaning conveyed by the words of Scripture. The <i>spiritual</i> sense is further subdivided into:
</p>
<ul><li>The <i>allegorical</i> sense, which includes <a href="/wiki/Typology_(theology)" title="Typology (theology)">typology</a>. An example would be the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Passage_of_the_Red_Sea" title="Passage of the Red Sea">parting of the Red Sea</a> being understood as a "type" (sign) of baptism.<sup class="nourlexpansion reference"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=1Cor+10%3A2&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">[1Cor 10:2]</a></sup></li>
<li>The <i><a href="/wiki/Moral" title="Moral">moral</a></i> sense, which understands the scripture to contain some ethical teaching.</li>
<li>The <i><a href="/wiki/Anagoge" title="Anagoge">anagogical</a></i> sense, which applies to <a href="/wiki/Eschatology" title="Eschatology">eschatology</a>, eternity and the <a href="/wiki/Apocalypse" title="Apocalypse">consummation of the world</a>.</li></ul>
<p>Regarding <a href="/wiki/Exegesis" title="Exegesis">exegesis</a>, following the rules of sound interpretation, Catholic theology holds:
</p>
<ul><li>The injunction that all other senses of sacred scripture are based on the <i>literal</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[178]</a></sup></li>
<li>That the historicity of the Gospels must be absolutely and constantly held<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[179]</a></sup></li>
<li>That scripture must be read within the "living Tradition of the whole Church"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[180]</a></sup> and</li>
<li>That "the task of interpretation has been entrusted to the bishops in communion with the successor of Peter, the <a href="/wiki/Bishop" title="Bishop">Bishop</a> of <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome" title="Diocese of Rome">Rome</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[181]</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Protestant_interpretation">Protestant interpretation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar nomobile nowraplinks"><tbody><tr><th class="sidebar-title"><a href="/wiki/Five_solae" title="Five solae">Five <i>solae</i></a> of the<br/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a></th></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading">
<i><a href="/wiki/Sola_scriptura" title="Sola scriptura">Sola scriptura</a></i></th></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading">
<i><a href="/wiki/Sola_fide" title="Sola fide">Sola fide</a></i></th></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading">
<i><a href="/wiki/Sola_gratia" title="Sola gratia">Sola gratia</a></i></th></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading">
<i><a href="/wiki/Solus_Christus" title="Solus Christus">Solus Christus</a></i></th></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading">
<i><a href="/wiki/Soli_Deo_gloria" title="Soli Deo gloria">Soli Deo gloria</a></i></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Five_solae" title="Template:Five solae"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Five_solae" title="Template talk:Five solae"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Five_solae&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Qualities_of_Scripture">Qualities of Scripture</span></h4>
<p>Many Protestant Christians, such as Lutherans and the Reformed, believe in the doctrine of  <i><a href="/wiki/Sola_scriptura" title="Sola scriptura">sola scriptura</a></i>—that the Bible is a self-sufficient revelation, the final authority on all Christian doctrine, and <a href="/wiki/Revelation" title="Revelation">revealed all truth</a> necessary for salvation;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WELS2014_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-WELS2014-187">[182]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[183]</a></sup> other Protestant Christians, such as Methodists and Anglicans, affirm the doctrine of <i><a href="/wiki/Prima_scriptura" title="Prima scriptura">prima scriptura</a></i> which teaches that Scripture is the primary source for Christian doctrine, but that "tradition, experience, and reason" can nurture the Christian religion as long as they are in harmony with the <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WELS2014_187-1"><a href="#cite_note-WELS2014-187">[182]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Humphrey2013_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-Humphrey2013-189">[184]</a></sup> Protestants characteristically believe that ordinary believers may reach an adequate understanding of Scripture because Scripture itself is clear in its meaning (or "perspicuous"). Martin Luther believed that without God's help, Scripture would be "enveloped in darkness".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foutz_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-Foutz-190">[185]</a></sup> He advocated for "one definite and simple understanding of Scripture".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foutz_190-1"><a href="#cite_note-Foutz-190">[185]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/John_Calvin" title="John Calvin">John Calvin</a> wrote, "all who refuse not to follow the Holy Spirit as their guide, find in the Scripture a clear light".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[186]</a></sup> Related to this is "efficacy", that Scripture is able to lead people to faith; and "sufficiency", that the Scriptures contain everything that one needs to know in order to obtain salvation and to live a Christian life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[187]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Original_intended_meaning_of_Scripture">Original intended meaning of Scripture</span></h4>
<p>Protestants stress the meaning conveyed by the words of Scripture, the <a href="/wiki/Historical-grammatical_method" title="Historical-grammatical method">historical-grammatical method</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[188]</a></sup> The historical-grammatical method or grammatico-historical method is an effort in <a href="/wiki/Biblical_hermeneutics" title="Biblical hermeneutics">Biblical hermeneutics</a> to find the intended original meaning in the text.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elwell565_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-Elwell565-194">[189]</a></sup> This original intended meaning of the text is drawn out through examination of the passage in light of the grammatical and syntactical aspects, the historical background, the literary genre, as well as theological (canonical) considerations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[190]</a></sup> The historical-grammatical method distinguishes between the one original meaning and the significance of the text. The significance of the text includes the ensuing use of the text or application. The original passage is seen as having only a single meaning or sense. As Milton S. Terry said: "A fundamental principle in grammatico-historical exposition is that the words and sentences can have but one significance in one and the same connection. The moment we neglect this principle we drift out upon a sea of uncertainty and conjecture."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[191]</a></sup> Technically speaking, the grammatical-historical method of interpretation is distinct from the determination of the passage's significance in light of that interpretation. Taken together, both define the term (Biblical) hermeneutics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elwell565_194-1"><a href="#cite_note-Elwell565-194">[189]</a></sup>
Some Protestant interpreters make use of <a href="/wiki/Typology_(theology)" title="Typology (theology)">typology</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[192]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Christianity" title="History of Christianity">History of Christianity</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Christianity" title="Timeline of Christianity">Timeline of Christianity</a>.</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Christianity">Early Christianity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_centers_of_Christianity" title="Early centers of Christianity">Early centers of Christianity</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Apostolic_Age">Apostolic Age</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_1st_century" title="Christianity in the 1st century">Christianity in the 1st century</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_73792_mount_zion_jerusalem.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3808" data-file-width="5712" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/PikiWiki_Israel_73792_mount_zion_jerusalem.jpg/220px-PikiWiki_Israel_73792_mount_zion_jerusalem.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/PikiWiki_Israel_73792_mount_zion_jerusalem.jpg/330px-PikiWiki_Israel_73792_mount_zion_jerusalem.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/PikiWiki_Israel_73792_mount_zion_jerusalem.jpg/440px-PikiWiki_Israel_73792_mount_zion_jerusalem.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_73792_mount_zion_jerusalem.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Cenacle" title="Cenacle">Cenacle</a> on <a href="/wiki/Mount_Zion" title="Mount Zion">Mount Zion</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, claimed to be the location of the <a href="/wiki/Last_Supper" title="Last Supper">Last Supper</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pentecost" title="Pentecost">Pentecost</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Christianity developed during the 1st century AD as a <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Christian" title="Jewish Christian">Jewish Christian</a> sect with <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_religion" title="Hellenistic religion">Hellenistic</a> influence<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[193]</a></sup> of <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple_Judaism" title="Second Temple Judaism">Second Temple Judaism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cory2015_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cory2015-199">[194]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Benko1984_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-Benko1984-200">[195]</a></sup> An early Jewish Christian community was founded in <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> under the leadership of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pillars_of_the_Church" title="Pillars of the Church">Pillars of the Church</a>, namely <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_the_Just" title="James the Just">James the Just</a>, the brother of Jesus, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Peter</a>, and John.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jewish Christianity soon attracted Gentile <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/God-fearers" title="God-fearers">God-fearers</a>, posing a problem for its <a href="/wiki/Jewish_principles_of_faith" title="Jewish principles of faith">Jewish religious outlook</a>, which insisted on close observance of the Jewish commandments. <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">Paul the Apostle</a> solved this by insisting that salvation by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pistis_Christou" title="Pistis Christou">faith in Christ</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Participation_in_Christ" title="Participation in Christ">participation</a> in his death and resurrection by their baptism, sufficed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[197]</a></sup> At first he persecuted the early Christians, but after a conversion experience he preached to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gentiles" title="Gentiles">gentiles</a>, and is regarded as having had a formative effect on the emerging <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christian</a> identity as separate from Judaism. Eventually, his departure from Jewish customs would result in the establishment of Christianity as an independent religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[198]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ante-Nicene_period">Ante-Nicene period</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_ante-Nicene_period" title="Christianity in the ante-Nicene period">Christianity in the ante-Nicene period</a> and <a href="/wiki/Great_Church" title="Great Church">Great Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P46.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="819" data-file-width="580" decoding="async" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/P46.jpg/170px-P46.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/P46.jpg/255px-P46.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/P46.jpg/340px-P46.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:P46.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A folio from <a href="/wiki/Papyrus_46" title="Papyrus 46">Papyrus 46</a>, an early-3rd-century collection of <a href="/wiki/Pauline_epistles" title="Pauline epistles">Pauline epistles</a></div></div></div>
<p>This formative period was followed by the early <a href="/wiki/Bishop" title="Bishop">bishops</a>, whom Christians consider the <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_succession" title="Apostolic succession">successors of Christ's apostles</a>. From the year 150, Christian teachers began to produce theological and apologetic works aimed at defending the faith. These authors are known as the <a href="/wiki/Church_Fathers" title="Church Fathers">Church Fathers</a>, and the study of them is called <a href="/wiki/Patristics" title="Patristics">patristics</a>. Notable early Fathers include <a href="/wiki/Ignatius_of_Antioch" title="Ignatius of Antioch">Ignatius of Antioch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polycarp" title="Polycarp">Polycarp</a>, <a href="/wiki/Justin_Martyr" title="Justin Martyr">Justin Martyr</a>, <a href="/wiki/Irenaeus" title="Irenaeus">Irenaeus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tertullian" title="Tertullian">Tertullian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clement_of_Alexandria" title="Clement of Alexandria">Clement of Alexandria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Origen" title="Origen">Origen</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Christians" title="Persecution of Christians">Persecution of Christians</a> occurred intermittently and on a small scale by both Jewish and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persecution_of_early_Christians_by_the_Romans" title="Persecution of early Christians by the Romans">Roman authorities</a>, with Roman action starting at the time of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_Rome" title="Great Fire of Rome">Great Fire of Rome</a> in 64 AD. Examples of early executions under Jewish authority reported in the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a> include the deaths of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Stephen" title="Saint Stephen">Saint Stephen</a><sup class="nourlexpansion reference"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Acts+7%3A59&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">[Acts 7:59]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James,_son_of_Zebedee" title="James, son of Zebedee">James, son of Zebedee</a>.<sup class="nourlexpansion reference"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Acts+12%3A2&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">[Acts 12:2]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Decian_persecution" title="Decian persecution">Decian persecution</a> was the first empire-wide conflict,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-martin_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-martin-204">[199]</a></sup> when the edict of <a href="/wiki/Decius" title="Decius">Decius</a> in 250 AD required everyone in the Roman Empire (except Jews) to perform a sacrifice to the Roman gods. The <a href="/wiki/Diocletianic_Persecution" title="Diocletianic Persecution">Diocletianic Persecution</a> beginning in 303 AD was also particularly severe. Roman persecution ended in 313 AD with the <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Milan" title="Edict of Milan">Edict of Milan</a>.
</p><p>While <a href="/wiki/Proto-orthodox_Christianity" title="Proto-orthodox Christianity">Proto-orthodox Christianity</a> was becoming dominant, heterodox sects also existed at the same time, which held radically different beliefs. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gnostic_Christianity" title="Gnostic Christianity">Gnostic Christianity</a> developed a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Duotheistic" title="Duotheistic">duotheistic</a> doctrine based on illusion and enlightenment rather than forgiveness of sin. With only a few scriptures overlapping with the developing orthodox canon, most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gnostic_texts" title="Gnostic texts">Gnostic texts</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gnostic_gospels" title="Gnostic gospels">Gnostic gospels</a> were eventually considered heretical and suppressed by mainstream Christians. A gradual splitting off of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gentile_Christianity" title="Gentile Christianity">Gentile Christianity</a> left <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_Christians" title="Jewish Christians">Jewish Christians</a> continuing to follow the <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Moses" title="Law of Moses">Law of Moses</a>, including practices such as circumcision. By the fifth century, they and the <a href="/wiki/Jewish%E2%80%93Christian_gospels" title="Jewish–Christian gospels">Jewish–Christian gospels</a> would be largely suppressed by the dominant sects in both Judaism and Christianity.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Spread_and_acceptance_in_Roman_Empire">Spread and acceptance in Roman Empire</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christianization_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="Christianization of the Roman Empire">Christianization of the Roman Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Thessalonica" title="Edict of Thessalonica">Edict of Thessalonica</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mor-mattai.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Mor-mattai.png/220px-Mor-mattai.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Mor-mattai.png/330px-Mor-mattai.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Mor-mattai.png/440px-Mor-mattai.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mor-mattai.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mar_Mattai_Monastery" title="Mar Mattai Monastery">Monastery of St. Matthew</a>, located atop <a href="/wiki/Mount_Alfaf" title="Mount Alfaf">Mount Alfaf</a> in northern <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, is recognized as one of the oldest Christian monasteries in existence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[200]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Christianity spread to <a href="/wiki/Aramaic" title="Aramaic">Aramaic</a>-speaking peoples along the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean_coast" title="Mediterranean coast">Mediterranean coast</a> and also to the inland parts of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> and beyond that into the <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a> and the later <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian Empire</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, which was dominated at different times and to varying extents by these empires.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[201]</a></sup> The presence of Christianity in Africa began in the middle of the 1st century in Egypt and by the end of the 2nd century in the region around <a href="/wiki/Carthage" title="Carthage">Carthage</a>. <a href="/wiki/Mark_the_Evangelist" title="Mark the Evangelist">Mark the Evangelist</a> is claimed to have started the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Alexandria" title="Church of Alexandria">Church of Alexandria</a> in about 43 CE; various later churches claim this as their own legacy, including the <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church" title="Coptic Orthodox Church">Coptic Orthodox Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[204]</a></sup> Important Africans who influenced the early development of Christianity include <a href="/wiki/Tertullian" title="Tertullian">Tertullian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clement_of_Alexandria" title="Clement of Alexandria">Clement of Alexandria</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Origen_of_Alexandria" title="Origen of Alexandria">Origen of Alexandria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cyprian" title="Cyprian">Cyprian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Athanasius" title="Athanasius">Athanasius</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Augustine_of_Hippo" title="Augustine of Hippo">Augustine of Hippo</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kohrvirab.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2334" data-file-width="3504" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Kohrvirab.jpg/220px-Kohrvirab.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Kohrvirab.jpg/330px-Kohrvirab.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Kohrvirab.jpg/440px-Kohrvirab.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kohrvirab.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The 7th-century <a href="/wiki/Khor_Virap" title="Khor Virap">Khor Virap</a> monastery in the shadow of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Ararat" title="Mount Ararat">Mount Ararat</a>; <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a> was the first state to adopt Christianity as the state religion, in AD 301.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Armenia_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-Armenia-210">[205]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tiridates_III_of_Armenia" title="Tiridates III of Armenia">King Tiridates III</a> made Christianity the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a> in <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a> between 301 and 314,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Armenia_210-1"><a href="#cite_note-Armenia-210">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-211">[206]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-almanac_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-almanac-212">[207]</a></sup> thus Armenia became the first officially Christian state. It was not an entirely new religion in Armenia, having penetrated into the country from at least the third century, but it may have been present even earlier.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maarten_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-maarten-213">[208]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Constantine_the_Great" title="Constantine the Great">Constantine I</a> was exposed to Christianity in his youth, and throughout his life his support for the religion grew, culminating in baptism on his deathbed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[209]</a></sup> During his reign, state-sanctioned persecution of Christians was ended with the <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Serdica" title="Edict of Serdica">Edict of Toleration</a> in 311 and the <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Milan" title="Edict of Milan">Edict of Milan</a> in 313. At that point, Christianity was still a minority belief, comprising perhaps only five percent of the Roman population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[210]</a></sup> Influenced by his adviser <a href="/wiki/Mardonius_(philosopher)" title="Mardonius (philosopher)">Mardonius</a>, Constantine's nephew <a href="/wiki/Julian_(emperor)" title="Julian (emperor)">Julian</a> unsuccessfully tried to suppress Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ricciotti_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ricciotti-216">[211]</a></sup> On 27 February 380, <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">Theodosius I</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gratian" title="Gratian">Gratian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Valentinian_II" title="Valentinian II">Valentinian II</a> established <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nicene_Christianity" title="Nicene Christianity">Nicene Christianity</a> as the <a href="/wiki/State_church_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="State church of the Roman Empire">State church of the Roman Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[212]</a></sup> As soon as it became connected to the state, Christianity grew wealthy; the Church solicited donations from the rich and could now own land.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[213]</a></sup>
</p><p>Constantine was also instrumental in the convocation of the <a href="/wiki/First_Council_of_Nicaea" title="First Council of Nicaea">First Council of Nicaea</a> in 325, which sought to address <a href="/wiki/Arianism" title="Arianism">Arianism</a> and formulated the Nicene Creed, which is still used by in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholicism" title="Catholicism">Catholicism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy" title="Eastern Orthodoxy">Eastern Orthodoxy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">Lutheranism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anglicanism" title="Anglicanism">Anglicanism</a>, and many other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant">Protestant</a> churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McTavish2010_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-McTavish2010-219">[214]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UMC—Our_Common_Heritage_as_Christians_40-1"><a href="#cite_note-UMC—Our_Common_Heritage_as_Christians-40">[39]</a></sup> Nicaea was the first of a series of <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_council" title="Ecumenical council">ecumenical councils</a>, which formally defined critical elements of the theology of the Church, notably concerning <a href="/wiki/Christology" title="Christology">Christology</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McManners37_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-McManners37-220">[215]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_East" title="Church of the East">Church of the East</a> did not accept the third and following ecumenical councils and is still separate today by its successors (<a href="/wiki/Assyrian_Church_of_the_East" title="Assyrian Church of the East">Assyrian Church of the East</a>).
</p><p>In terms of prosperity and cultural life, the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a> was one of the peaks in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_history" title="Christian history">Christian history</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_civilization" title="Christian civilization">Christian civilization</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[216]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> remained the leading city of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_world" title="Christian world">Christian world</a> in size, wealth, and culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[217]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Greek_scholars_in_the_Renaissance" title="Greek scholars in the Renaissance">There was a renewed interest in classical Greek philosophy</a>, as well as an increase in literary output in vernacular Greek.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Browning-1992-190-218_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-Browning-1992-190-218-223">[218]</a></sup> Byzantine art and literature held a preeminent place in Europe, and the cultural impact of <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_art" title="Byzantine art">Byzantine art</a> on the West during this period was enormous and of long-lasting significance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Browning-1992-218_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-Browning-1992-218-224">[219]</a></sup> The later rise of <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> in North Africa reduced the size and numbers of Christian congregations, leaving in large numbers only the <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church" title="Coptic Orthodox Church">Coptic Church</a> in Egypt, the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox_Tewahedo_Church" title="Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church">Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church</a> in the Horn of Africa and the <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Sudan" title="Christianity in Sudan">Nubian Church</a> in the Sudan (Nobatia, Makuria and Alodia).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">Middle Ages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Christianity in the Middle Ages">Christianity in the Middle Ages</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Middle_Ages">Early Middle Ages</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:228px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Krist_spred_3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="168" data-file-width="226" decoding="async" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a7/Krist_spred_3.jpg" width="226"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Krist_spred_3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Christendom" title="Christendom">Christendom</a> by A.D. 600 after its <a href="/wiki/Spread_of_Christianity" title="Spread of Christianity">spread to Africa and Europe</a> from the Middle East.</div></div></div>
<p>With the decline and <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">fall of the Roman Empire in the West</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Papacy" title="Papacy">papacy</a> became a political player, first visible in <a href="/wiki/Pope_Leo_I" title="Pope Leo I">Pope Leo</a>'s diplomatic dealings with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Attila_the_Hun" title="Attila the Hun">Huns</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vandals" title="Vandals">Vandals</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gonzalez-p238_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gonzalez-p238-225">[220]</a></sup> The church also entered into a long period of missionary activity and expansion among the various tribes. While <a href="/wiki/Arianism" title="Arianism">Arianists</a> instituted the death penalty for practicing pagans (see the <a href="/wiki/Massacre_of_Verden" title="Massacre of Verden">Massacre of Verden</a>, for example), what would later become <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholicism" title="Catholicism">Catholicism</a> also spread among the <a href="/wiki/Hungarians" title="Hungarians">Hungarians</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gonzalez-p238_225-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gonzalez-p238-225">[220]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celtic</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_peoples" title="Baltic peoples">Baltic</a> and some <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slavic_peoples" title="Slavic peoples">Slavic peoples</a>.
</p><p>Around 500, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Benedict" title="St. Benedict">St. Benedict</a> set out his <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monastic_Rule" title="Monastic Rule">Monastic Rule</a>, establishing a system of regulations for the foundation and running of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monasteries" title="Monasteries">monasteries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gonzalez-p238_225-2"><a href="#cite_note-Gonzalez-p238-225">[220]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Monasticism" title="Monasticism">Monasticism</a> became a powerful force throughout Europe,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gonzalez-p238_225-3"><a href="#cite_note-Gonzalez-p238-225">[220]</a></sup> and gave rise to many early centers of learning, most famously in <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gaul" title="Gaul">Gaul</a>, contributing to the <a href="/wiki/Carolingian_Renaissance" title="Carolingian Renaissance">Carolingian Renaissance</a> of the 9th century.
</p><p>In the 7th century, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Syria" title="Muslim conquest of Syria">Muslims conquered Syria</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>), North Africa, and Spain, converting some of the Christian population to <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, and placing the rest under a separate <a href="/wiki/Dhimmi" title="Dhimmi">legal status</a>. Part of the Muslims' success was due to the exhaustion of the Byzantine Empire in its decades long conflict with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persia" title="Persia">Persia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMullin200888_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMullin200888-226">[221]</a></sup> Beginning in the 8th century, with the rise of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carolingian" title="Carolingian">Carolingian</a> leaders, the Papacy sought greater political support in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Frankish_Kingdom" title="Frankish Kingdom">Frankish Kingdom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMullin200893–94_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMullin200893–94-227">[222]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Middle Ages brought about major changes within the church. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pope_Gregory_the_Great" title="Pope Gregory the Great">Pope Gregory the Great</a> dramatically reformed the <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiastical_polity" title="Ecclesiastical polity">ecclesiastical structure</a> and administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[223]</a></sup> In the early 8th century, <a href="/wiki/Iconoclasm" title="Iconoclasm">iconoclasm</a> became a divisive issue, when it was sponsored by the <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">Byzantine</a> emperors. The <a href="/wiki/Second_Council_of_Nicaea" title="Second Council of Nicaea">Second Ecumenical Council of Nicaea</a> (787) finally pronounced in favor of icons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[224]</a></sup> In the early 10th century, Western Christian monasticism was further rejuvenated through the leadership of the great Benedictine monastery of <a href="/wiki/Cluny_Abbey" title="Cluny Abbey">Cluny</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[225]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="High_and_Late_Middle_Ages">High and Late Middle Ages</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jesus-Christ-from-Hagia-Sophia.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="873" decoding="async" height="195" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Jesus-Christ-from-Hagia-Sophia.jpg/170px-Jesus-Christ-from-Hagia-Sophia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Jesus-Christ-from-Hagia-Sophia.jpg/255px-Jesus-Christ-from-Hagia-Sophia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Jesus-Christ-from-Hagia-Sophia.jpg/340px-Jesus-Christ-from-Hagia-Sophia.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jesus-Christ-from-Hagia-Sophia.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An example of Byzantine pictorial art, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/De%C3%ABsis" title="Deësis">Deësis</a> mosaic at the <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia#Deësis_mosaic" title="Hagia Sophia">Hagia Sophia</a> in <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CouncilofClermont.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1035" data-file-width="1072" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/CouncilofClermont.jpg/170px-CouncilofClermont.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/CouncilofClermont.jpg/255px-CouncilofClermont.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/CouncilofClermont.jpg/340px-CouncilofClermont.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CouncilofClermont.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pope_Urban_II" title="Pope Urban II">Pope Urban II</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Clermont" title="Council of Clermont">Council of Clermont</a>, where he preached the <a href="/wiki/First_Crusade" title="First Crusade">First Crusade</a>. Illustration by <a href="/wiki/Jean_Colombe" title="Jean Colombe">Jean Colombe</a> from the <i><a href="/wiki/Passages_d%27outremer" title="Passages d'outremer">Passages d'outremer</a></i>, c. 1490.</div></div></div>
<p>In the West, from the 11th century onward, some older cathedral schools <a href="/wiki/Medieval_university" title="Medieval university">became universities</a> (see, for example, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oxford" title="University of Oxford">University of Oxford</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Paris" title="University of Paris">University of Paris</a> and <a href="/wiki/University_of_Bologna" title="University of Bologna">University of Bologna</a>). Previously, higher education had been the domain of Christian <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_school" title="Cathedral school">cathedral schools</a> or <a href="/wiki/Monastic_school" title="Monastic school">monastic schools</a> (<i>Scholae monasticae</i>), led by <a href="/wiki/Monk" title="Monk">monks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nun" title="Nun">nuns</a>. Evidence of such schools dates back to the 6th century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[226]</a></sup> These new universities expanded the curriculum to include academic programs for clerics, lawyers, civil servants, and physicians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[227]</a></sup> The university is generally regarded as an institution that has its origin in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Christianity" title="History of Christianity">Medieval Christian</a> setting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-verger1999_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-verger1999-233">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rüegg,_Walter_1992,_pp._XIX_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rüegg,_Walter_1992,_pp._XIX-235">[230]</a></sup>
</p><p>Accompanying the rise of the "new towns" throughout Europe, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mendicant_order" title="Mendicant order">mendicant orders</a> were founded, bringing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Consecrated_life_(Catholic_Church)" title="Consecrated life (Catholic Church)">consecrated religious life</a> out of the monastery and into the new urban setting. The two principal mendicant movements were the <a href="/wiki/Franciscans" title="Franciscans">Franciscans</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[231]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Order" title="Dominican Order">Dominicans</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[232]</a></sup> founded by <a href="/wiki/Francis_of_Assisi" title="Francis of Assisi">St. Francis</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Dominic" title="St. Dominic">St. Dominic</a>, respectively. Both orders made significant contributions to the development of the great universities of Europe. Another new order was the <a href="/wiki/Cistercians" title="Cistercians">Cistercians</a>, whose large isolated monasteries spearheaded the settlement of former wilderness areas. In this period, church building and ecclesiastical architecture reached new heights, culminating in the orders of <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_architecture" title="Romanesque architecture">Romanesque</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gothic_architecture" title="Gothic architecture">Gothic architecture</a> and the building of the great European cathedrals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[233]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Christian_nationalism" title="Christian nationalism">Christian nationalism</a> emerged during this era in which Christians felt the impulse to recover lands in which Christianity had historically flourished.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USE2005_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-USE2005-239">[234]</a></sup> From 1095 under the pontificate of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Urban_II" title="Urban II">Urban II</a>, the <a href="/wiki/First_Crusade" title="First Crusade">First Crusade</a> was launched.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[235]</a></sup> These were a series of military campaigns in the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Land" title="Holy Land">Holy Land</a> and elsewhere, initiated in response to pleas from the Byzantine Emperor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alexios_I" title="Alexios I">Alexios I</a> for aid against <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turkish</a> expansion. The Crusades ultimately failed to stifle Islamic aggression and even contributed to Christian enmity with the sacking of <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Crusade" title="Fourth Crusade">Fourth Crusade</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[236]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Christian Church experienced internal conflict between the 7th and 13th centuries that resulted in a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East-West_Schism" title="East-West Schism">schism</a> between the so-called Latin or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Christian" title="Western Christian">Western Christian</a> branch (the Catholic Church),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[237]</a></sup> and an <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern</a>, largely Greek, branch (the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>). The two sides disagreed on a number of administrative, liturgical and doctrinal issues, most prominently <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_opposition_to_papal_supremacy" title="Eastern Orthodox opposition to papal supremacy">Eastern Orthodox opposition to papal supremacy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Orthodox_Information_Centre-Great_Schism_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-Orthodox_Information_Centre-Great_Schism-243">[238]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SandSp91_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-SandSp91-244">[239]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Second_Council_of_Lyon" title="Second Council of Lyon">Second Council of Lyon</a> (1274) and the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Florence" title="Council of Florence">Council of Florence</a> (1439) attempted to reunite the churches, but in both cases, the Eastern Orthodox refused to implement the decisions, and the two principal churches remain in schism to the present day. However, the Catholic Church has achieved union with various <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">smaller eastern churches</a>.
</p><p>In the thirteenth century, a new emphasis on Jesus' suffering, exemplified by the Franciscans' preaching, had the consequence of turning worshippers' attention towards Jews, on whom <a href="/wiki/Jewish_deicide" title="Jewish deicide">Christians had placed the blame for Jesus' death</a>. Christianity's limited tolerance of Jews was not new—Augustine of Hippo said that Jews should not be allowed to enjoy the citizenship that Christians took for granted—but the growing antipathy towards Jews was a factor that led to <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Expulsion" title="Edict of Expulsion">the expulsion of Jews from England in 1290</a>, the first of many such expulsions in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-diarmaid_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-diarmaid-245">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-telushkin_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-telushkin-246">[241]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beginning around 1184, following the crusade against <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cathars" title="Cathars">Cathar</a> heresy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[242]</a></sup> various institutions, broadly referred to as the <a href="/wiki/Inquisition" title="Inquisition">Inquisition</a>, were established with the aim of suppressing <a href="/wiki/Heresy" title="Heresy">heresy</a> and securing religious and doctrinal unity within Christianity through <a href="/wiki/Religious_conversion" title="Religious conversion">conversion</a> and prosecution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[243]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_era">Modern era</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_modern_era" title="Christianity in the modern era">Christianity in the modern era</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Protestant_Reformation_and_Counter-Reformation">Protestant Reformation and Counter-Reformation</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Reformation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Counter-Reformation" title="Counter-Reformation">Counter-Reformation</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/European_wars_of_religion" title="European wars of religion">European wars of religion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_Papacy" title="Renaissance Papacy">Renaissance Papacy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Luther_95_Thesen.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4611" data-file-width="3228" decoding="async" height="243" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Luther_95_Thesen.png/170px-Luther_95_Thesen.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Luther_95_Thesen.png/255px-Luther_95_Thesen.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Luther_95_Thesen.png/340px-Luther_95_Thesen.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Luther_95_Thesen.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther" title="Martin Luther">Martin Luther</a> initiated the <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Reformation</a> with his <i><a href="/wiki/Ninety-five_Theses" title="Ninety-five Theses">Ninety-five Theses</a></i> in 1517.</div></div></div>
<p>The 15th-century <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> brought about a renewed interest in ancient and classical learning. During the <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Reformation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther" title="Martin Luther">Martin Luther</a> posted the <i><a href="/wiki/Ninety-five_Theses" title="Ninety-five Theses">Ninety-five Theses</a></i> 1517 against the sale of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indulgences" title="Indulgences">indulgences</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Simon_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-Simon-249">[244]</a></sup> Printed copies soon spread throughout Europe. In 1521 the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edict_of_Worms" title="Edict of Worms">Edict of Worms</a> condemned and excommunicated Luther and his followers, resulting in the schism of the <a href="/wiki/Western_Christianity" title="Western Christianity">Western Christendom</a> into several branches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Simon-120-121_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-Simon-120-121-250">[245]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other reformers like <a href="/wiki/Huldrych_Zwingli" title="Huldrych Zwingli">Zwingli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Oecolampadius" title="Johannes Oecolampadius">Oecolampadius</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Calvin" title="John Calvin">Calvin</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Knox" title="John Knox">Knox</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jacobus_Arminius" title="Jacobus Arminius">Arminius</a> further criticized Catholic teaching and worship. These challenges developed into the movement called <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a>, which repudiated the <a href="/wiki/Papal_primacy" title="Papal primacy">primacy of the pope</a>, the role of tradition, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_sacraments" title="Catholic sacraments">seven sacraments</a>, and other doctrines and practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Simon_249-1"><a href="#cite_note-Simon-249">[244]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/English_Reformation" title="English Reformation">Reformation in England</a> began in 1534, when <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Henry_VIII_of_England" title="Henry VIII of England">King Henry VIII</a> had himself <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Act_of_Supremacy" title="Act of Supremacy">declared head</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_England" title="Church of England">Church of England</a>. Beginning in 1536, the monasteries throughout England, Wales and Ireland were <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_monasteries" title="Dissolution of the monasteries">dissolved</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schama_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-Schama-251">[246]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Thomas_M%C3%BCntzer" title="Thomas Müntzer">Thomas Müntzer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andreas_Karlstadt" title="Andreas Karlstadt">Andreas Karlstadt</a> and other theologians perceived both the Catholic Church and the confessions of the <a href="/wiki/Magisterial_Reformation" title="Magisterial Reformation">Magisterial Reformation</a> as corrupted. Their activity brought about the <a href="/wiki/Radical_Reformation" title="Radical Reformation">Radical Reformation</a>, which gave birth to various <a href="/wiki/Anabaptism" title="Anabaptism">Anabaptist</a> denominations.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michelangelo%27s_Pieta_5450_cropncleaned_edit.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1660" data-file-width="1584" decoding="async" height="231" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Michelangelo%27s_Pieta_5450_cropncleaned_edit.jpg/220px-Michelangelo%27s_Pieta_5450_cropncleaned_edit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Michelangelo%27s_Pieta_5450_cropncleaned_edit.jpg/330px-Michelangelo%27s_Pieta_5450_cropncleaned_edit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Michelangelo%27s_Pieta_5450_cropncleaned_edit.jpg/440px-Michelangelo%27s_Pieta_5450_cropncleaned_edit.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michelangelo%27s_Pieta_5450_cropncleaned_edit.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Michelangelo" title="Michelangelo">Michelangelo</a>'s 1498–99 <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Michelangelo%27s_Piet%C3%A0" title="Michelangelo's Pietà">Pietà</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica" title="St. Peter's Basilica">St. Peter's Basilica</a>; the Catholic Church was among the patronages of the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-natgeo_254_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_254-252">[247]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[248]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[249]</a></sup></div></div></div>
