<p>Partly in response to the Protestant Reformation, the Catholic Church engaged in a substantial process of reform and renewal, known as the <a href="/wiki/Counter-Reformation" title="Counter-Reformation">Counter-Reformation</a> or Catholic Reform.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter2004242–244_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter2004242–244-255">[250]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Trent" title="Council of Trent">Council of Trent</a> clarified and reasserted Catholic doctrine. During the following centuries, competition between Catholicism and Protestantism became deeply entangled with political struggles among European states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Simon3_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-Simon3-256">[251]</a></sup>
</p><p>Meanwhile, the discovery of America by <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> in 1492 brought about a new wave of missionary activity. Partly from missionary zeal, but under the impetus of <a href="/wiki/Colonialism" title="Colonialism">colonial expansion</a> by the European powers, Christianity spread to the Americas, Oceania, East Asia and sub-Saharan Africa.
</p><p>Throughout Europe, the division caused by the Reformation led to outbreaks of <a href="/wiki/Religious_violence" title="Religious violence">religious violence</a> and the establishment of separate state churches in Europe. <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">Lutheranism</a> spread into the northern, central, and eastern parts of present-day Germany, <a href="/wiki/Livonia" title="Livonia">Livonia</a>, and Scandinavia. <a href="/wiki/Anglicanism" title="Anglicanism">Anglicanism</a> was established in England in 1534. <a href="/wiki/Calvinism" title="Calvinism">Calvinism</a> and its varieties, such as <a href="/wiki/Presbyterianism" title="Presbyterianism">Presbyterianism</a>, were introduced in Scotland, the Netherlands, Hungary, Switzerland, and France. <a href="/wiki/Arminianism" title="Arminianism">Arminianism</a> gained followers in the Netherlands and <a href="/wiki/Frisia" title="Frisia">Frisia</a>. Ultimately, these differences led to the outbreak of <a href="/wiki/Religious_war" title="Religious war">conflicts</a> in which religion played a key factor. The <a href="/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War" title="Thirty Years' War">Thirty Years' War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/English_Civil_War" title="English Civil War">English Civil War</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/French_Wars_of_Religion" title="French Wars of Religion">French Wars of Religion</a> are prominent examples. These events intensified the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_debate_on_persecution_and_toleration" title="Christian debate on persecution and toleration">Christian debate on persecution and toleration</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[252]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the revival of neoplatonism <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_humanism" title="Renaissance humanism">Renaissance humanists</a> did not reject Christianity; quite the contrary, many of the greatest works of the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> were devoted to it, and the Catholic Church patronized many works of <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_art" title="Renaissance art">Renaissance art</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-openuni_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-openuni-258">[253]</a></sup> Much, if not most, of the new art was commissioned by or in dedication to the Church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-openuni_258-1"><a href="#cite_note-openuni-258">[253]</a></sup> Some scholars and historians attribute Christianity to having contributed to the rise of the <a href="/wiki/Scientific_Revolution" title="Scientific Revolution">Scientific Revolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[254]</a></sup> Many well-known historical figures who influenced <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_science" title="Western science">Western science</a> considered themselves Christian such as <a href="/wiki/Nicolaus_Copernicus" title="Nicolaus Copernicus">Nicolaus Copernicus</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[255]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Galileo_Galilei" title="Galileo Galilei">Galileo Galilei</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[256]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Kepler" title="Johannes Kepler">Johannes Kepler</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[257]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Newton" title="Isaac Newton">Isaac Newton</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Newton_–_1_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-Newton_–_1-263">[258]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Boyle" title="Robert Boyle">Robert Boyle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[259]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-Enlightenment">Post-Enlightenment</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Madonna_and_Child,_Kakure_Kirishitan.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="416" data-file-width="370" decoding="async" height="247" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Madonna_and_Child%2C_Kakure_Kirishitan.jpg/220px-Madonna_and_Child%2C_Kakure_Kirishitan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Madonna_and_Child%2C_Kakure_Kirishitan.jpg/330px-Madonna_and_Child%2C_Kakure_Kirishitan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f9/Madonna_and_Child%2C_Kakure_Kirishitan.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Madonna_and_Child,_Kakure_Kirishitan.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A depiction of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madonna_and_Child" title="Madonna and Child">Madonna and Child</a> in a 19th-century <a href="/wiki/Kakure_Kirishitan" title="Kakure Kirishitan">Kakure Kirishitan</a> <a href="/wiki/Ukiyo-e" title="Ukiyo-e">Japanese woodcut</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In the era known as the <a href="/wiki/Great_Divergence" title="Great Divergence">Great Divergence</a>, when in the West, the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scientific_revolution" title="Scientific revolution">scientific revolution</a> brought about great societal changes, Christianity was confronted with various forms of <a href="/wiki/Skepticism" title="Skepticism">skepticism</a> and with certain modern <a href="/wiki/Ideology" title="Ideology">political ideologies</a>, such as versions of <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liberalism" title="Liberalism">liberalism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[260]</a></sup> Events ranged from mere <a href="/wiki/Anti-clericalism" title="Anti-clericalism">anti-clericalism</a> to violent outbursts against Christianity, such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dechristianisation_of_France_during_the_French_Revolution" title="Dechristianisation of France during the French Revolution">dechristianization of France during the French Revolution</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[261]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War" title="Spanish Civil War">Spanish Civil War</a>, and certain <a href="/wiki/Marxism" title="Marxism">Marxist</a> movements, especially <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution_(1917)" title="Russian Revolution (1917)">the Russian Revolution</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Christians_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union">persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union</a> under <a href="/wiki/State_atheism" title="State atheism">state atheism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[262]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[263]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Adappur2000_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-Adappur2000-269">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[265]</a></sup>
</p><p>Especially pressing in Europe was the formation of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nation_states" title="Nation states">nation states</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_era" title="Napoleonic era">Napoleonic era</a>. In all European countries, different Christian denominations found themselves in competition to greater or lesser extents with each other and with the state. Variables were the relative sizes of the denominations and the religious, political, and ideological orientation of the states. Urs Altermatt of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Fribourg" title="University of Fribourg">University of Fribourg</a>, looking specifically at Catholicism in Europe, identifies four models for the European nations. In traditionally Catholic-majority countries such as Belgium, Spain, and Austria, to some extent, religious and national communities are more or less identical. Cultural symbiosis and separation are found in Poland, the Republic of Ireland, and Switzerland, all countries with competing denominations. Competition is found in Germany, the Netherlands, and again Switzerland, all countries with minority Catholic populations, which to a greater or lesser extent identified with the nation. Finally, separation between religion (again, specifically Catholicism) and the state is found to a great degree in France and Italy, countries where the state actively opposed itself to the authority of the Catholic Church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[266]</a></sup>
</p><p>The combined factors of the formation of nation states and <a href="/wiki/Ultramontanism" title="Ultramontanism">ultramontanism</a>, especially in Germany and the Netherlands, but also in England to a much lesser extent,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[267]</a></sup> often forced Catholic churches, organizations, and believers to choose between the national demands of the state and the authority of the Church, specifically the papacy. This conflict came to a head in the <a href="/wiki/First_Vatican_Council" title="First Vatican Council">First Vatican Council</a>, and in Germany would lead directly to the <i><a href="/wiki/Kulturkampf" title="Kulturkampf">Kulturkampf</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[268]</a></sup> where liberals and Protestants under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Otto_von_Bismarck" title="Otto von Bismarck">Bismarck</a> managed to severely restrict Catholic expression and organization.
</p><p>Christian commitment in Europe dropped as modernity and secularism came into their own,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[269]</a></sup> particularly in the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">Estonia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[270]</a></sup> while religious commitments in America have been generally high in comparison to Europe. Changes in worldwide Christianity over the last century have been significant, since 1900, Christianity has spread rapidly in  in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_South" title="Global South">Global South</a> and Third World countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[271]</a></sup> The late 20th century has shown the shift of Christian adherence to the <a href="/wiki/Third_World" title="Third World">Third World</a> and the Southern Hemisphere in general,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[272]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hanciles2008_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hanciles2008-278">[273]</a></sup> with the West no longer the chief standard bearer of Christianity. Approximately 7 to 10% of <a href="/wiki/Arabs" title="Arabs">Arabs</a> are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_Christians_and_Arabic-speaking_Christians" title="Arab Christians and Arabic-speaking Christians">Christians</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pacini_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pacini-279">[274]</a></sup> most prevalent in Egypt, <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Christianity_by_country" title="Christianity by country">Christianity by country</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christian_population_growth" title="Christian population growth">Christian population growth</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Christendom" title="Christendom">Christendom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christian_state" title="Christian state">Christian state</a></div>
<p>With around 2.8 billion adherents,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-281">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-World-282">[277]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gordonconwell.edu_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-gordonconwell.edu-283">[278]</a></sup> split into three main branches of Catholic, Protestant, and Eastern Orthodox, Christianity is the <a href="/wiki/Major_religious_groups" title="Major religious groups">world's largest religion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewDec2012_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-PewDec2012-284">[279]</a></sup> The Christian share of the world's population has stood at around 33% for the last hundred years, which means that one in three persons on Earth are Christians. This masks a major shift in the demographics of Christianity; large increases in the developing world have been accompanied by substantial declines in the developed world, mainly in Western Europe and North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[280]</a></sup> According to a 2015 <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a> study, within the next four decades, Christianity will remain the largest religion; and by 2050, the Christian population is expected to exceed 3 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewProjections_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-PewProjections-286">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 60">: 60 </span></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Reabertura_Museu_de_Arte_Sacra_(18626301050).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3578" data-file-width="5368" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Reabertura_Museu_de_Arte_Sacra_%2818626301050%29.jpg/220px-Reabertura_Museu_de_Arte_Sacra_%2818626301050%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Reabertura_Museu_de_Arte_Sacra_%2818626301050%29.jpg/330px-Reabertura_Museu_de_Arte_Sacra_%2818626301050%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Reabertura_Museu_de_Arte_Sacra_%2818626301050%29.jpg/440px-Reabertura_Museu_de_Arte_Sacra_%2818626301050%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Reabertura_Museu_de_Arte_Sacra_(18626301050).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Christian procession in <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>, the country with the largest Catholic population in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewDec2012_284-1"><a href="#cite_note-PewDec2012-284">[279]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg/220px-%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg/330px-%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg/440px-%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Trinity_Sunday" title="Trinity Sunday">Trinity Sunday</a> in <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a> has experienced a great revival since the fall of communism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pew20152016_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pew20152016-287">[282]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>According to some scholars, Christianity ranks at first place in net gains through <a href="/wiki/Religious_conversion" title="Religious conversion">religious conversion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-he_Oxford_Handbook_of_Religious_Conversion_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-he_Oxford_Handbook_of_Religious_Conversion-288">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Evangelicalism_and_Conversion_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-Evangelicalism_and_Conversion-289">[284]</a></sup> As a percentage of Christians, the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a> and <a href="/wiki/Orthodoxy" title="Orthodoxy">Orthodoxy</a> (both <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodoxy" title="Oriental Orthodoxy">Oriental</a>) are declining in some parts of the world (though Catholicism is growing in Asia, in Africa, vibrant in Eastern Europe, etc.), while <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestants" title="Protestants">Protestants</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a> are on the rise in the developing world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pewforum1_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-pewforum1-290">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[286]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[287]</a></sup> The so-called <i>popular Protestantism</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[note 6]</a></sup> is one of the fastest growing religious categories in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[288]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.com_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com-295">[289]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barker_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-Barker-296">[290]</a></sup> Nevertheless, Catholicism will also continue to grow to 1.63 billion by 2050, according to Todd Johnson of the Center for the Study of Global Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[291]</a></sup> Africa alone, by 2015, will be home to 230 million African Catholics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[292]</a></sup> And if in 2018, the U.N. projects that Africa's population will reach 4.5 billion by 2100 (not 2 billion as predicted in 2004), Catholicism will indeed grow, as will other religious groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[293]</a></sup> According to Pew Research Center, Africa is expected to be home to 1.1 billion <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Africa" title="Christianity in Africa">African Christians</a> by 2050.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewProjections_286-1"><a href="#cite_note-PewProjections-286">[281]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2010, 87% of the world's Christian population lived in countries where Christians are in the majority, while 13% of the world's Christian population lived in countries where Christians are in the minority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Christianity_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Christianity-17">[17]</a></sup> Christianity is the predominant religion in Europe, the Americas, Oceania, and Southern Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Christianity_17-2"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Christianity-17">[17]</a></sup> In Asia, it is the dominant religion in Armenia, Cyprus, Georgia, East Timor, and the Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[294]</a></sup> However, it is declining in some areas including the northern and western United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[295]</a></sup> some areas in Oceania (Australia<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[296]</a></sup> and New Zealand<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2006table28_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-2006table28-303">[297]</a></sup>), northern Europe (including Great Britain,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[298]</a></sup> Scandinavia and other places), France, Germany, and the Canadian provinces of Ontario, British Columbia, and Quebec, and some parts of Asia (especially the Middle East, due to the <a href="/wiki/Christian_emigration" title="Christian emigration">Christian emigration</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[301]</a></sup> and Macau<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[302]</a></sup>).
</p><p>The Christian population is not decreasing in Brazil, the southern United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARIS2008_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-ARIS2008-309">[303]</a></sup> and the province of Alberta, Canada,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census2001_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-census2001-310">[304]</a></sup> but the percentage is decreasing. Since the fall of communism, the proportion of Christians has been stable or even increased in the  <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_European" title="Eastern European">Eastern European</a> countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pew_Research_Center_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pew_Research_Center-311">[305]</a></sup> Christianity is growing rapidly in both numbers and percentage in <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewDec2012_284-2"><a href="#cite_note-PewDec2012-284">[279]</a></sup> other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asian_countries" title="Asian countries">Asian countries</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewDec2012_284-3"><a href="#cite_note-PewDec2012-284">[279]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Singapore_Management_University_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-Singapore_Management_University-313">[307]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan Africa</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewDec2012_284-4"><a href="#cite_note-PewDec2012-284">[279]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Next_Christendom_2002_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Next_Christendom_2002-314">[308]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewDec2012_284-5"><a href="#cite_note-PewDec2012-284">[279]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pew_Research_Center_311-1"><a href="#cite_note-Pew_Research_Center-311">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pew20152016_287-1"><a href="#cite_note-Pew20152016-287">[282]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a> (<a href="/wiki/Maghreb" title="Maghreb">Maghreb</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-academia.edu_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-315">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Next_Christendom_2002_314-1"><a href="#cite_note-The_Next_Christendom_2002-314">[308]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Cooperation_Council" title="Gulf Cooperation Council">Gulf Cooperation Council</a> countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewDec2012_284-6"><a href="#cite_note-PewDec2012-284">[279]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Next_Christendom_2002_314-2"><a href="#cite_note-The_Next_Christendom_2002-314">[308]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite the declining numbers, Christianity remains the dominant religion in the Western World, where 70% are Christians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Christianity_17-3"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Christianity-17">[17]</a></sup> Christianity remains the largest religion in <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a>, where 71% of Western <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europeans</a> identified themselves as <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christian</a> in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[310]</a></sup>  A 2011 <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a> survey found that 76% of Europeans, 73% in Oceania and about 86% in the Americas (90% in Latin America and 77% in North America) identified themselves as Christians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Christianity_17-4"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Christianity-17">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[312]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[313]</a></sup> By 2010 about 157 countries and territories in the world had <a href="/wiki/Christianity_by_country" title="Christianity by country">Christian majorities</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewDec2012_284-7"><a href="#cite_note-PewDec2012-284">[279]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, there are many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charismatic_movements" title="Charismatic movements">charismatic movements</a> that have become well established over large parts of the world, especially Africa, Latin America, and Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[314]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[315]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-movedbythespirit_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-movedbythespirit-322">[316]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannica_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-323">[317]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CTReview_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-CTReview-324">[318]</a></sup> Since 1900, primarily due to conversion, Protestantism has spread rapidly in Africa, Asia, Oceania, and Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encyclopedia_of_Protestantism_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopedia_of_Protestantism-325">[319]</a></sup> From 1960 to 2000, the global growth of the number of reported <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evangelical_Protestants" title="Evangelical Protestants">Evangelical Protestants</a> grew three times the world's population rate, and twice that of <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[320]</a></sup> According to the historian <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Blainey" title="Geoffrey Blainey">Geoffrey Blainey</a> from the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Melbourne" title="University of Melbourne">University of Melbourne</a>, since the 1960s there has been a substantial increase in the number of conversions from Islam to Christianity, mostly to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evangelical" title="Evangelical">Evangelical</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pentecostal" title="Pentecostal">Pentecostal</a> forms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[321]</a></sup> A study conducted by St. Mary's University estimated about 10.2 million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Convert_to_Christianity" title="Convert to Christianity">converts to Christianity</a> in 2015;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-academia.edu_315-1"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-315">[309]</a></sup> according to the study significant numbers of Muslim converts to Christianity can be found in Afghanistan,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-academia.edu_315-2"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-315">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-https_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-https-328">[322]</a></sup> Azerbaijan,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-academia.edu_315-3"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-315">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-https_328-1"><a href="#cite_note-https-328">[322]</a></sup> Central Asia (including Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, and other countries),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-academia.edu_315-4"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-315">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-https_328-2"><a href="#cite_note-https-328">[322]</a></sup> Indonesia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-academia.edu_315-5"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-315">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-https_328-3"><a href="#cite_note-https-328">[322]</a></sup> Malaysia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-academia.edu_315-6"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-315">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-https_328-4"><a href="#cite_note-https-328">[322]</a></sup> the Middle East (including Iran, Saudi Arabia, Turkey,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[323]</a></sup> and other countries),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-academia.edu_315-7"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-315">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-https_328-5"><a href="#cite_note-https-328">[322]</a></sup> North Africa (including Algeria, Morocco,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto10_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto10-330">[324]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto15_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto15-331">[325]</a></sup> and Tunisia<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-report_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-report-332">[326]</a></sup>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-academia.edu_315-8"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-315">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-https_328-6"><a href="#cite_note-https-328">[322]</a></sup> Sub-Saharan Africa,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-academia.edu_315-9"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-315">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-https_328-7"><a href="#cite_note-https-328">[322]</a></sup> and the Western World (including Albania, Belgium, France, Germany, Kosovo, the Netherlands, Russia, Scandinavia, United Kingdom, the United States, and other western countries).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-academia.edu_315-10"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-315">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-https_328-8"><a href="#cite_note-https-328">[322]</a></sup> It is also reported that Christianity is popular among people of different backgrounds in Africa and Asia; according to a report by the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Management_University" title="Singapore Management University">Singapore Management University</a>, more people in Southeast Asia are converting to Christianity, many of them young and having a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_degree" title="University degree">university degree</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Singapore_Management_University_313-1"><a href="#cite_note-Singapore_Management_University-313">[307]</a></sup> According to scholar Juliette Koning and Heidi Dahles of <a href="/wiki/Vrije_Universiteit_Amsterdam" title="Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam">Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam</a>  there is a "rapid expansion" of <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Singapore" title="Christianity in Singapore">Christianity in Singapore</a>, China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Indonesia" title="Christianity in Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, Malaysia, and South Korea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Singapore_Management_University_313-2"><a href="#cite_note-Singapore_Management_University-313">[307]</a></sup> According to scholar Terence Chong from the Institute of Southeast Asian Studies, since the 1980s Christianity is expanding in China, Singapore,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[327]</a></sup> Indonesia, <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Japan" title="Christianity in Japan">Japan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-christianpost.com_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-christianpost.com-334">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[329]</a></sup> Malaysia, Taiwan, South Korea,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Christianity_17-5"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Christianity-17">[17]</a></sup> and Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[330]</a></sup>
</p><p>In most countries in the developed world, <a href="/wiki/Church_attendance" title="Church attendance">church attendance</a> among people who continue to identify themselves as Christians has been falling over the last few decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[331]</a></sup> Some sources view this simply as part of a drift away from traditional membership institutions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[332]</a></sup> while others link it to signs of a decline in belief in the importance of religion in general.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[333]</a></sup> Europe's Christian population, though in decline, still constitutes the largest geographical component of the religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[334]</a></sup> According to data from the 2012 European Social Survey, around a third of <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Europe" title="Christianity in Europe">European Christians</a> say they attend services once a month or more.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economist_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-economist-341">[335]</a></sup> Conversely, according to the <a href="/wiki/World_Values_Survey" title="World Values Survey">World Values Survey</a>, about more than two-thirds of Latin American Christians, and about 90% of <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Africa" title="Christianity in Africa">African Christians</a> (in Ghana, Nigeria, Rwanda, South Africa and Zimbabwe) said they attended church regularly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economist_341-1"><a href="#cite_note-economist-341">[335]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Christian_state" title="Christian state">Christianity</a>, in one form or another, is the sole <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a> of the following nations: Argentina (Catholic),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Argentina_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Argentina-342">[336]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tuvalu" title="Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a> (Reformed), <a href="/wiki/Tonga" title="Tonga">Tonga</a> (Methodist), Norway (Lutheran),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-abcnyheter_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-abcnyheter-343">[337]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[339]</a></sup> Costa Rica (Catholic),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Costa_Rica_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Costa_Rica-346">[340]</a></sup> the Kingdom of Denmark (Lutheran),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Denmark_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Denmark-347">[341]</a></sup> England (Anglican),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Centre_for_Citizenship-England_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-Centre_for_Citizenship-England-348">[342]</a></sup> Georgia (Georgian Orthodox),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beliefnet-Georgia_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-Beliefnet-Georgia-349">[343]</a></sup> Greece (Greek Orthodox),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encyclopædia_Britannica-El_Salvador_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopædia_Britannica-El_Salvador-350">[344]</a></sup> Iceland (Lutheran),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Iceland_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Iceland-351">[345]</a></sup> Liechtenstein (Catholic),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-U.S._Department_of_State-Liechtenstein_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-U.S._Department_of_State-Liechtenstein-352">[346]</a></sup> Malta (Catholic),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Malta_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Malta-353">[347]</a></sup> Monaco (Catholic),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Monaco_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Monaco-354">[348]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a> (Catholic).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Vatican_City_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopædia_Britannica-Vatican_City-355">[349]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are numerous other countries, such as Cyprus, which although do not have an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Established_church" title="Established church">established church</a>, still give official recognition and support to a specific <a href="/wiki/Christian_denomination" title="Christian denomination">Christian denomination</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-U.S._Department_of_State-Cyprus_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-U.S._Department_of_State-Cyprus-356">[350]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Churches_and_denominations">Churches and denominations</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Christian_denominations" title="List of Christian denominations">List of Christian denominations</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Christian_denominations_by_number_of_members" title="List of Christian denominations by number of members">List of Christian denominations by number of members</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_schisms_in_Christianity" title="List of schisms in Christianity">List of schisms in Christianity</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiology" title="Ecclesiology">Ecclesiology</a></div>
<p>Christianity can be taxonomically divided into six main groups: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholicism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox_Churches" title="Oriental Orthodox Churches">Oriental Orthodoxy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodoxy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_East" title="Church of the East">Church of the East</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Restorationism" title="Restorationism">Restorationism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Riswold2009_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-Riswold2009-363">[357]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mitchell2010_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mitchell2010-364">[358]</a></sup> A broader distinction that is sometimes drawn is between <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern Christianity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Christianity" title="Western Christianity">Western Christianity</a>, which has its origins in the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">East–West Schism</a> (Great Schism) of the 11th century. Recently, neither Western or Eastern <a href="/wiki/World_Christianity" title="World Christianity">World Christianity</a> has also stood out, for example, in <a href="/wiki/African-initiated_church" title="African-initiated church">African-initiated churches</a>. However, there are other present<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Religious_Tolerance—Four_Sects_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-Religious_Tolerance—Four_Sects-365">[359]</a></sup> and historical<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[360]</a></sup> Christian groups that do not fit neatly into one of these primary categories.
</p><p>There is a diversity of <a href="/wiki/Doctrine" title="Doctrine">doctrines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liturgy" title="Liturgy">liturgical</a> practices among groups calling themselves Christian. These groups may vary <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiology" title="Ecclesiology">ecclesiologically</a> in their views on a classification of <a href="/wiki/Christian_denomination" title="Christian denomination">Christian denominations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[361]</a></sup> The Nicene Creed (325), however, is typically accepted as authoritative by most Christians, including the Catholic, Eastern Orthodox, Oriental Orthodox, and major Protestant (such as Lutheran and Anglican) denominations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[362]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="clade clade-words noresize nowrap" style="position: relative;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Christianity_Branches_without_text.svg"><img alt="Christianity Branches without text.svg" data-file-height="911" data-file-width="2416" decoding="async" height="264" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Christianity_Branches_without_text.svg/700px-Christianity_Branches_without_text.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Christianity_Branches_without_text.svg/1050px-Christianity_Branches_without_text.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Christianity_Branches_without_text.svg/1400px-Christianity_Branches_without_text.svg.png 2x" width="700"/></a>

<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:680px; top:170.5px"><span style="display: inline-block; -ms-transform: rotate(-90deg); -webkit-transform: rotate(-90deg); transform: rotate(-90deg);;"><i><a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern Christianity</a></i></span></div>

<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:540px; top:98.4px"><a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church"><span style="color:red;">(Latin Church)</span></a></div>

<div style="position:absolute; left:540px; top:177.5px"><a href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox_Churches" title="Oriental Orthodox Churches"><span style="color:purple;">Oriental Orthodox Churches</span></a></div>
