<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Catholic_Church">Catholic Church</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pope_Francis_in_March_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="996" data-file-width="996" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Pope_Francis_in_March_2013.jpg/220px-Pope_Francis_in_March_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Pope_Francis_in_March_2013.jpg/330px-Pope_Francis_in_March_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Pope_Francis_in_March_2013.jpg/440px-Pope_Francis_in_March_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pope_Francis_in_March_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a>, the current leader of the Catholic Church.</div></div></div>
<p>The Catholic Church consists of those <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Particular_Church" title="Particular Church">particular churches</a>, headed by bishops, in communion with the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">pope</a>, the bishop of Rome, as its highest authority in matters of faith, morality, and church governance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LumenG_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-LumenG-369">[363]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SandSp1_370-0"><a href="#cite_note-SandSp1-370">[364]</a></sup> Like <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox">Eastern Orthodoxy</a>, the Catholic Church, through <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_succession" title="Apostolic succession">apostolic succession</a>, traces its origins to the Christian community founded by Jesus Christ.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NatGeographic281_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-NatGeographic281-371">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norman11_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-Norman11-372">[366]</a></sup> Catholics maintain that the "<a href="/wiki/Four_Marks_of_the_Church" title="Four Marks of the Church">one, holy, catholic, and apostolic church</a>" founded by Jesus <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%22Subsistit_in%22_in_Lumen_Gentium" title='"Subsistit in" in Lumen Gentium'>subsists fully</a> in the Catholic Church, but also acknowledges other Christian churches and communities<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LumenGentium_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-LumenGentium-373">[367]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[368]</a></sup> and works towards <a href="/wiki/Ecumenism" title="Ecumenism">reconciliation</a> among all Christians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LumenGentium_373-1"><a href="#cite_note-LumenGentium-373">[367]</a></sup> The Catholic faith is detailed in the <i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cat_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-cat-375">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[370]</a></sup>
</p><p>Of its <a href="/wiki/Sacraments_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Sacraments of the Catholic Church">seven sacraments</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eucharist_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Eucharist in the Catholic Church">Eucharist</a> is the principal one, celebrated <a href="/wiki/Catholic_liturgy" title="Catholic liturgy">liturgically</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Mass_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Mass in the Catholic Church">Mass</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[371]</a></sup> The church teaches that through <a href="/wiki/Consecration#Eucharist" title="Consecration">consecration</a> by a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Priesthood_(Catholic_Church)" title="Priesthood (Catholic Church)">priest</a>, the sacrificial <a href="/wiki/Sacramental_bread" title="Sacramental bread">bread</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sacramental_wine" title="Sacramental wine">wine</a> <a href="/wiki/Transubstantiation" title="Transubstantiation">become the body and blood of Christ</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Virgin_Mary" title="Virgin Mary">Virgin Mary</a> is <a href="/wiki/Veneration_of_Mary_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church">venerated</a> in the Catholic Church as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mother_of_God" title="Mother of God">Mother of God</a> and <a href="/wiki/Queen_of_Heaven" title="Queen of Heaven">Queen of Heaven</a>, honoured in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mariology_of_the_Catholic_Church#Dogmatic_teachings" title="Mariology of the Catholic Church">dogmas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marian_devotions" title="Marian devotions">devotions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marian_dogmas_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-marian_dogmas-378">[372]</a></sup> Its teaching includes <a href="/wiki/Divine_Mercy" title="Divine Mercy">Divine Mercy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sanctification" title="Sanctification">sanctification</a> through faith and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evangelization" title="Evangelization">evangelization</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Gospel" title="The Gospel">the Gospel</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/Catholic_social_teaching" title="Catholic social teaching">Catholic social teaching</a>, which emphasises voluntary support for the sick, the poor, and the afflicted through the <a href="/wiki/Works_of_mercy" title="Works of mercy">corporal and spiritual works of mercy</a>. The Catholic Church operates thousands of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_schools" title="Catholic schools">Catholic schools</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_higher_education" title="Catholic higher education">universities</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_health_care" title="Catholic Church and health care">hospitals</a>, and orphanages around the world, and is the largest non-government provider of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_education" title="Catholic education">education</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Healthcare_and_the_Catholic_Church" title="Healthcare and the Catholic Church">health care</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geopolitics_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-Geopolitics-379">[373]</a></sup> Among its other social services are numerous charitable and humanitarian organizations.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Canon_law_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Canon law of the Catholic Church">Canon law</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">Latin</a>: <i lang="la">jus canonicum</i>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[374]</a></sup> is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legal_system" title="Legal system">system</a> of <a href="/wiki/Law" title="Law">laws</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canon_law" title="Canon law">legal principles</a> made and enforced by the <a href="/wiki/Hierarchy_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Hierarchy of the Catholic Church">hierarchical authorities</a> of the Catholic Church to regulate its external organisation and government and to order and direct the activities of Catholics toward the mission of the church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[375]</a></sup> The canon law of the Latin Church was the first modern Western <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legal_system" title="Legal system">legal system</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[376]</a></sup> and is the oldest continuously functioning legal system in the West.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[378]</a></sup> while the distinctive traditions of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_canon_law" title="Eastern Catholic canon law">Eastern Catholic canon law</a> govern the 23 Eastern Catholic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Particular_church" title="Particular church">particular churches</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Sui_iuris" title="Sui iuris">sui iuris</a>.</i>
</p><p>As the world's oldest and largest continuously functioning international institution,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[379]</a></sup> it has played a prominent role in the history and development of <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Western_civilization" title="Western civilization">Western civilization</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-O'CollinsPref_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-O'CollinsPref-386">[380]</a></sup> The 2,834 <a href="/wiki/Episcopal_see" title="Episcopal see">sees</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[381]</a></sup> are grouped into <a href="/wiki/Sui_iuris#Catholic_ecclesiastical_use" title="Sui iuris">24 particular autonomous Churches</a> (the largest of which being the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin Church</a>), each with its own distinct traditions regarding the <a href="/wiki/Liturgy" title="Liturgy">liturgy</a> and the administering of <a href="/wiki/Sacraments_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Sacraments of the Catholic Church">sacraments</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OneFaith71_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-OneFaith71-388">[382]</a></sup> With more than 1.1 billion baptized members, the Catholic Church is the largest Christian <a href="/wiki/Christian_Church" title="Christian Church">church</a> and represents 50.1%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Christianity_17-6"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Christianity-17">[17]</a></sup> all Christians as well as one sixth of the <a href="/wiki/World_population" title="World population">world's population</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-389">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Adherents_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-Adherents-390">[384]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[385]</a></sup> Catholics live all over the world through <a href="/wiki/Catholic_missions" title="Catholic missions">missions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diaspora" title="Diaspora">diaspora</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Conversion_to_Christianity" title="Conversion to Christianity">conversions</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Eastern_Orthodox_Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Church_of_St._George,_Istanbul_(August_2010).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3168" data-file-width="4752" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Church_of_St._George%2C_Istanbul_%28August_2010%29.jpg/220px-Church_of_St._George%2C_Istanbul_%28August_2010%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Church_of_St._George%2C_Istanbul_%28August_2010%29.jpg/330px-Church_of_St._George%2C_Istanbul_%28August_2010%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Church_of_St._George%2C_Istanbul_%28August_2010%29.jpg/440px-Church_of_St._George%2C_Istanbul_%28August_2010%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Church_of_St._George,_Istanbul_(August_2010).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/St._George%27s_Cathedral,_Istanbul" title="St. George's Cathedral, Istanbul">St. George's Cathedral</a> in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>: It has been the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarchate_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople">Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople</a> whose leader is regarded as the <i><a href="/wiki/Primus_inter_pares" title="Primus inter pares">primus inter pares</a></i> in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[386]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The Eastern Orthodox Church consists of those churches in communion with the <a href="/wiki/Patriarch" title="Patriarch">patriarchal</a> sees of the East, such as the <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarch_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople">Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODCC1199_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-ODCC1199-393">[387]</a></sup> Like the Catholic Church, the Eastern Orthodox Church also traces its heritage to the foundation of Christianity through <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_succession" title="Apostolic succession">apostolic succession</a> and has an <a href="/wiki/Episcopal_polity" title="Episcopal polity">episcopal</a> structure, though the <a href="/wiki/Autocephaly" title="Autocephaly">autonomy</a> of its component parts is emphasized, and most of them are national churches.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_theology" title="Eastern Orthodox theology">Eastern Orthodox theology</a> is based on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holy_tradition" title="Holy tradition">holy tradition</a> which incorporates the dogmatic decrees of the <a href="/wiki/First_seven_ecumenical_councils" title="First seven ecumenical councils">seven Ecumenical Councils</a>, the Scriptures, and the teaching of the <a href="/wiki/Church_Fathers" title="Church Fathers">Church Fathers</a>. The church teaches that it is the <a href="/wiki/Four_Marks_of_the_Church" title="Four Marks of the Church">one, holy, catholic and apostolic</a> <a href="/wiki/One_true_church" title="One true church">church</a> established by <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Christianity" title="Jesus in Christianity">Jesus Christ</a> in his <a href="/wiki/Great_Commission" title="Great Commission">Great Commission</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OCA_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-OCA-394">[388]</a></sup> and that its bishops are the successors of Christ's apostles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[389]</a></sup> It maintains that it practises the original Christian faith, as passed down by holy tradition. Its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Patriarchates" title="Patriarchates">patriarchates</a>, reminiscent of the <a href="/wiki/Pentarchy" title="Pentarchy">pentarchy</a>, and other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Autocephalous" title="Autocephalous">autocephalous</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Autonomous" title="Autonomous">autonomous</a> churches reflect a variety of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hierarchical" title="Hierarchical">hierarchical</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church_organization" title="Eastern Orthodox Church organization">organisation</a>. It recognises seven major sacraments, of which the <a href="/wiki/Eucharist" title="Eucharist">Eucharist</a> is the principal one, celebrated <a href="/wiki/Divine_Liturgy" title="Divine Liturgy">liturgically</a> in <a href="/wiki/Synaxis" title="Synaxis">synaxis</a>. The church teaches that through <a href="/wiki/Consecration#Eucharist" title="Consecration">consecration</a> <a href="/wiki/Epiclesis" title="Epiclesis">invoked</a> by a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Priesthood_(Orthodox_Church)" title="Priesthood (Orthodox Church)">priest</a>, the sacrificial bread and wine become the body and blood of Christ. The <a href="/wiki/Mary,_mother_of_Jesus" title="Mary, mother of Jesus">Virgin Mary</a> is <a href="/wiki/Veneration" title="Veneration">venerated</a> in the Eastern Orthodox Church as the <a href="/wiki/Theotokos" title="Theotokos">God-bearer</a>, honoured in <a href="/wiki/Marian_devotions" title="Marian devotions">devotions</a>.
</p><p>Eastern Orthodoxy is the second largest single denomination in Christianity, with an estimated 230 million adherents, although <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a> collectively outnumber them, substantially.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Christianity_17-7"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Christianity-17">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CSGC2019_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-CSGC2019-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aboutWeb_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-aboutWeb-396">[390]</a></sup> As one of the oldest surviving religious institutions in the world, the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a> has played a prominent role in the history and culture of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southeastern_Europe" title="Southeastern Europe">Southeastern Europe</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Near_East" title="Near East">Near East</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ware1993_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ware1993-397">[391]</a></sup> The majority of Eastern Orthodox Christians live mainly in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">Southeast</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, and parts of the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> region, <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Far_East" title="Russian Far East">Russian Far East</a>. Over half of Eastern Orthodox Christians follow the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a>, while the vast majority live within <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[392]</a></sup> There are also communities in the former <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine regions</a> of Africa, the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Mediterranean" title="Eastern Mediterranean">Eastern Mediterranean</a>, and in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>. Eastern Orthodox communities are also present in many other parts of the world, particularly North America, Western Europe, and Australia, formed through <a href="/wiki/Diaspora" title="Diaspora">diaspora</a>, <a href="/wiki/Conversion_to_Christianity" title="Conversion to Christianity">conversions</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Missionary" title="Missionary">missionary</a> activity.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Oriental_Orthodoxy">Oriental Orthodoxy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodoxy" title="Oriental Orthodoxy">Oriental Orthodoxy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Addis_abeba,_chiesa_della_trinit%C3%A0,_esterno_02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="4806" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Addis_abeba%2C_chiesa_della_trinit%C3%A0%2C_esterno_02.jpg/220px-Addis_abeba%2C_chiesa_della_trinit%C3%A0%2C_esterno_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Addis_abeba%2C_chiesa_della_trinit%C3%A0%2C_esterno_02.jpg/330px-Addis_abeba%2C_chiesa_della_trinit%C3%A0%2C_esterno_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Addis_abeba%2C_chiesa_della_trinit%C3%A0%2C_esterno_02.jpg/440px-Addis_abeba%2C_chiesa_della_trinit%C3%A0%2C_esterno_02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Addis_abeba,_chiesa_della_trinit%C3%A0,_esterno_02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Holy_Trinity_Cathedral_(Addis_Ababa)" title="Holy Trinity Cathedral (Addis Ababa)">Holy Trinity Cathedral</a> in <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a>, the seat of the Ethiopian Orthodox; the largest of the Oriental Orthodox Churches.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodoxy" title="Oriental Orthodoxy">Oriental Orthodox Churches</a> (also called "Old Oriental" churches) are those eastern churches that recognize the first three ecumenical councils—<a href="/wiki/First_Council_of_Nicaea" title="First Council of Nicaea">Nicaea</a>, <a href="/wiki/First_Council_of_Constantinople" title="First Council of Constantinople">Constantinople</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Council_of_Ephesus" title="First Council of Ephesus">Ephesus</a>—but reject the dogmatic definitions of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon" title="Council of Chalcedon">Council of Chalcedon</a> and instead espouse a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Miaphysite" title="Miaphysite">Miaphysite</a> <a href="/wiki/Christology" title="Christology">christology</a>.
</p><p>The Oriental Orthodox communion consists of six groups: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syriac_Orthodox" title="Syriac Orthodox">Syriac Orthodox</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church" title="Coptic Orthodox Church">Coptic Orthodox</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox" title="Ethiopian Orthodox">Ethiopian Orthodox</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eritrean_Orthodox" title="Eritrean Orthodox">Eritrean Orthodox</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malankara_Orthodox_Syrian_Church" title="Malankara Orthodox Syrian Church">Malankara Orthodox Syrian Church</a> (India), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Armenian_Apostolic" title="Armenian Apostolic">Armenian Apostolic</a> churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[393]</a></sup> These six churches, while being in communion with each other, are completely independent hierarchically.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[394]</a></sup> These churches are generally not in communion with the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>, with whom they are in dialogue for erecting a communion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sor.cua.edu_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-sor.cua.edu-401">[395]</a></sup> Together, they have about 62 million members worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[396]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[397]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[398]</a></sup>
</p><p>As some of the oldest religious institutions in the world, the Oriental Orthodox Churches have played a prominent role in the history and culture of <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eritrea" title="Eritrea">Eritrea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nubia#Christian_Nubia" title="Nubia">Sudan</a> and parts of the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a> and <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[399]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[400]</a></sup> An Eastern Christian body of <a href="/wiki/Autocephaly" title="Autocephaly">autocephalous</a> <a href="/wiki/Christian_denomination" title="Christian denomination">churches</a>, its <a href="/wiki/Bishop" title="Bishop">bishops</a> are equal by virtue of <a href="/wiki/Consecration#Ordination_of_bishops" title="Consecration">episcopal ordination</a>, and its doctrines can be summarized in that the churches recognize the validity of only the first three <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_council" title="Ecumenical council">ecumenical councils</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[401]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some Oriental Orthodox Churches such as the <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church" title="Coptic Orthodox Church">Coptic Orthodox</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox" title="Ethiopian Orthodox">Ethiopian Orthodox</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eritrean_Orthodox" title="Eritrean Orthodox">Eritrean Orthodox</a>, places a heavier emphasis on Old Testament teachings than one might find in other Christian denominations, and its followers adhere to certain practices: following <a href="/wiki/Christian_dietary_laws" title="Christian dietary laws">dietary rules</a> that are similar to Jewish <a href="/wiki/Kashrut" title="Kashrut">Kashrut</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[402]</a></sup> require that their male members undergo <a href="/wiki/Circumcision" title="Circumcision">circumcision</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[403]</a></sup> and observes <a href="/wiki/Ritual_purification" title="Ritual purification">ritual purification</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[404]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[405]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Assyrian_Church_of_the_East">Assyrian Church of the East</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_Church_of_the_East" title="Assyrian Church of the East">Assyrian Church of the East</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Church_of_Saint_John_the_Arab.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="625" data-file-width="867" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Church_of_Saint_John_the_Arab.jpg/220px-Church_of_Saint_John_the_Arab.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Church_of_Saint_John_the_Arab.jpg/330px-Church_of_Saint_John_the_Arab.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Church_of_Saint_John_the_Arab.jpg/440px-Church_of_Saint_John_the_Arab.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Church_of_Saint_John_the_Arab.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A 6th-century <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nestorian_church" title="Nestorian church">Nestorian church</a>, St. John the Arab, in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assyrian_tribes" title="Assyrian tribes">Assyrian village</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Andac" title="Andac">Geramon</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hakkari_(historical_region)" title="Hakkari (historical region)">Hakkari</a>, southeastern Turkey.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_East" title="Church of the East">Church of the East</a>, which was part of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Church" title="Great Church">Great Church</a>, shared <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communion_(Christian)" title="Communion (Christian)">communion</a> with those in the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> until the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ephesus" title="Council of Ephesus">Council of Ephesus</a> <a href="/wiki/Nestorian_schism" title="Nestorian schism">condemned</a> <a href="/wiki/Nestorius" title="Nestorius">Nestorius</a> in 431. Continuing as a <i><a href="/wiki/Dhimmi" title="Dhimmi">dhimmi</a></i> community under the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Sunni Caliphate</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia" title="Muslim conquest of Persia">Muslim conquest of Persia</a> (633–654), the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_East" title="Church of the East">Church of the East</a> played a major role in the history of <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Asia" title="Christianity in Asia">Christianity in Asia</a>. Between the 9th and 14th centuries, it represented the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Christian_denomination" title="Christian denomination">Christian denomination</a> in terms of geographical extent. It established <a href="/wiki/Dioceses_of_the_Church_of_the_East_to_1318" title="Dioceses of the Church of the East to 1318">dioceses</a> and communities stretching from the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> and today's Iraq and <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>, to <a href="/wiki/India_(East_Syriac_ecclesiastical_province)" title="India (East Syriac ecclesiastical province)">India</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Saint_Thomas_Christians" title="Saint Thomas Christians">Saint Thomas Syrian Christians</a> of <a href="/wiki/Kerala" title="Kerala">Kerala</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Christianity_among_the_Mongols" title="Christianity among the Mongols">Mongol kingdoms</a> in Central Asia, and <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_East_in_China" title="Church of the East in China">China</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a> (7th–9th centuries). In the 13th and 14th centuries, the church experienced a final period of expansion under the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_Empire" title="Mongol Empire">Mongol Empire</a>, where influential Church of the East clergy sat in the Mongol court.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_Church_of_the_East" title="Assyrian Church of the East">Assyrian Church of the East</a>, with an unbroken patriarchate established in the 17th century, is an independent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Christian" title="Eastern Christian">Eastern Christian</a> denomination which claims continuity from the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_East" title="Church of the East">Church of the East</a>—in parallel to the Catholic patriarchate established in the 16th century that evolved into the <a href="/wiki/Chaldean_Catholic_Church" title="Chaldean Catholic Church">Chaldean Catholic Church</a>, an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic" title="Eastern Catholic">Eastern Catholic</a> church in <a href="/wiki/Full_communion" title="Full communion">full communion</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a>. It is an Eastern Christian <a href="/wiki/Christian_denomination" title="Christian denomination">church</a> that follows the traditional <a href="/wiki/Christology" title="Christology">christology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiology" title="Ecclesiology">ecclesiology</a> of the historical Church of the East. Largely <a href="/wiki/Aniconism_in_Christianity" title="Aniconism in Christianity">aniconic</a> and not in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communion_(Christianity)" title="Communion (Christianity)">communion</a> with any other church, it belongs to the eastern branch of <a href="/wiki/Syriac_Christianity" title="Syriac Christianity">Syriac Christianity</a>, and uses the <a href="/wiki/East_Syriac_Rite" title="East Syriac Rite">East Syriac Rite</a> in its <a href="/wiki/Liturgy" title="Liturgy">liturgy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[406]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Church_of_Saint_Mary_-_Urmia_-_Iran_-_%DA%A9%D9%84%DB%8C%D8%B3%D8%A7%DB%8C_%D9%86%D9%86%D9%87_%D9%85%D8%B1%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%8C_%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%87_-_%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Church_of_Saint_Mary_-_Urmia_-_Iran_-_%DA%A9%D9%84%DB%8C%D8%B3%D8%A7%DB%8C_%D9%86%D9%86%D9%87_%D9%85%D8%B1%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%8C_%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%87_-_%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86.jpg/220px-Church_of_Saint_Mary_-_Urmia_-_Iran_-_%DA%A9%D9%84%DB%8C%D8%B3%D8%A7%DB%8C_%D9%86%D9%86%D9%87_%D9%85%D8%B1%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%8C_%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%87_-_%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Church_of_Saint_Mary_-_Urmia_-_Iran_-_%DA%A9%D9%84%DB%8C%D8%B3%D8%A7%DB%8C_%D9%86%D9%86%D9%87_%D9%85%D8%B1%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%8C_%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%87_-_%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86.jpg/330px-Church_of_Saint_Mary_-_Urmia_-_Iran_-_%DA%A9%D9%84%DB%8C%D8%B3%D8%A7%DB%8C_%D9%86%D9%86%D9%87_%D9%85%D8%B1%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%8C_%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%87_-_%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Church_of_Saint_Mary_-_Urmia_-_Iran_-_%DA%A9%D9%84%DB%8C%D8%B3%D8%A7%DB%8C_%D9%86%D9%86%D9%87_%D9%85%D8%B1%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%8C_%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%87_-_%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86.jpg/440px-Church_of_Saint_Mary_-_Urmia_-_Iran_-_%DA%A9%D9%84%DB%8C%D8%B3%D8%A7%DB%8C_%D9%86%D9%86%D9%87_%D9%85%D8%B1%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%8C_%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%87_-_%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Church_of_Saint_Mary_-_Urmia_-_Iran_-_%DA%A9%D9%84%DB%8C%D8%B3%D8%A7%DB%8C_%D9%86%D9%86%D9%87_%D9%85%D8%B1%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%8C_%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%87_-_%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/St._Mary_Church,_Urmia" title="St. Mary Church, Urmia">Saint Mary Church</a>; an ancient Assyrian church located in the city of <a href="/wiki/Urmia" title="Urmia">Urmia</a>, Iran.</div></div></div>
<p>Its main spoken language is <a href="/wiki/Syriac_language" title="Syriac language">Syriac</a>, a dialect of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Aramaic" title="Eastern Aramaic">Eastern Aramaic</a>, and the majority of its adherents are ethnic <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_people" title="Assyrian people">Assyrians</a>, mostly living in <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chaldean_Syrian_Church" title="Chaldean Syrian Church">Chaldean Syrian Church</a>), and in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assyrian_diaspora" title="Assyrian diaspora">Assyrian diaspora</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[407]</a></sup> It is officially headquartered in the city of <a href="/wiki/Erbil" title="Erbil">Erbil</a> in northern <a href="/wiki/Iraqi_Kurdistan" title="Iraqi Kurdistan">Iraqi Kurdistan</a>, and its original area also spreads into south-eastern Turkey and north-western Iran, corresponding to ancient <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">Assyria</a>. Its hierarchy is composed of <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_bishop" title="Metropolitan bishop">metropolitan bishops</a> and <a href="/wiki/Diocesan_bishop" title="Diocesan bishop">diocesan bishops</a>, while lower clergy consists of <a href="/wiki/Priest" title="Priest">priests</a> and <a href="/wiki/Deacon" title="Deacon">deacons</a>, who serve in dioceses (eparchies) and parishes throughout the Middle East, India, North America, Oceania, and Europe (including the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> and Russia).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[408]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Church_of_the_East" title="Ancient Church of the East">Ancient Church of the East</a> distinguished itself from the <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_Church_of_the_East" title="Assyrian Church of the East">Assyrian Church of the East</a> in 1964. It is one of the <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_people" title="Assyrian people">Assyrian</a> churches that claim continuity with the historical Church of the East, one of the oldest Christian churches in Mesopotamia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[409]</a></sup> It is officially headquartered in the city of <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>, Iraq.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blackwell1_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-blackwell1-416">[410]</a></sup> The majority of its adherents are ethnic <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_people" title="Assyrian people">Assyrians</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blackwell1_416-1"><a href="#cite_note-blackwell1-416">[410]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Protestantism">Protestantism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Proto-Protestantism" title="Proto-Protestantism">Proto-Protestantism</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Protestant_ecclesiology" title="Protestant ecclesiology">Protestant ecclesiology</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile nowraplinks plainlist" style="color: black;"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-pretitle">Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Protestantism" title="Category:Protestantism">a series</a> on</td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-title-with-pretitle" style="padding:0.2em; background:#efefef;"><a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Golden_Christian_Cross.svg" title="Latin version of the Christian cross which is used by virtually all Protestant denominations"><img alt="Latin version of the Christian cross which is used by virtually all Protestant denominations" data-file-height="1052" data-file-width="744" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Golden_Christian_Cross.svg/85px-Golden_Christian_Cross.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Golden_Christian_Cross.svg/128px-Golden_Christian_Cross.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Golden_Christian_Cross.svg/170px-Golden_Christian_Cross.svg.png 2x" width="85"/></a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-above">

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:#efefef;">Other developments</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Arminianism" title="Arminianism">Arminianism</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Christian_fundamentalism" title="Christian fundamentalism">Christian fundamentalism</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Crypto-Protestantism" title="Crypto-Protestantism">Crypto-Protestantism</a></li>

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:#efefef;">Related movements</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/House_church" title="House church">House churches</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nondenominational_Christianity" title="Nondenominational Christianity">Nondenominational Christianity</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Spiritual_Christianity" title="Spiritual Christianity">Spiritual Christianity</a></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below" style="padding-top:0.15em;">
<a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P_christianity.svg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/16px-P_christianity.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/24px-P_christianity.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/32px-P_christianity.svg.png 2x" width="16"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Christianity" title="Portal:Christianity">Christianity portal</a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Protestantism" title="Template:Protestantism"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Protestantism" title="Template talk:Protestantism"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Protestantism&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>In 1521, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edict_of_Worms" title="Edict of Worms">Edict of Worms</a> condemned <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther" title="Martin Luther">Martin Luther</a> and officially banned citizens of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a> from defending or propagating his ideas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ENC3_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-ENC3-417">[411]</a></sup> This split within the Roman Catholic church is now called the <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Reformation</a>. Prominent Reformers included Martin Luther, <a href="/wiki/Huldrych_Zwingli" title="Huldrych Zwingli">Huldrych Zwingli</a>, and <a href="/wiki/John_Calvin" title="John Calvin">John Calvin</a>. The 1529 <a href="/wiki/Protestation_at_Speyer" title="Protestation at Speyer">Protestation at Speyer</a> against being excommunicated gave this party the name <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a>. Luther's primary theological heirs are known as <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">Lutherans</a>. Zwingli and Calvin's heirs are far broader denominationally, and are referred to as the <a href="/wiki/Calvinism" title="Calvinism">Reformed tradition</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McManners251_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-McManners251-418">[412]</a></sup> Protestants have developed <a href="/wiki/Protestant_culture" title="Protestant culture">their own culture</a>, with major contributions in education, the <a href="/wiki/Merton_thesis" title="Merton thesis">humanities and sciences</a>, the political and social order, the <a href="/wiki/Protestant_work_ethic" title="Protestant work ethic">economy</a> and the arts, and many other fields.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Karl-Heussi_1956_pp._317–319_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-Karl-Heussi_1956_pp._317–319-419">[413]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[414]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Anglicanism" title="Anglicanism">Anglican</a> churches descended from the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_England" title="Church of England">Church of England</a> and organized in the <a href="/wiki/Anglican_Communion" title="Anglican Communion">Anglican Communion</a>. Some, but not all Anglicans consider themselves both Protestant and Catholic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[415]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[416]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the Anglican, Lutheran, and the Reformed branches of Protestantism originated for the most part in cooperation with the government, these movements are termed the  "<a href="/wiki/Magisterial_Reformation" title="Magisterial Reformation">Magisterial Reformation</a>". On the other hand, groups such as the <a href="/wiki/Anabaptism" title="Anabaptism">Anabaptists</a>, who often do not consider themselves to be Protestant, originated in the <a href="/wiki/Radical_Reformation" title="Radical Reformation">Radical Reformation</a>, which though sometimes protected under <i>Acts of Toleration</i>, do not trace their history back to any state church. They are further distinguished by their rejection of infant baptism; they believe in baptism only of adult believers—<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Credobaptism" title="Credobaptism">credobaptism</a> (Anabaptists include the <a href="/wiki/Amish" title="Amish">Amish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_Christian_Church" title="Apostolic Christian Church">Apostolic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mennonites" title="Mennonites">Mennonites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hutterites" title="Hutterites">Hutterites</a>, <a href="/wiki/River_Brethren" title="River Brethren">River Brethren</a> and <a href="/wiki/Schwarzenau_Brethren" title="Schwarzenau Brethren">Schwarzenau Brethren</a>/<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_Baptist" title="German Baptist">German Baptist</a> groups.)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gertz2004_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gertz2004-423">[417]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BenedettoDuke2008_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-BenedettoDuke2008-424">[418]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Littell2000_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-Littell2000-425">[419]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[420]</a></sup>
</p><p>The term <i>Protestant</i> also refers to any churches which formed later, with either the Magisterial or Radical traditions. In the 18th century, for example, <a href="/wiki/Methodism" title="Methodism">Methodism</a> grew out of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglican" title="Anglican">Anglican</a> minister <a href="/wiki/John_Wesley" title="John Wesley">John Wesley</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evangelical_Revival" title="Evangelical Revival">evangelical revival movement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Methodist_Central_Hall_Westminster—Methodism_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-Methodist_Central_Hall_Westminster—Methodism-427">[421]</a></sup> Several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pentecostal" title="Pentecostal">Pentecostal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nondenominational_Christianity" title="Nondenominational Christianity">non-denominational churches</a>, which emphasize the cleansing power of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Spirit" title="Holy Spirit">Holy Spirit</a>, in turn grew out of Methodism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FYW—Pentecostalism_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-FYW—Pentecostalism-428">[422]</a></sup> Because Methodists, Pentecostals and other evangelicals stress "accepting Jesus as your personal Lord and Savior",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CUMC_Accepting_Christ_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-CUMC_Accepting_Christ-429">[423]</a></sup> which comes from Wesley's emphasis of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Born_again_(Christianity)" title="Born again (Christianity)">New Birth</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UMC_GBGM-The_New_Birth_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-UMC_GBGM-The_New_Birth-430">[424]</a></sup> they often refer to themselves as being <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Born_again_Christianity" title="Born again Christianity">born-again</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UMC_GBGM-Grace_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-UMC_GBGM-Grace-431">[425]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Warren_Wilson_College—Total_Experience_of_the_Spirit_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-Warren_Wilson_College—Total_Experience_of_the_Spirit-432">[426]</a></sup>
</p><p>Protestantism is the second largest major group of Christians after Catholicism by number of followers, although the Eastern Orthodox Church is larger than any single Protestant denomination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Adherents_390-1"><a href="#cite_note-Adherents-390">[384]</a></sup> Estimates vary, mainly over the question of which denominations to classify as Protestant. Yet, the total number of Protestant Christians is  generally estimated between 800 million and 1 billion, corresponding to nearly 40% of the world's Christians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CSGC2019_15-2"><a href="#cite_note-CSGC2019-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pewforum1_290-1"><a href="#cite_note-pewforum1-290">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[427]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[428]</a></sup> The majority of Protestants are members of just a handful of denominational families, i.e. <a href="/wiki/Adventism" title="Adventism">Adventists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anglicanism" title="Anglicanism">Anglicans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baptists" title="Baptists">Baptists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Calvinism" title="Calvinism">Reformed (Calvinists)</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[429]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">Lutherans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Methodism" title="Methodism">Methodists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moravian_Church" title="Moravian Church">Moravians</a>/<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hussite_Church" title="Hussite Church">Hussites</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pentecostalism" title="Pentecostalism">Pentecostals</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pewforum1_290-2"><a href="#cite_note-pewforum1-290">[285]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nondenominational_Christianity" title="Nondenominational Christianity">Nondenominational</a>, <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">evangelical</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charismatic_Movement" title="Charismatic Movement">charismatic</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neo-charismatic_churches" title="Neo-charismatic churches">neo-charismatic</a>, independent, and other churches are on the rise, and constitute a significant part of Protestant Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[430]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some groups of individuals who hold basic Protestant tenets identify themselves simply as "Christians" or "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Born-again" title="Born-again">born-again</a> Christians". They typically distance themselves from the <a href="/wiki/Confessionalism_(religion)" title="Confessionalism (religion)">confessionalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Creed" title="Creed">creedalism</a> of other Christian communities<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-437">[431]</a></sup> by calling themselves "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Christianity" title="Non-denominational Christianity">non-denominational</a>" or "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evangelical" title="Evangelical">evangelical</a>". Often founded by individual pastors, they have little affiliation with historic denominations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pew_Forum_on_Religion_&amp;_Public_Life_/_U.S._Religious_Landscape_Survey_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pew_Forum_on_Religion_&amp;_Public_Life_/_U.S._Religious_Landscape_Survey-438">[432]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-nolines">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 225px"><div style="width: 225px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 220px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Interdenominational_movements_%26_other_Protestant_developments.svg" title="Links between interdenominational movements and other developments within Protestantism"><img alt="Links between interdenominational movements and other developments within Protestantism" data-file-height="512" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Interdenominational_movements_%26_other_Protestant_developments.svg/188px-Interdenominational_movements_%26_other_Protestant_developments.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Interdenominational_movements_%26_other_Protestant_developments.svg/282px-Interdenominational_movements_%26_other_Protestant_developments.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Interdenominational_movements_%26_other_Protestant_developments.svg/375px-Interdenominational_movements_%26_other_Protestant_developments.svg.png 2x" width="188"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Links between interdenominational movements and other developments within Protestantism
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 225px"><div style="width: 225px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 220px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Protestant_branches.svg" title="Historical chart of the main Protestant branches"><img alt="Historical chart of the main Protestant branches" data-file-height="512" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Protestant_branches.svg/188px-Protestant_branches.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Protestant_branches.svg/282px-Protestant_branches.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Protestant_branches.svg/375px-Protestant_branches.svg.png 2x" width="188"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Restorationism">Restorationism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Restorationism" title="Restorationism">Restorationism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Priesthood03080u.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3010" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="271" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Priesthood03080u.jpg/180px-Priesthood03080u.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Priesthood03080u.jpg/270px-Priesthood03080u.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Priesthood03080u.jpg/360px-Priesthood03080u.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Priesthood03080u.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A 19th-century drawing of <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Smith" title="Joseph Smith">Joseph Smith</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Cowdery" title="Oliver Cowdery">Oliver Cowdery</a> receiving the <a href="/wiki/Aaronic_priesthood_(Latter_Day_Saints)" title="Aaronic priesthood (Latter Day Saints)">Aaronic priesthood</a> from <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a>. <a href="/wiki/Latter_Day_Saint_movement" title="Latter Day Saint movement">Latter Day Saints</a> believe that the <a href="/wiki/Priest#Christianity" title="Priest">Priesthood</a> ceased to exist after the death of the apostles and therefore needed to be <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Restoration_(Latter_Day_Saints)" title="Restoration (Latter Day Saints)">restored</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Second_Great_Awakening" title="Second Great Awakening">Second Great Awakening</a>, a period of religious revival that occurred in the United States during the early 1800s, saw the development of a number of unrelated churches. They generally saw themselves as <a href="/wiki/Restorationism" title="Restorationism">restoring</a> the original church of Jesus Christ rather than reforming one of the existing churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[433]</a></sup> A common belief held by Restorationists was that the other divisions of Christianity had introduced doctrinal defects into Christianity, which was known as the <a href="/wiki/Great_Apostasy" title="Great Apostasy">Great Apostasy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Religious_Tolerance—Restorationism_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-Religious_Tolerance—Restorationism-440">[434]</a></sup> In Asia, <a href="/wiki/Iglesia_ni_Cristo" title="Iglesia ni Cristo">Iglesia ni Cristo</a> is a known restorationist religion that was established during the early 1900s.
</p><p>Some of the churches originating during this period are historically connected to early 19th-century camp meetings in the Midwest and upstate New York. One of the largest churches produced from the movement is <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[435]</a></sup> American <a href="/wiki/Millennialism" title="Millennialism">Millennialism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Adventism" title="Adventism">Adventism</a>, which arose from Evangelical Protestantism, influenced the <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a> movement and, as a reaction specifically to <a href="/wiki/William_Miller_(preacher)" title="William Miller (preacher)">William Miller</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventists</a>. Others, including the <a href="/wiki/Christian_Church_(Disciples_of_Christ)" title="Christian Church (Disciples of Christ)">Christian Church (Disciples of Christ)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Evangelical_Christian_Church_in_Canada" title="Evangelical Christian Church in Canada">Evangelical Christian Church in Canada</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[436]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[437]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Churches_of_Christ" title="Churches of Christ">Churches of Christ</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Christian_churches_and_churches_of_Christ" title="Christian churches and churches of Christ">Christian churches and churches of Christ</a>, have their roots in the contemporaneous Stone-Campbell <a href="/wiki/Restoration_Movement" title="Restoration Movement">Restoration Movement</a>, which was centered in Kentucky and Tennessee. Other groups originating in this time period include the <a href="/wiki/Christadelphians" title="Christadelphians">Christadelphians</a> and the previously mentioned <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latter_Day_Saints_movement" title="Latter Day Saints movement">Latter Day Saints movement</a>. While the churches originating in the Second Great Awakening have some superficial similarities, their doctrine and practices vary significantly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[438]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other">Other</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Biserica_unitarian%C4%83_20180321_115158_05.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Biserica_unitarian%C4%83_20180321_115158_05.jpg/180px-Biserica_unitarian%C4%83_20180321_115158_05.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Biserica_unitarian%C4%83_20180321_115158_05.jpg/270px-Biserica_unitarian%C4%83_20180321_115158_05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Biserica_unitarian%C4%83_20180321_115158_05.jpg/360px-Biserica_unitarian%C4%83_20180321_115158_05.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Biserica_unitarian%C4%83_20180321_115158_05.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Unitarian_Church_of_Transylvania" title="Unitarian Church of Transylvania">Unitarian Church of Transylvania</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cluj-Napoca" title="Cluj-Napoca">Cluj-Napoca</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Within Italy, Poland, Lithuania, Transylvania, Hungary, Romania, and the United Kingdom, <a href="/wiki/Unitarianism" title="Unitarianism">Unitarian Churches</a> emerged from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reformed_tradition" title="Reformed tradition">Reformed</a> tradition in the 16th century;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[439]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Unitarian_Church_of_Transylvania" title="Unitarian Church of Transylvania">Unitarian Church of Transylvania</a> is an example of such a denomination that arose in this era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[440]</a></sup> They adopted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anabaptist" title="Anabaptist">Anabaptist</a> doctrine of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Credobaptism" title="Credobaptism">credobaptism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bochenski2013_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bochenski2013-447">[441]</a></sup>
</p><p>Various smaller <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Independent_Catholic" title="Independent Catholic">Independent Catholic</a> communities, such as the <a href="/wiki/Old_Catholic_Church" title="Old Catholic Church">Old Catholic Church</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[442]</a></sup> include the word <i><a href="/wiki/Catholic_(term)" title="Catholic (term)">Catholic</a></i> in their title, and arguably have more or less liturgical practices in common with the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a>, but are no longer in <a href="/wiki/Full_communion" title="Full communion">full communion</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Plummer_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-Plummer-449">[443]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spiritual_Christians" title="Spiritual Christians">Spiritual Christians</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Doukhobors" title="Doukhobors">Doukhobors</a> and <a href="/wiki/Molokan" title="Molokan">Molokans</a>, broke from the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a> and maintain close association with Mennonites and <a href="/wiki/Quakers" title="Quakers">Quakers</a> due to similar religious practices; all of these groups are furthermore collectively considered to be <a href="/wiki/Peace_churches" title="Peace churches">peace churches</a> due to their belief in <a href="/wiki/Christian_pacifism" title="Christian pacifism">pacifism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fahlbusch2008_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fahlbusch2008-450">[444]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FlemingRowan2004_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-FlemingRowan2004-451">[445]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Messianic_Judaism" title="Messianic Judaism">Messianic Judaism</a> (or the Messianic Movement) is the name of a Christian movement comprising a number of streams, whose members may consider themselves Jewish. The movement originated in the 1960s and 1970s, and it blends elements of religious Jewish practice with evangelical Christianity. Messianic Judaism affirms Christian creeds such as the messiahship and divinity of "Yeshua" (the Hebrew name of Jesus) and the Triune Nature of God, while also adhering to some Jewish dietary laws and customs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ariel2006p208_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ariel2006p208-452">[446]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Esoteric_Christianity" title="Esoteric Christianity">Esoteric Christians</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/The_Christian_Community" title="The Christian Community">The Christian Community</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[447]</a></sup> regard Christianity as a <a href="/wiki/Western_esotericism" title="Western esotericism">mystery religion</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[448]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Besant_2001_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-Besant_2001-455">[449]</a></sup> and profess the existence and possession of certain <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Esotericism" title="Esotericism">esoteric</a> doctrines or practices,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[450]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[451]</a></sup> hidden from the public and accessible only to a narrow circle of "enlightened", "initiated", or highly educated people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[452]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[453]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nondenominational_Christianity" title="Nondenominational Christianity">Nondenominational Christianity</a> or non-denominational Christianity consists of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Simple_church" title="Simple church">churches</a> which typically distance themselves from the <a href="/wiki/Confessionalism_(religion)" title="Confessionalism (religion)">confessionalism</a> or <a href="/wiki/Creed" title="Creed">creedalism</a> of other Christian communities<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_437-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-437">[431]</a></sup> by not formally aligning with a specific <a href="/wiki/Christian_denomination" title="Christian denomination">Christian denomination</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hughes1997_460-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hughes1997-460">[454]</a></sup> Nondenominational Christianity first arose in the 18th century through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stone-Campbell_Restoration_Movement" title="Stone-Campbell Restoration Movement">Stone-Campbell Restoration Movement</a>, with followers organizing themselves simply as "<a href="/wiki/Christians_(Stone_Movement)" title="Christians (Stone Movement)">Christians</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Disciples_of_Christ_(Campbell_Movement)" title="Disciples of Christ (Campbell Movement)">Disciples of Christ</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[note 7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hughes1997_460-2"><a href="#cite_note-Hughes1997-460">[454]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barnett2020_461-1"><a href="#cite_note-Barnett2020-461">[455]</a></sup> but many typically adhere to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evangelical_Christianity" title="Evangelical Christianity">evangelical Christianity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nash2020_463-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nash2020-463">[456]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HughesRoberts2001_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-HughesRoberts2001-464">[457]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cherok2011_465-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cherok2011-465">[458]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Influence_on_Western_culture">Influence on Western culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Christian_culture" title="Christian culture">Christian culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Role_of_Christianity_in_civilization" title="Role of Christianity in civilization">Role of Christianity in civilization</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Protestant_culture" title="Protestant culture">Protestant culture</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_influences_in_Islam" title="Christian influences in Islam">Christian influences in Islam</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader"><a href="/wiki/Christian_culture" title="Christian culture">Christian culture</a></div></div><div class="trow"><div style="width:104px;max-width:104px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:136px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NotreDameDeParis.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3806"
