//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/NotreDameDeParis.jpg/204px-NotreDameDeParis.jpg 2x" width="102"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:89px;max-width:89px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:131px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Christ_the_Redeemer_-_Cristo_Redentor.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3744" data-file-width="2497" decoding="async" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Christ_the_Redeemer_-_Cristo_Redentor.jpg/87px-Christ_the_Redeemer_-_Cristo_Redentor.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Christ_the_Redeemer_-_Cristo_Redentor.jpg/131px-Christ_the_Redeemer_-_Cristo_Redentor.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Christ_the_Redeemer_-_Cristo_Redentor.jpg/174px-Christ_the_Redeemer_-_Cristo_Redentor.jpg 2x" width="87"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:199px;max-width:199px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:131px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Svatba_(2).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Svatba_%282%29.jpg/197px-Svatba_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Svatba_%282%29.jpg/296px-Svatba_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Svatba_%282%29.jpg/394px-Svatba_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="197"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption"><i>Clockwise from top</i>: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sistine_chapel_ceiling" title="Sistine chapel ceiling">Sistine chapel ceiling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Notre-Dame_de_Paris" title="Notre-Dame de Paris">Notre-Dame</a> cathedral in Paris, Eastern Orthodox <a href="/wiki/Wedding" title="Wedding">wedding</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Christ_the_Redeemer_(statue)" title="Christ the Redeemer (statue)">Christ the Redeemer</a></i> statue, <a href="/wiki/Nativity_scene" title="Nativity scene">Nativity scene</a></div></div></div></div>
<p>The history of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_world" title="Christian world">Christian world</a> spans about 1,700 years and includes a variety of socio-political developments, as well as advances in the <a href="/wiki/Christian_art" title="Christian art">arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_cathedrals_and_great_churches" title="Architecture of cathedrals and great churches">architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_literature" title="Christian literature">literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianity_and_science" title="Christianity and science">science</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_philosophy" title="Christian philosophy">philosophy</a>, and technology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crisis_in_Western_Education_466-0"><a href="#cite_note-Crisis_in_Western_Education-466">[459]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-E._McGrath_467-0"><a href="#cite_note-E._McGrath-467">[460]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-National_Review_Book_Service_468-0"><a href="#cite_note-National_Review_Book_Service-468">[461]</a></sup> Since the spread of Christianity from the <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">Levant</a> to <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a> during the early <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>, Christendom has been divided in the pre-existing <a href="/wiki/Greek_East_and_Latin_West" title="Greek East and Latin West">Greek East and Latin West</a>. Consequently, different versions of the Christian cultures arose with their own rites and practices, centred around the cities of <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a> (<a href="/wiki/Western_Christianity" title="Western Christianity">Western Christianity</a>), whose community was called Western or Latin Christendom,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[462]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> (<a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern Christianity</a>), <a href="/wiki/Antioch" title="Antioch">Antioch</a> (<a href="/wiki/Syriac_Christianity" title="Syriac Christianity">Syriac Christianity</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coptic_Christianity" title="Coptic Christianity">Coptic Christianity</a>), whose communities were called Eastern Christendom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[463]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[464]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[465]</a></sup> From the 11th to 13th centuries, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_Christendom" title="Latin Christendom">Latin Christendom</a> rose to the central role of the <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">Western world</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western culture</a>, throughout most of its history, has been nearly equivalent to <a href="/wiki/Christian_culture" title="Christian culture">Christian culture</a>, and a large portion of the population of the Western Hemisphere can be described as practicing or nominal Christians. The notion of "Europe" and the "Western World" has been intimately connected with the concept of "Christianity and <a href="/wiki/Christendom" title="Christendom">Christendom</a>". Many historians even attribute Christianity for being the link that created a unified <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_identity" title="European identity">European identity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[466]</a></sup>
</p><p>Though Western culture contained several polytheistic religions during its early years under the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greek</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman empires</a>, as the centralized Roman power waned, the dominance of the Catholic Church was the only consistent force in Western Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1994_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1994-474">[467]</a></sup> Until the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[468]</a></sup> Christian culture guided the course of philosophy, literature, art, music and science.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1994_474-1"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1994-474">[467]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crisis_in_Western_Education_466-1"><a href="#cite_note-Crisis_in_Western_Education-466">[459]</a></sup> Christian disciplines of the respective arts have subsequently developed into <a href="/wiki/Christian_philosophy" title="Christian philosophy">Christian philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_art" title="Christian art">Christian art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_music" title="Christian music">Christian music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_literature" title="Christian literature">Christian literature</a>, and so on.
</p><p>Christianity has had a significant impact on education, as the church created the bases of the Western system of education,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[469]</a></sup> and was the sponsor of <a href="/wiki/Medieval_university" title="Medieval university">founding universities</a> in the Western world, as the university is generally regarded as an institution that has its origin in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Christianity" title="History of Christianity">Medieval Christian</a> setting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-verger1999_233-1"><a href="#cite_note-verger1999-233">[228]</a></sup> Historically, Christianity has often been a patron of science and medicine; many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Catholic_cleric-scientists" title="List of Catholic cleric-scientists">Catholic clergy</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hough_p68_477-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hough_p68-477">[470]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Jesuit_scientists" title="List of Jesuit scientists">Jesuits</a> in particular,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoods2005109_478-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoods2005109-478">[471]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[472]</a></sup> have been active in the sciences throughout history and have made significant contributions to the <a href="/wiki/Christianity_and_science" title="Christianity and science">development of science</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[473]</a></sup> Protestantism also has had an important influence on science. According to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Merton_Thesis" title="Merton Thesis">Merton Thesis</a>, there was a positive correlation between the rise of English <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Puritanism" title="Puritanism">Puritanism</a> and German <a href="/wiki/Pietism" title="Pietism">Pietism</a> on the one hand, and early experimental science on the other.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[474]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[475]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[476]</a></sup> The civilizing influence of Christianity includes social welfare,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[477]</a></sup> founding hospitals,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[478]</a></sup> economics (as the <a href="/wiki/Protestant_work_ethic" title="Protestant work ethic">Protestant work ethic</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[479]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[480]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-J._Hillerbrand_488-0"><a href="#cite_note-J._Hillerbrand-488">[481]</a></sup> architecture,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BF_489-0"><a href="#cite_note-BF-489">[482]</a></sup> politics,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[483]</a></sup> literature,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[484]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hygiene_in_Christianity" title="Hygiene in Christianity">personal hygiene</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ablution_in_Christianity" title="Ablution in Christianity">ablution</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[485]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[486]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Warsh_494-0"><a href="#cite_note-Warsh-494">[487]</a></sup> and family life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[488]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[489]</a></sup> Historically, <i><a href="/wiki/Extended_family" title="Extended family">extended families</a></i> were the basic family unit in the <a href="/wiki/Christian_culture" title="Christian culture">Christian culture</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_countries" title="Catholic countries">countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[490]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/List_of_Christian_scientists_and_scholars_of_the_medieval_Islamic_world" title="List of Christian scientists and scholars of the medieval Islamic world">Eastern Christian scientists and scholars of the medieval Islamic world</a> (particularly <a href="/wiki/Syriac_Orthodox_Church" title="Syriac Orthodox Church">Jacobite</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nestorianism" title="Nestorianism">Nestorian</a> <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a>) contributed to the Arab <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">Islamic civilization</a> during the reign of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Umayyad" title="Umayyad">Umayyad</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abbasids" title="Abbasids">Abbasid</a>, by translating works of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greek_philosophers" title="Greek philosophers">Greek philosophers</a> to <a href="/wiki/Syriac_language" title="Syriac language">Syriac</a> and afterwards, to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[491]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[492]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[493]</a></sup> They also excelled in philosophy, science, theology, and medicine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[494]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[495]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[496]</a></sup> Scholars and intellectuals agree <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christians_in_the_Middle_East" title="Christians in the Middle East">Christians in the Middle East</a> have made significant contributions to Arab and Islamic civilization since the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, and they have had a significant impact contributing the culture of the <a href="/wiki/Mashriq" title="Mashriq">Mashriq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Radai20082_504-0"><a href="#cite_note-Radai20082-504">[497]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HuffPost_505-0"><a href="#cite_note-HuffPost-505">[498]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Lists_of_Christians" title="Lists of Christians">Christians</a> have made a myriad of contributions to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Progress_(history)" title="Progress (history)">human progress</a> in a broad and diverse range of fields, including philosophy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A._Spinello_506-0"><a href="#cite_note-A._Spinello-506">[499]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Christians_in_science_and_technology" title="List of Christians in science and technology">science and technology</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gilley_507-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gilley-507">[500]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Steane_508-0"><a href="#cite_note-Steane-508">[501]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[502]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[503]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_health_care" title="Catholic Church and health care">medicine</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-S._Kroger_511-0"><a href="#cite_note-S._Kroger-511">[504]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Catholic_Church_artists" title="List of Catholic Church artists">fine arts and architecture</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[505]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christianity_and_politics" title="Christianity and politics">politics</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Catholic_authors" title="List of Catholic authors">literatures</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_Music" title="Christian Music">music</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hall100_513-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hall100-513">[506]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Business" title="Business">business</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[507]</a></sup> According to <i>100 Years of Nobel Prizes</i> a review of the Nobel Prizes award between 1901 and 2000 reveals that (65.4%) of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_Prizes" title="Nobel Prizes">Nobel Prizes</a> Laureates, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Christian_Nobel_laureates" title="List of Christian Nobel laureates">have identified Christianity</a> in its various forms as their religious preference.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nobel_Prize_515-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nobel_Prize-515">[508]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cultural_Christian" title="Cultural Christian">Cultural Christians</a> are secular people with a Christian heritage who may not believe in the religious claims of Christianity, but who retain an affinity for the popular culture, art, <a href="/wiki/Christian_music" title="Christian music">music</a>, and so on related to the religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[509]</a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/wiki/Postchristianity" title="Postchristianity">Postchristianity</a></i> is the term for the decline of Christianity, particularly in <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Europe" title="Christianity in Europe">Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Canada" title="Religion in Canada">Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Australia" title="Christianity in Australia">Australia</a>, and to a minor degree the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Cone" title="Southern Cone">Southern Cone</a>, in the 20th and 21st centuries, considered in terms of <a href="/wiki/Postmodernism" title="Postmodernism">postmodernism</a>. It refers to the loss of Christianity's monopoly on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Values" title="Values">values</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_view" title="World view">world view</a> in historically Christian societies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[510]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Ecumenism">Ecumenism</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ecumenism" title="Ecumenism">Ecumenism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:231px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2bishopsReformation.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3251" data-file-width="4403" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/2bishopsReformation.jpg/229px-2bishopsReformation.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/2bishopsReformation.jpg/344px-2bishopsReformation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/2bishopsReformation.jpg/458px-2bishopsReformation.jpg 2x" width="229"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2bishopsReformation.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bishop <a href="/wiki/John_M._Quinn" title="John M. Quinn">John M. Quinn</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Diocese_of_Winona" title="Roman Catholic Diocese of Winona">Roman Catholic Diocese of Winona</a> and Bishop Steven Delzer of <a href="/wiki/List_of_ELCA_synods" title="List of ELCA synods">Evangelical Lutheran Southeastern Minnesota Synod</a> leading a <a href="/wiki/Reformation_Day" title="Reformation Day">Reformation Day</a> service (2017)</div></div></div>
<p>Christian groups and denominations have long expressed ideals of being reconciled, and in the 20th century, Christian <a href="/wiki/Ecumenism" title="Ecumenism">ecumenism</a> advanced in two ways.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McManners581_518-0"><a href="#cite_note-McManners581-518">[511]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pizzey2019_519-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pizzey2019-519">[512]</a></sup> One way was greater cooperation between groups, such as the <a href="/wiki/World_Evangelical_Alliance" title="World Evangelical Alliance">World Evangelical Alliance</a> founded in 1846 in London or the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edinburgh_Missionary_Conference" title="Edinburgh Missionary Conference">Edinburgh Missionary Conference</a> of Protestants in 1910, the Justice, Peace and Creation Commission of the <a href="/wiki/World_Council_of_Churches" title="World Council of Churches">World Council of Churches</a> founded in 1948 by Protestant and Orthodox churches, and similar national councils like the <a href="/wiki/National_Council_of_Churches_in_Australia" title="National Council of Churches in Australia">National Council of Churches in Australia</a>, which includes Catholics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McManners581_518-1"><a href="#cite_note-McManners581-518">[511]</a></sup>
</p><p>The other way was an institutional union with <a href="/wiki/United_and_uniting_churches" title="United and uniting churches">united churches</a>, a practice that can be traced back to unions between Lutherans and Calvinists in early 19th-century Germany. Congregationalist, Methodist, and Presbyterian churches united in 1925 to form the <a href="/wiki/United_Church_of_Canada" title="United Church of Canada">United Church of Canada</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[513]</a></sup> and in 1977 to form the <a href="/wiki/Uniting_Church_in_Australia" title="Uniting Church in Australia">Uniting Church in Australia</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Church_of_South_India" title="Church of South India">Church of South India</a> was formed in 1947 by the union of Anglican, Baptist, Methodist, Congregationalist, and Presbyterian churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[514]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Christian_Flag" title="Christian Flag">Christian Flag</a> is an ecumenical flag designed in the early 20th century to represent all of Christianity and <a href="/wiki/Christendom" title="Christendom">Christendom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CA2014_522-0"><a href="#cite_note-CA2014-522">[515]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ecumenical, <a href="/wiki/Monasticism" title="Monasticism">monastic</a> <a href="/wiki/Taiz%C3%A9_Community" title="Taizé Community">Taizé Community</a> is notable for being composed of more than one hundred <a href="/wiki/Monk" title="Monk">brothers</a> from Protestant and Catholic traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-taize_523-0"><a href="#cite_note-taize-523">[516]</a></sup> The community emphasizes the reconciliation of all denominations and its main church, located in <a href="/wiki/Taiz%C3%A9,_Sa%C3%B4ne-et-Loire" title="Taizé, Saône-et-Loire">Taizé, Saône-et-Loire</a>, France, is named the "Church of Reconciliation".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-taize_523-1"><a href="#cite_note-taize-523">[516]</a></sup> The community is internationally known, attracting over 100,000 young <a href="/wiki/Christian_pilgrimage" title="Christian pilgrimage">pilgrims</a> annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[517]</a></sup>
</p><p>Steps towards reconciliation on a global level were taken in 1965 by the Catholic and Orthodox churches, mutually revoking the excommunications that marked their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East-West_Schism" title="East-West Schism">Great Schism</a> in 1054;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[518]</a></sup> the Anglican Catholic International Commission (ARCIC) working towards full communion between those churches since 1970;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[519]</a></sup> and some <a href="/wiki/Lutheran_World_Federation" title="Lutheran World Federation">Lutheran</a> and Catholic churches signing the <a href="/wiki/Joint_Declaration_on_the_Doctrine_of_Justification" title="Joint Declaration on the Doctrine of Justification">Joint Declaration on the Doctrine of Justification</a> in 1999 to address conflicts at the root of the Protestant Reformation. In 2006, the <a href="/wiki/World_Methodist_Council" title="World Methodist Council">World Methodist Council</a>, representing all Methodist denominations, adopted the declaration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[520]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Criticism.2C_persecution.2C_and_apologetics"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Criticism,_persecution,_and_apologetics">Criticism, persecution, and apologetics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Christianity" title="Criticism of Christianity">Criticism of Christianity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Christians" title="Persecution of Christians">Persecution of Christians</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Christian_apologetics" title="Christian apologetics">Christian apologetics</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Anti-Christian_sentiment" title="Anti-Christian sentiment">Anti-Christian sentiment</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Criticism">Criticism</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SummaTheologiae.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="625" decoding="async" height="256" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/SummaTheologiae.jpg/200px-SummaTheologiae.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/SummaTheologiae.jpg/300px-SummaTheologiae.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/SummaTheologiae.jpg/400px-SummaTheologiae.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SummaTheologiae.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A copy of the <i><a href="/wiki/Summa_Theologica" title="Summa Theologica">Summa Theologica</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Aquinas" title="Thomas Aquinas">Thomas Aquinas</a></div></div></div>
<p>Criticism of Christianity and Christians goes back to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apostolic_Age" title="Apostolic Age">Apostolic Age</a>, with the New Testament recording friction between the followers of Jesus and the <a href="/wiki/Pharisees" title="Pharisees">Pharisees</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scribes" title="Scribes">scribes</a> (e.g. <a class="external text" href="https://www.biblica.com/bible/?osis=niv:Matthew%2015:1–20" rel="nofollow">Matthew 15:1–20</a> and <a class="external text" href="https://www.biblica.com/bible/?osis=niv:Mark%207:1–23" rel="nofollow">Mark 7:1–23</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528"><a href="#cite_note-528">[521]</a></sup> In the 2nd century, Christianity was criticized by the Jews on various grounds, e.g. that the prophecies of the Hebrew Bible could not have been fulfilled by Jesus, given that he did not have a successful life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529"><a href="#cite_note-529">[522]</a></sup> Additionally, a sacrifice to remove sins in advance, for everyone or as a human being, did not fit to the Jewish sacrifice ritual; furthermore, <a href="/wiki/God_in_Judaism" title="God in Judaism">God</a> is said to judge people on their deeds instead of their beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[523]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[524]</a></sup> One of the first comprehensive attacks on Christianity came from the Greek philosopher <a href="/wiki/Celsus" title="Celsus">Celsus</a>, who wrote <i><a href="/wiki/The_True_Word" title="The True Word">The True Word</a></i>, a polemic criticizing Christians as being unprofitable members of society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[525]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[526]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olson1999_534-0"><a href="#cite_note-Olson1999-534">[527]</a></sup> In response, the church father <a href="/wiki/Origen" title="Origen">Origen</a> published his treatise <i><a href="/wiki/Contra_Celsum" title="Contra Celsum">Contra Celsum</a></i>, or <i>Against Celsus</i>, a seminal work of Christian apologetics, which systematically addressed Celsus's criticisms and helped bring Christianity a level of academic respectability.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535"><a href="#cite_note-535">[528]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olson1999_534-1"><a href="#cite_note-Olson1999-534">[527]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the 3rd century, criticism of Christianity had mounted. Wild rumors about Christians were widely circulated, claiming that they were <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheists</a> and that, as part of their rituals, they devoured human infants and engaged in incestuous orgies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536"><a href="#cite_note-536">[529]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[530]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Neoplatonism" title="Neoplatonism">Neoplatonist</a> philosopher <a href="/wiki/Porphyry_(philosopher)" title="Porphyry (philosopher)">Porphyry</a> wrote the fifteen-volume <i>Adversus Christianos</i> as a comprehensive attack on Christianity, in part building on the teachings of <a href="/wiki/Plotinus" title="Plotinus">Plotinus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538"><a href="#cite_note-538">[531]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[532]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the 12th century, the <a href="/wiki/Mishneh_Torah" title="Mishneh Torah">Mishneh Torah</a> (i.e., <a href="/wiki/Rabbi" title="Rabbi">Rabbi</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moses_Maimonides" title="Moses Maimonides">Moses Maimonides</a>) was criticizing Christianity on the grounds of idol worship, in that Christians attributed divinity to Jesus, who had a physical body.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-540"><a href="#cite_note-540">[533]</a></sup> In the 19th century, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nietzsche" title="Nietzsche">Nietzsche</a> began to write a series of polemics on the "unnatural" teachings of Christianity (e.g. sexual abstinence), and continued his criticism of Christianity to the end of his life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[534]</a></sup> In the 20th century, the philosopher <a href="/wiki/Bertrand_Russell" title="Bertrand Russell">Bertrand Russell</a> expressed his criticism of Christianity in <i><a href="/wiki/Why_I_Am_Not_a_Christian" title="Why I Am Not a Christian">Why I Am Not a Christian</a></i>, formulating his rejection of Christianity in the setting of logical arguments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542"><a href="#cite_note-542">[535]</a></sup>
</p><p>Criticism of Christianity continues to date, e.g. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish">Jewish</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> theologians criticize the doctrine of the <a href="/wiki/Trinity" title="Trinity">Trinity</a> held by most Christians, stating that this doctrine in effect assumes that there are three gods, running against the basic tenet of <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">monotheism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-543"><a href="#cite_note-543">[536]</a></sup> New Testament scholar <a href="/wiki/Robert_M._Price" title="Robert M. Price">Robert M. Price</a> has outlined the possibility that some Bible stories are based partly on myth in <i>The Christ Myth Theory and its problems</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[537]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Persecution">Persecution</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kharput_Christian_refugees_-_C.D.Morris_-_National_Geographic,_Nov._1925.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="334" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Kharput_Christian_refugees_-_C.D.Morris_-_National_Geographic%2C_Nov._1925.jpg/220px-Kharput_Christian_refugees_-_C.D.Morris_-_National_Geographic%2C_Nov._1925.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Kharput_Christian_refugees_-_C.D.Morris_-_National_Geographic%2C_Nov._1925.jpg/330px-Kharput_Christian_refugees_-_C.D.Morris_-_National_Geographic%2C_Nov._1925.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Kharput_Christian_refugees_-_C.D.Morris_-_National_Geographic%2C_Nov._1925.jpg/440px-Kharput_Christian_refugees_-_C.D.Morris_-_National_Geographic%2C_Nov._1925.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kharput_Christian_refugees_-_C.D.Morris_-_National_Geographic,_Nov._1925.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Christians fleeing their homes in the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, circa 1922. Many Christians were persecuted and/or killed during the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide" title="Armenian genocide">Armenian genocide</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">Greek genocide</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assyrian_genocide" title="Assyrian genocide">Assyrian genocide</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545"><a href="#cite_note-545">[538]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Christians are one of the most <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Christians" title="Persecution of Christians">persecuted</a> religious group in the world, especially in the <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_Middle_East" title="Christianity in the Middle East">Middle-East</a>, North Africa and South and East Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-546"><a href="#cite_note-546">[539]</a></sup> In 2017, <a href="/wiki/Open_Doors" title="Open Doors">Open Doors</a> estimated approximately 260 million Christians are subjected annually to "high, very high, or extreme persecution"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Weber_2017_CT_547-0"><a href="#cite_note-Weber_2017_CT-547">[540]</a></sup> with North Korea considered the most hazardous nation for Christians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enos_2017_NK_548-0"><a href="#cite_note-Enos_2017_NK-548">[541]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549"><a href="#cite_note-549">[542]</a></sup> In 2019, a report<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mounstephen_2019_FCO_interim_rep_550-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mounstephen_2019_FCO_interim_rep-550">[543]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mounstephen_2019_FCO_final_rep_551-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mounstephen_2019_FCO_final_rep-551">[544]</a></sup> commissioned by the United Kingdom's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Foreign_and_Commonwealth_Affairs" title="Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs">Secretary of State</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_and_Commonwealth_Office" title="Foreign and Commonwealth Office">Foreign and Commonwealth Office</a> (FCO) to investigate global persecution of Christians found persecution has increased, and is highest in the Middle East, North Africa, India, China, North Korea, and Latin America, among others, and that it is global and not limited to Islamic states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kay_2019_NP_552-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kay_2019_NP-552">[545]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mounstephen_2019_FCO_final_rep_551-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mounstephen_2019_FCO_final_rep-551">[544]</a></sup> This investigation found that approximately 80% of persecuted believers worldwide are Christians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wintour_2019_Guardian_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wintour_2019_Guardian-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Apologetics">Apologetics</span></h3>
<p>Christian apologetics aims to present a <a href="/wiki/Reason" title="Reason">rational</a> basis for Christianity. The word "apologetic" (Greek: ἀπολογητικός <i>apologētikos</i>) comes from the Greek verb ἀπολογέομαι <i>apologeomai</i>, meaning "(I) speak in defense of".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553"><a href="#cite_note-553">[546]</a></sup> Christian apologetics has taken many forms over the centuries, starting with Paul the Apostle. The philosopher <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Aquinas" title="Thomas Aquinas">Thomas Aquinas</a> presented five arguments for God's existence in the <i><a href="/wiki/Summa_Theologica" title="Summa Theologica">Summa Theologica</a></i>, while his <i><a href="/wiki/Summa_contra_Gentiles" title="Summa contra Gentiles">Summa contra Gentiles</a></i> was a major apologetic work.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554"><a href="#cite_note-554">[547]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555"><a href="#cite_note-555">[548]</a></sup> Another famous apologist, <a href="/wiki/G._K._Chesterton" title="G. K. Chesterton">G. K. Chesterton</a>, wrote in the early twentieth century about the benefits of religion and, specifically, Christianity. Famous for his use of paradox, Chesterton explained that while Christianity had the most mysteries, it was the most practical religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[549]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557"><a href="#cite_note-557">[550]</a></sup> He pointed to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Role_of_the_Christian_Church_in_civilization" title="Role of the Christian Church in civilization">advance of Christian civilizations</a> as proof of its practicality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chesterton.org_558-0"><a href="#cite_note-chesterton.org-558">[551]</a></sup> The physicist and priest <a href="/wiki/John_Polkinghorne" title="John Polkinghorne">John Polkinghorne</a>, in his <i><a href="/wiki/Questions_of_Truth" title="Questions of Truth">Questions of Truth</a></i>, discusses the subject of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Religion_and_science" title="Religion and science">religion and science</a>, a topic that other Christian apologists such as <a href="/wiki/Ravi_Zacharias" title="Ravi Zacharias">Ravi Zacharias</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Lennox" title="John Lennox">John Lennox</a>, and <a href="/wiki/William_Lane_Craig" title="William Lane Craig">William Lane Craig</a> have engaged, with the latter two men opining that the <a href="/wiki/Religious_interpretations_of_the_Big_Bang_theory" title="Religious interpretations of the Big Bang theory">inflationary Big Bang model</a> is evidence for the <a href="/wiki/Existence_of_God" title="Existence of God">existence of God</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Howson2011_559-0"><a href="#cite_note-Howson2011-559">[552]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Creationist_apologetics" title="Creationist apologetics">Creationist apologetics</a> is apologetics that aims to defend <a href="/wiki/Creationism" title="Creationism">creationism</a>.
</p>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1093669538">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portalborder{border:solid #aaa 1px}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:175px;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalborder>ul{padding:0.1em;background:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style><div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint plainlist portalbox portalborder tright" role="navigation">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width reflist-columns-2">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">It appears in the Acts of the Apostles, <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(King_James)/Acts#9:2" title="s:Bible (King James)/Acts">Acts 9:2</a>, <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(King_James)/Acts#19:9" title="s:Bible (King James)/Acts">Acts 19:9</a> and <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(King_James)/Acts#19:23" title="s:Bible (King James)/Acts">Acts 19:23</a>. Some <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_translations_of_the_bible" title="English translations of the bible">English translations of the New Testament</a> capitalize 'the Way' (e.g. the <a href="/wiki/New_King_James_Version" title="New King James Version">New King James Version</a> and the <a href="/wiki/English_Standard_Version" title="English Standard Version">English Standard Version</a>), indicating that this was how 'the new religion seemed then to be designated'<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> whereas others treat the phrase as indicative—'the way',<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> 'that way'<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> or 'the way of the Lord'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Syriac_language" title="Syriac language">Syriac</a> version reads, "the way of God" and the <a href="/wiki/Vulgate" title="Vulgate">Vulgate Latin</a> version, "the way of the Lord".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Trias-Trinitas-87"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Trias-Trinitas_87-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Trias-Trinitas_87-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">The Latin equivalent, from which English <i>trinity</i> is derived,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[83]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (August 2020)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> is <i>trinitas</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Trinitas_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-Trinitas-85">[84]</a></sup> though Latin also borrowed Greek <i>trias</i> verbatim.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[85]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-109">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Frequently a distinction is made between "liturgical" and "non-liturgical" churches based on how elaborate or antiquated the worship; in this usage, churches whose services are unscripted or improvised are described as "non-liturgical".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[106]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-111"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-111">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Often these are arranged on an <a href="/wiki/Annual_cycle" title="Annual cycle">annual cycle</a>, using a book called a <a href="/wiki/Lectionary" title="Lectionary">lectionary</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-134"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-134">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>Iesous Christos Theou <b>H</b>yios Soter</i> may be a more complete transliteration; in <a href="/wiki/Koine_Greek_phonology#Loss_of_aspiration" title="Koine Greek phonology">Koine Greek</a>, the daseia or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spiritus_asper" title="Spiritus asper">spiritus asper</a> had largely ceased being pronounced and was not—commonly—marked in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Majuscule" title="Majuscule">majuscule</a> script of the time.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-293"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-293">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A flexible term, defined as all forms of Protestantism with the notable exception of the historical denominations deriving directly from the Protestant Reformation.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-462"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-462">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The first Nondenominational Christian churches which emerged through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stone-Campbell_Restoration_Movement" title="Stone-Campbell Restoration Movement">Stone-Campbell Restoration Movement</a> are tied to associations such as the <a href="/wiki/Churches_of_Christ" title="Churches of Christ">Churches of Christ</a> or the <a href="/wiki/Christian_Church_(Disciples_of_Christ)" title="Christian Church (Disciples of Christ)">Christian Church (Disciples of Christ)</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hughes1997_460-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hughes1997-460">[454]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barnett2020_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-Barnett2020-461">[455]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div>

.cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation web cs1" diffused of all faiths.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" </li>
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFDenova2022">Denova, Rebecca (2 March 2022). <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldhistory.org/christianity/" rel="nofollow">"Christianity"</a>. <a href="/wiki/World_History_Encyclopedia" title="World History Encyclopedia">World History Encyclopedia</a>. <q>Christianity is the world's largest religion, with 2.8 billion adherents.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Christianity&amp;rft.pub=World+History+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.date=2022-03-02&amp;rft.aulast=Denova&amp;rft.aufirst=Rebecca&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.worldhistory.org%2Fchristianity%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://countrymeters.info/en/World#religion" rel="nofollow">"World's largest religion by population is still Christianity"</a>. <i>Countrymeters</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 January</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Countrymeters&amp;rft.atitle=World%27s+largest+religion+by+population+is+still+Christianity&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fcountrymeters.info%2Fen%2FWorld%23religion&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pew_Forum" title="Pew Forum">The Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life</a>. December 2012. "<a class="external text" href="https://assets.pewresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/11/2014/01/global-religion-full.pdf" rel="nofollow">The Global Religious Landscape: A Report on the Size and Distribution of the World's Major Religious Groups as of 2010</a>." DC: Pew Research Center. <a class="external text" href="https://www.pewforum.org/2012/12/18/global-religious-landscape-exec/" rel="nofollow">Article</a>.</span>

<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFWoodhead2004">Woodhead 2004</a>, p. n.p</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFS._T._Kimbrough2005">S. T. Kimbrough, ed. (2005). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=q-vhwjamOioC&amp;q=anagignoskomena&amp;pg=PA23" rel="nofollow"><i>Orthodox and Wesleyan Scriptural understanding and practice</i></a>. St Vladimir's Seminary Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-88141-301-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-88141-301-4"><bdi>978-0-88141-301-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Orthodox+and+Wesleyan+Scriptural+understanding+and+practice&amp;rft.pub=St+Vladimir%27s+Seminary+Press&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-88141-301-4&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dq-vhwjamOioC%26q%3Danagignoskomena%26pg%3DPA23&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>Religions in Global Society</i>. p. 146, Peter Beyer, 2006</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Cambridge_University_Historical_Series-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cambridge_University_Historical_Series_8-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Cambridge University Historical Series, <i>An Essay on Western Civilization in Its Economic Aspects</i>, p. 40: Hebraism, like Hellenism, has been an all-important factor in the development of Western Civilization; Judaism, as the precursor of Christianity, has indirectly had had much to do with shaping the ideals and morality of western nations since the christian era.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Caltron_J.H_Hayas-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Caltron_J.H_Hayas_9-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Caltron J.H Hayas, <i>Christianity and Western Civilization</i> (1953), Stanford University Press, p. 2: "That certain distinctive features of our Western civilization—the civilization of western Europe and of America—have been shaped chiefly by Judaeo – Graeco – Christianity, Catholic and Protestant."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Fred_Reinhard_Dallmayr-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Fred_Reinhard_Dallmayr_10-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Fred Reinhard Dallmayr, <i>Dialogue Among Civilizations: Some Exemplary Voices</i> (2004), p. 22: Western civilization is also sometimes described as "Christian" or "Judaeo- Christian" civilization.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Spread-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Spread_11-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=g2AtOlJMPTUC&amp;pg=PA52" rel="nofollow"><i>Muslim-Christian Relations</i></a>. Amsterdam University Press. 2006. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-90-5356-938-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-90-5356-938-2"><bdi>978-90-5356-938-2</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 October</span> 2007</span>. <q>The enthusiasm for evangelization among the Christians was also accompanied by the awareness that the most immediate problem to solve was how to serve the huge number of new <a href="/wiki/Conversion_to_Christianity" title="Conversion to Christianity">converts</a>. Simatupang said, if the number of the Christians were double or triple, then the number of the ministers should also be doubled or tripled and the role of the laity should be maximized and Christian service to society through schools, universities, hospitals and orphanages, should be increased. In addition, for him the Christian mission should be involved in the struggle for justice amid the process of modernization.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Muslim-Christian+Relations&amp;rft.pub=Amsterdam+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-90-5356-938-2&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dg2AtOlJMPTUC%26pg%3DPA52&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Charity-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Charity_12-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKammer2004">Kammer, Fred (1 May 2004). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=WmuV6g0yR3sC&amp;pg=PA77" rel="nofollow"><i>Doing Faith Justice</i></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paulist_Press" title="Paulist Press">Paulist Press</a>. p. 77. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8091-4227-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8091-4227-9"><bdi>978-0-8091-4227-9</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 October</span> 2007</span>. <q>Theologians, bishops, and preachers urged the Christian community to be as compassionate as their God was, reiterating that creation was for all of humanity. They also accepted and developed the identification of Christ with the poor and the requisite Christian duty to the poor. Religious congregations and individual charismatic leaders promoted the development of a number of helping institutions-hospitals, hospices for <a href="/wiki/Christian_pilgrimage" title="Christian pilgrimage">pilgrims</a>, orphanages, shelters for unwed mothers-that laid the foundation for the modern "large network of hospitals, orphanages and schools, to serve the poor and society at large."</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Doing+Faith+Justice&amp;rft.pages=77&amp;rft.pub=Paulist+Press&amp;rft.date=2004-05-01&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8091-4227-9&amp;rft.aulast=Kammer&amp;rft.aufirst=Fred&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DWmuV6g0yR3sC%26pg%3DPA77&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Service-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Service_13-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=dz_EM2ofIb4C&amp;pg=PA132" rel="nofollow"><i>Christian Church Women: Shapers of a Movement</i></a>. Chalice Press. March 1994. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8272-0463-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8272-0463-8"><bdi>978-0-8272-0463-8</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 October</span> 2007</span>. <q>In the central provinces of India they established schools, orphanages, hospitals, and churches, and spread the gospel message in zenanas.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Christian+Church+Women%3A+Shapers+of+a+Movement&amp;rft.pub=Chalice+Press&amp;rft.date=1994-03&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8272-0463-8&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Ddz_EM2ofIb4C%26pg%3DPA132&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-14">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.pewforum.org/2011/12/19/global-christianity-traditions/" rel="nofollow">"Christian Traditions"</a>. <i>Pew Research Center's Religion &amp; Public Life Project</i>. 19 December 2011. <q>About half of all Christians worldwide are Catholic (50%), while more than a third are Protestant (37%). Orthodox communions comprise 12% of the world's Christians.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Pew+Research+Center%27s+Religion+%26+Public+Life+Project&amp;rft.atitle=Christian+Traditions&amp;rft.date=2011-12-19&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.pewforum.org%2F2011%2F12%2F19%2Fglobal-christianity-traditions%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-54">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=1Cor+15%3A6&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">1Cor 15:6</a></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-55"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-55">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=John&amp;version=3%3A16" rel="nofollow">John</a></span>, <span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=John+5%3A24&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">5:24</a></span>, <span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=John+6%3A39%E2%80%9340&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">6:39–40</a></span>, <span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=John+6%3A47&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">6:47</a></span>, <span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=John+10%3A10&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">10:10</a></span>, <span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=John+11%3A25%E2%80%9326&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">11:25–26</a></span>, and <span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=John+17%3A3&amp;version=NRSV" rel="nofollow">17:3</a></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-56"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-56">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This is drawn from a number of sources, especially the early Creeds, the <i>Catechism of the Catholic Church</i>, certain theological works, and various Confessions drafted during the Reformation including the <i>Thirty Nine Articles of the Church of England</i>, works contained in the <i>Book of Concord</i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-57"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-57">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Fuller, <i>The Foundations of New Testament Christology</i>, p. 11.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-58"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-58">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A <a href="/wiki/Jesus_Seminar" title="Jesus Seminar">Jesus Seminar</a> conclusion held that "in the view of the Seminar, he did not rise bodily from the dead; the resurrection is based instead on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vision_hypothesis" title="Vision hypothesis">visionary experiences</a> of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Peter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">Paul</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mary_Magdalene" title="Mary Magdalene">Mary</a>."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-59">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Funk. <i>The Acts of Jesus: What Did Jesus Really Do?</i>.</span>
</li>

</li>

<li id="cite_note-remedy-63"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-remedy_63-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-remedy_63-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFEisenbaum2004">Eisenbaum, Pamela (Winter 2004). <span class="cs1-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required"><a class="external text" href="https://www.sbl-site.org/assets/pdfs/JBL1234.pdf" rel="nofollow">"A Remedy for Having Been Born of Woman: Jesus, Gentiles, and Genealogy in Romans"</a></span> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Journal of Biblical Literature</i>. <b>123</b> (4): 671–702. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.2307%2F3268465" rel="nofollow">10.2307/3268465</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/3268465" rel="nofollow">3268465</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221009/https://www.sbl-site.org/assets/pdfs/JBL1234.pdf" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 9 October 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-Monotheism-72"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Monotheism_72-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Christianity's status as monotheistic is affirmed in, among other sources, the <i><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia" title="Catholic Encyclopedia">Catholic Encyclopedia</a></i> (article "<a class="external text" href="https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/10499a.htm" rel="nofollow">Monotheism</a>"); <a href="/wiki/William_F._Albright" title="William F. Albright">William F. Albright</a>, <i>From the Stone Age to Christianity</i>; <a href="/wiki/H._Richard_Niebuhr" title="H. Richard Niebuhr">H. Richard Niebuhr</a>; About.com, <a class="external text" href="https://ancienthistory.about.com/od/monotheisticreligions/" rel="nofollow"><i>Monotheistic Religion resources</i></a>; Kirsch, <i>God Against the Gods</i>; Woodhead, <i>An Introduction to Christianity</i>; <a href="/wiki/Columbia_Encyclopedia" title="Columbia Encyclopedia">The Columbia Electronic Encyclopedia</a> <a class="external text" href="https://www.infoplease.com/ce6/society/A0833762.html" rel="nofollow"><i>Monotheism</i></a>; The New Dictionary of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cultural_Literacy" title="Cultural Literacy">Cultural Literacy</a>, <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20071212011435/https://www.bartleby.com/59/5/monotheism.html" rel="nofollow"><i>monotheism</i></a>; New Dictionary of Theology, <a class="external text" href="https://www.ntwrightpage.com/Wright_NDCT_Paul.htm" rel="nofollow"><i>Paul</i></a>, pp. 496–499; Meconi. <li id="cite_note-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-78">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBowden2005">Bowden, John Stephen (2005). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaofch0000unse_u1l4/page/1206/mode/2up" rel="nofollow"><i>Encyclopedia of Christianity</i></a>. New York, N.Y. : Oxford University Press. p. 1207. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-522393-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-522393-4"><bdi>978-0-19-522393-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+Christianity&amp;rft.pages=1207&amp;rft.pub=New+York%2C+N.Y.+%3A+Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-522393-4&amp;rft.aulast=Bowden&amp;rft.aufirst=John+Stephen&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fencyclopediaofch0000unse_u1l4%2Fpage%2F1206%2Fmode%2F2up&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-79">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Heidi J. Hornik and Mikeal Carl Parsons, <i><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=BmWpMKaDBVUC&amp;pg=PA34" rel="nofollow">Interpreting Christian Art: Reflections on Christian art</a></i>, Mercer University Press, 2003, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-86554-850-1" title="Special:BookSources/0-86554-850-1">0-86554-850-1</a>, pp. 32–35.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-80"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-80">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>Examples of ante-Nicene statements</i>:<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Hence all the power of magic became dissolved; and every bond of wickedness was destroyed, men's ignorance was taken away, and the old kingdom abolished God Himself appearing in the form of a man, for the renewal of eternal life.</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite>St. Ignatius of Antioch in <i>Letter to the Ephesians</i>, ch.4, shorter version, Roberts-Donaldson translation</cite></div></blockquote><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>We have also as a Physician the Lord our God Jesus the Christ the only-begotten Son and Word, before time began, but who afterwards became also man, of Mary the virgin. For 'the Word was made flesh.' Being incorporeal, He was in the body; being impassible, He was in a passable body; being immortal, He was in a mortal body; being life, He became subject to corruption, that He might free our souls from death and corruption, and heal them, and might restore them to health, when they were diseased with ungodliness and wicked lusts</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite>St. Ignatius of Antioch in <i>Letter to the Ephesians</i>, ch.7, shorter version, Roberts-Donaldson translation</cite></div></blockquote>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>The Church, though dispersed throughout the whole world, even to the ends of the earth, has received from the apostles and their disciples this faith: ...one God, the Father Almighty, Maker of heaven, and earth, and the sea, and all things that are in them; and in one Christ Jesus, the Son of God, who became incarnate for our salvation; and in the Holy Spirit, who proclaimed through the prophets the dispensations of God, and the advents, and the birth from a virgin, and the passion, and the resurrection from the dead, and the ascension into heaven in the flesh of the beloved Christ Jesus, our Lord, and His manifestation from heaven in the glory of the Father 'to gather all things in one,' and to raise up anew all flesh of the whole human race, in order that to Christ Jesus, our Lord, and God, and Savior, and King, according to the will of the invisible Father, 'every knee should bow, of things in heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth, and that every tongue should confess; to him, and that He should execute just judgment towards all...</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite>St. Irenaeus in <i>Against Heresies</i>, ch.X, v.I, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation cs2" id="CITEREFDonaldson1950">Donaldson, Sir James (1950), <i>Ante Nicene Fathers, Volume 1: Apostolic Fathers, Justin Martyr, Irenaeus</i>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_B._Eerdmans_Publishing_Co." title="William B. Eerdmans Publishing Co.">William B. Eerdmans Publishing Co.</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8028-8087-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8028-8087-1"><bdi>978-0-8028-8087-1</bdi></a></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Ante+Nicene+Fathers%2C+Volume+1%3A+Apostolic+Fathers%2C+Justin+Martyr%2C+Irenaeus&amp;rft.pub=William+B.+Eerdmans+Publishing+Co.&amp;rft.date=1950&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8028-8087-1&amp;rft.aulast=Donaldson&amp;rft.aufirst=Sir+James&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></cite></div></blockquote>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>For, in the name of God, the Father and Lord of the universe, and of our Savior Jesus Christ, and of the Holy Spirit, they then receive the washing with water</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite>Justin Martyr in <i>First Apology</i>, ch. LXI, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation cs2" id="CITEREFDonaldson1950">Donaldson, Sir James (1950), <i>Ante Nicene Fathers, Volume 1: Apostolic Fathers, Justin Martyr, Irenaeus</i>, Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Company, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8028-8087-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8028-8087-1"><bdi>978-0-8028-8087-1</bdi></a></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Ante+Nicene+Fathers%2C+Volume+1%3A+Apostolic+Fathers%2C+Justin+Martyr%2C+Irenaeus&amp;rft.pub=Wm.+B.+Eerdmans+Publishing+Company&amp;rft.date=1950&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8028-8087-1&amp;rft.aulast=Donaldson&amp;rft.aufirst=Sir+James&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></cite></div></blockquote></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-81">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFOlson2002">Olson, Roger E. (2002). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=SUAidAp8AgEC" rel="nofollow"><i>The Trinity</i></a>. Wm. B. <li id="cite_note-114"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-114">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFWallwork2019">Wallwork, Norman (2019). <a class="external text" href="https://jlg.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Hymns-Purpose.pdf" rel="nofollow">"The Purpose of a Hymn Book"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <li id="cite_note-118"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-118">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20060812151753/https://www.lordlife.org/site/dbpage.asp?page_id=140000871&amp;sec_id=140000527" rel="nofollow">Understanding Closed Communion</a>, stating "<i>Therefore, our Congregation and our Denomination practices what is called ‘close or closed Communion’, meaning that before you take Communion at our Churches, we ask you to take a Communion Class first to properly learn what Communion is all about.</i>", by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Archive.org" title="Archive.org">Archive.org</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-Hartzler2013-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Hartzler2013_124-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHartzler2013">Hartzler, Rachel Nafziger (30 April 2013). <i>No Strings Attached: Boundary Lines in Pleasant Places: A History of Warren Street / Pleasant Oaks Mennonite Church</i>. <li id="cite_note-126"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-126">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSenn2012">Senn, Frank C. (2012). <i>Introduction to Christian Liturgy</i>. Fortress Press. p. 103. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4514-2433-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4514-2433-1"><bdi>978-1-4514-2433-1</bdi></a>. <q>For example, days of Mary, Joseph, and John the Baptist (e.g., August 15, March 19, June 24, respectively) are ranked as solemnities in the Roman Catholic calendar; in the Anglican and Lutheran calendars they are holy days or lesser festivals respectively.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Introduction+to+Christian+Liturgy&amp;rft.pages=103&amp;rft.pub=Fortress+Press&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4514-2433-1&amp;rft.aulast=Senn&amp;rft.aufirst=Frank+C.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-calendar-127"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-calendar_127-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-calendar_127-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFFortescue1912">Fortescue, Adrian (1912). <a class="external text" href="https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/03158a.htm" rel="nofollow">"Christian Calendar"</a>. <i>The Catholic Encyclopedia</i>.
