</li>
<li id="cite_note-128"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-128">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Hickman. <i>Handbook of the Christian Year</i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-129"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-129">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.ccel.org/fathers2/ANF-04/anf04-34.htm" rel="nofollow">"ANF04. Fathers of the Third Century: Tertullian, Part Fourth; Minucius Felix; Commodian; Origen, Parts First and Second | Christian Classics Ethereal Library"</a>. Ccel.org. 1 June 2005<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">5 May</span> 2009</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=ANF04.+Fathers+of+the+Third+Century%3A+Tertullian%2C+Part+Fourth%3B+Minucius+Felix%3B+Commodian%3B+Origen%2C+Parts+First+and+Second+%26%23124%3B+Christian+Classics+Ethereal+Library&amp;rft.pub=Ccel.org&amp;rft.date=2005-06-01&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ccel.org%2Ffathers2%2FANF-04%2Fanf04-34.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-130"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-130">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Minucius Felix speaks of the cross of Jesus in its familiar form, likening it to objects with a crossbeam or to a man with arms outstretched in prayer (<a class="external text" href="https://www.ccel.org/fathers2/ANF-04/anf04-34.htm#P5713_906729" rel="nofollow">Octavius of Minucius Felix</a>, chapter XXIX).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-131"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-131">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"At every forward step and movement, at every going in and out, when we put on our clothes and shoes, when we bathe, when we sit at table, when we light the lamps, on couch, on seat, in all the ordinary actions of daily life, we trace upon the forehead the sign." (Tertullian, <a class="external text" href="https://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/anf03.iv.vi.iii.html" rel="nofollow"><i>De Corona</i>, chapter 3</a>)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-soc-132"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-soc_132-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-soc_132-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Dilasser. <i>The Symbols of the Church</i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-cefish-133"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-cefish_133-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cefish_133-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1" id="CITEREFMaurice_M._Hassett1913">Maurice M. Hassett (1913). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="s:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/Symbolism of the Fish"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia_(1913)/Symbolism_of_the_Fish">"Symbolism of the Fish" </a></span>.  In Herbermann, Charles (ed.). <i><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia" title="Catholic Encyclopedia">Catholic Encyclopedia</a></i>. New York: Robert Appleton Company.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Symbolism+of+the+Fish&amp;rft.btitle=Catholic+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Robert+Appleton+Company&amp;rft.date=1913&amp;rft.au=Maurice+M.+Hassett&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-135"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-135">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i> (2nd ed.). <a href="/wiki/Vatican_Publishing_House" title="Vatican Publishing House">Libreria Editrice Vaticana</a>. 2019. <a class="external text" href="https://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG0015/__P3G.HTM#:~:text=1213%20" rel="nofollow">Paragraph 1213</a>. <q>Through Baptism we are freed from sin and reborn as sons of God; we become members of Christ, are incorporated into the Church and made sharers in her mission.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Catechism+of+the+Catholic+Church&amp;rft.pages=Paragraph+1213&amp;rft.edition=2nd&amp;rft.pub=Libreria+Editrice+Vaticana&amp;rft.date=2019&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-136"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-136">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Holy Baptism is the sacrament by which God adopts us as his children and makes us members of Christ's Body, the Church, and inheritors of the kingdom of God" (<a class="external text" href="https://anglicansonline.org/basics/catechism.html#Holy" rel="nofollow">Book of Common Prayer, 1979, Episcopal)</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-137"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-137">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Baptism is the sacrament of initiation and incorporation into the body of Christ" (<a class="external text" href="https://www.backriverumc.com/userFiles/1257/by_water_and_the_spirit.pdf" rel="nofollow">By Water and The Spirit – The Official United Methodist Understanding of Baptism (PDF)</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160313053601/https://www.backriverumc.com/userFiles/1257/by_water_and_the_spirit.pdf" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 13 March 2016 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-138"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-138">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"As an initiatory rite into membership of the Family of God, baptismal candidates are symbolically purified or washed as their sins have been forgiven and washed away" (<a href="/wiki/William_H._Brackney" title="William H. Brackney">William H. Brackney</a>, <a class="external text" href="https://www.baptisthistory.org/pamphlets/baptism.htm" rel="nofollow">Doing Baptism Baptist Style –  Believer's Baptism</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100107183031/https://www.baptisthistory.org/pamphlets/baptism.htm" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 7 January 2010 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-139"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-139">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"After the proclamation of faith, the baptismal water is prayed over and blessed as the sign of the goodness of God's creation. The person to be baptized is also prayed over and blessed with sanctified oil as the sign that his creation by God is holy and good. And then, after the solemn proclamation of "Alleluia" (God be praised), the person is immersed three times in the water in the name of the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit" (<a class="external text" href="https://www.oca.org/OCchapter.asp?SID=2&amp;ID=51" rel="nofollow">Orthodox Church in America: Baptism).</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20101012021946/https://www.oca.org/OCchapter.asp?SID=2&amp;ID=51" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 12 October 2010 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-140"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-140">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"In the Orthodox Church we totally immerse, because such total immersion symbolizes death. What death? The death of the "old, sinful man". After Baptism we are freed from the dominion of sin, even though after Baptism we retain an inclination and tendency toward evil.", Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of Australia, article "<a class="external text" href="https://www.greekorthodox.org.au/general/faq/faqbaptism" rel="nofollow">Baptism</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140930002357/https://www.greekorthodox.org.au/general/faq/faqbaptism" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 30 September 2014 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Olson2017-141"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Olson2017_141-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFOlson2017">Olson, Karen Bates (12 January 2017). <a class="external text" href="https://www.livinglutheran.org/2017/01/why-infant-baptism/" rel="nofollow">"Why infant baptism?"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Living_Lutheran" title="Living Lutheran">Living Lutheran</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-143"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-143">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i> (2nd ed.). <a href="/wiki/Vatican_Publishing_House" title="Vatican Publishing House">Libreria Editrice Vaticana</a>. 2019. <a class="external text" href="https://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG0015/__P3J.HTM#:~:text=1231%20" rel="nofollow">Paragraphs 1231, 1233, 1250, 1252</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Catechism+of+the+Catholic+Church&amp;rft.pages=Paragraphs+1231%2C+1233%2C+1250%2C+1252&amp;rft.edition=2nd&amp;rft.pub=Libreria+Editrice+Vaticana&amp;rft.date=2019&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-144"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-144">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i> (2nd ed.). <a href="/wiki/Vatican_Publishing_House" title="Vatican Publishing House">Libreria Editrice Vaticana</a>. 2019. <a class="external text" href="https://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG0015/__P3J.HTM#:~:text=1240%20" rel="nofollow">Paragraph 1240</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Catechism+of+the+Catholic+Church&amp;rft.pages=Paragraph+1240&amp;rft.edition=2nd&amp;rft.pub=Libreria+Editrice+Vaticana&amp;rft.date=2019&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Eby-145"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Eby_145-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFEby">Eby, Edwin R. <a class="external text" href="https://www.pilgrimministry.org/literature/early-anabaptist-positions-on-believer%E2%80%99s-baptism-and-a-challenge-for-today" rel="nofollow">"Early Anabaptist Positions on Believer's Baptism and a Challenge for Today"</a>. Pilgrim Mennonite Conference<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">11 May</span> 2022</span>. <q>They concluded according to the Scriptures that baptism must always follow a conscious decision to take up “following Christ.” They believed that a regenerated life becomes the experience of an adult who counts the cost of following Christ, exercises obedience to Christ, and is therefore baptized as a sign of such commitment and life.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Early+Anabaptist+Positions+on+Believer%27s+Baptism+and+a+Challenge+for+Today&amp;rft.pub=Pilgrim+Mennonite+Conference&amp;rft.aulast=Eby&amp;rft.aufirst=Edwin+R.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.pilgrimministry.org%2Fliterature%2Fearly-anabaptist-positions-on-believer%25E2%2580%2599s-baptism-and-a-challenge-for-today&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-KurianDay2017-146"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-KurianDay2017_146-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKurianDay2017">Kurian, George Thomas; Day, Sarah Claudine (14 March 2017). <i>The Essential Handbook of Denominations and Ministries</i>. Baker Books. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4934-0640-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4934-0640-1"><bdi>978-1-4934-0640-1</bdi></a>. <q>The Conservative Mennonite Conference practices believer's baptism, seen as an external symbol of internal spiritual purity and performed by immersion or pouring of water on the head; Communion; washing the feet of the saints, following Jesus's example and reminding beleivers of the need to be washed of pride, rivalry, and selfish motives; anointing the sick with oil--a symbol of the Holy Spirit and of the healing power of God--offered with the prayer of faith; and laying on of hands for ordination, symbolizing the imparting of responsibility and of God's power to fulfill that responsibility.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Essential+Handbook+of+Denominations+and+Ministries&amp;rft.pub=Baker+Books&amp;rft.date=2017-03-14&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4934-0640-1&amp;rft.aulast=Kurian&amp;rft.aufirst=George+Thomas&amp;rft.au=Day%2C+Sarah+Claudine&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Kraybill2010-147"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kraybill2010_147-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKraybill2010">Kraybill, Donald B. (1 November 2010). <i>Concise Encyclopedia of Amish, Brethren, Hutterites, and Mennonites</i>. JHU Press. p. 23. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8018-9911-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8018-9911-9"><bdi>978-0-8018-9911-9</bdi></a>. <q>All Amish, Hutterites, and most Mennonites baptized by pouring or sprinkling.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Concise+Encyclopedia+of+Amish%2C+Brethren%2C+Hutterites%2C+and+Mennonites&amp;rft.pages=23&amp;rft.pub=JHU+Press&amp;rft.date=2010-11-01&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8018-9911-9&amp;rft.aulast=Kraybill&amp;rft.aufirst=Donald+B.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-NoltLoewen2010-148"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-NoltLoewen2010_148-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFNoltLoewen2010">Nolt, Steven M.; Loewen, Harry (11 June 2010). <i>Through Fire and Water: An Overview of Mennonite History</i>. MennoMedia. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8316-9701-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8316-9701-3"><bdi>978-0-8316-9701-3</bdi></a>. <q>...both groups practiced believers baptism (the River Brethren did so by immersion in a stream or river) and stressed simplicity in life and nonresistance to violence.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Through+Fire+and+Water%3A+An+Overview+of+Mennonite+History&amp;rft.pub=MennoMedia&amp;rft.date=2010-06-11&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8316-9701-3&amp;rft.aulast=Nolt&amp;rft.aufirst=Steven+M.&amp;rft.au=Loewen%2C+Harry&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Brackney2012-149"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Brackney2012_149-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBrackney2012">Brackney, William H. (3 May 2012). <i>Historical Dictionary of Radical Christianity</i>. Scarecrow Press. p. 279. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8108-7365-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8108-7365-0"><bdi>978-0-8108-7365-0</bdi></a>. <q>The birthdate in 1708 marked the baptism by immersion of the group in the River Eder, thus believer's baptism became one of the primary tenets of The Brethren.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Historical+Dictionary+of+Radical+Christianity&amp;rft.pages=279&amp;rft.pub=Scarecrow+Press&amp;rft.date=2012-05-03&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8108-7365-0&amp;rft.aulast=Brackney&amp;rft.aufirst=William+H.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-150"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-150">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+6%3A9-13&amp;version=EHV" rel="nofollow">"Matthew 6:9–13 Evangelical Heritage Version (EHV)"</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">10 March</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Matthew+6%3A9%E2%80%9313+Evangelical+Heritage+Version+%28EHV%29&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.biblegateway.com%2Fpassage%2F%3Fsearch%3DMatthew%2B6%253A9-13%26version%3DEHV&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Jordan-151"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Jordan_151-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJordan2000">Jordan, Anne (2000). <i>Christianity</i>. Nelson Thornes. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7487-5320-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7487-5320-8"><bdi>978-0-7487-5320-8</bdi></a>. <q>When he was standing on a hillside, Jesus explained to his followers how they were to behave as God would wish. The talk has become known as the Sermon on the Mount, and is found in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter 5, 6 and 7. During the talk Jesus taught his followers how to pray and he gave them an example of suitable prayer. Christians call the prayer the Lord's Prayer, because it was taught by the Lord, Jesus Christ. It is also known as the Pattern Prayer as it provides a pattern for Christians to follow in prayer, to ensure that they pray in the way God and Jesus would want.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Christianity&amp;rft.pub=Nelson+Thornes&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7487-5320-8&amp;rft.aulast=Jordan&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Milavec2003-152"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Milavec2003_152-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMilavec2003">Milavec, Aaron (2003). <i>The Didache: Faith, Hope, &amp; Life of the Earliest Christian Communities, 50–70 C.E</i>. Paulist Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8091-0537-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8091-0537-3"><bdi>978-0-8091-0537-3</bdi></a>. <q>Given the placement of the Lord's Prayer in the Didache, it was to be expected that the new member of the community would come to learn and to pray the Lord's Prayer at the appointed hours three times each day only after baptism (8:2f.).</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Didache%3A+Faith%2C+Hope%2C+%26+Life+of+the+Earliest+Christian+Communities%2C+50%E2%80%9370+C.E.&amp;rft.pub=Paulist+Press&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8091-0537-3&amp;rft.aulast=Milavec&amp;rft.aufirst=Aaron&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Beckwith2005-153"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Beckwith2005_153-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBeckwith2005">Beckwith, Roger T. (2005). <i>Calendar, Chronology And Worship: Studies in Ancient Judaism And Early Christianity</i>. BRILL. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-90-04-14603-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-90-04-14603-7"><bdi>978-90-04-14603-7</bdi></a>. <q>So three minor hours of prayer were developed, at the third, sixth and ninth hours, which, as Dugmore points out, were ordinary divisions of the day for worldly affairs, and the Lord's Prayer was transferred to those hours.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Calendar%2C+Chronology+And+Worship%3A+Studies+in+Ancient+Judaism+And+Early+Christianity&amp;rft.pub=BRILL&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-90-04-14603-7&amp;rft.aulast=Beckwith&amp;rft.aufirst=Roger+T.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Chadwick1993-154"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Chadwick1993_154-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFChadwick1993"><a href="/wiki/Henry_Chadwick_(theologian)" title="Henry Chadwick (theologian)">Chadwick, Henry</a> (1993). <i>The Early Church</i>. Penguin. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-101-16042-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-101-16042-8"><bdi>978-1-101-16042-8</bdi></a>. <q>Hippolytus in the <i>Apostolic Tradition</i> directed that Christians should pray seven times a day – on rising, at the lighting of the evening lamp, at bedtime, at midnight, and also, if at home, at the third, sixth and ninth hours of the day, being hours associated with Christ's Passion. Prayers at the third, sixth, and ninth hours are similarly mentioned by Tertullian, Cyprian, Clement of Alexandria and Origen, and must have been very widely practised. These prayers were commonly associated with private Bible reading in the family.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Early+Church&amp;rft.pub=Penguin&amp;rft.date=1993&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-101-16042-8&amp;rft.aulast=Chadwick&amp;rft.aufirst=Henry&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Lössl2010-155"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Lössl2010_155-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLössl2010">Lössl, Josef (17 February 2010). <i>The Early Church: History and Memory</i>. A&amp;C Black. p. 135. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-567-16561-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-567-16561-9"><bdi>978-0-567-16561-9</bdi></a>. <q>Not only the content of early Christian prayer was rooted in Jewish tradition; its daily structure too initially followed a Jewish pattern, with prayer times in the early morning, at noon and in the evening. Later (in the course of the second century), this pattern combined with another one; namely prayer times in the evening, at midnight and in the morning. As a result seven 'hours of prayer' emerged, which later became the monastic 'hours' and are still treated as 'standard' prayer times in many churches today. They are roughly equivalent to midnight, 6 a.m., 9 a.m., noon, 3 p.m., 6 p.m. and 9 p.m. Prayer positions included prostration, kneeling and standing. ... Crosses made of wood or stone, or painted on walls or laid out as mosaics, were also in use, at first not directly as objections of veneration but in order to 'orientate' the direction of prayer (i.e. towards the east, Latin <i>oriens</i>).</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Early+Church%3A+History+and+Memory&amp;rft.pages=135&amp;rft.pub=A%26C+Black&amp;rft.date=2010-02-17&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-567-16561-9&amp;rft.aulast=L%C3%B6ssl&amp;rft.aufirst=Josef&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Kurian2020-156"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kurian2020_156-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFKurian">Kurian, Jake. <a class="external text" href="https://www.ds-wa.org/seven-times-a-day-i-praise-you-the-sheema-prayers.html" rel="nofollow">"<span class="cs1-kern-left"></span>"Seven Times a Day I Praise You" – The Shehimo Prayers"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Malankara_Orthodox_Diocese_of_Southwest_America" title="Malankara Orthodox Diocese of Southwest America">Diocese of South-West America of the Malankara Orthodox Syrian Church</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 August</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%22Seven+Times+a+Day+I+Praise+You%22+%E2%80%93+The+Shehimo+Prayers&amp;rft.pub=Diocese+of+South-West+America+of+the+Malankara+Orthodox+Syrian+Church&amp;rft.aulast=Kurian&amp;rft.aufirst=Jake&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ds-wa.org%2Fseven-times-a-day-i-praise-you-the-sheema-prayers.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Amherst1906-157"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Amherst1906_157-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMary_Cecil,_2nd_Baroness_Amherst_of_Hackney1906"><a href="/wiki/Mary_Cecil,_2nd_Baroness_Amherst_of_Hackney" title="Mary Cecil, 2nd Baroness Amherst of Hackney">Mary Cecil, 2nd Baroness Amherst of Hackney</a> (1906). <i>A Sketch of Egyptian History from the Earliest Times to the Present Day</i>. Methuen. p. 399. <q>Prayers 7 times a day are enjoined, and the most strict among the Copts recite one of more of the Psalms of David each time they pray. They always wash their hands and faces before devotions, and turn to the East.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Sketch+of+Egyptian+History+from+the+Earliest+Times+to+the+Present+Day&amp;rft.pages=399&amp;rft.pub=Methuen&amp;rft.date=1906&amp;rft.au=Mary+Cecil%2C+2nd+Baroness+Amherst+of+Hackney&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-WELS2014-187"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-WELS2014_187-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WELS2014_187-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.wels.net/what-we-believe/questions-answers/christian/methodist-beliefs" rel="nofollow">"Methodist Beliefs: In what ways are Lutherans different from United Methodists?"</a>. Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod. 2014. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140522105449/https://www.wels.net/what-we-believe/questions-answers/christian/methodist-beliefs" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 22 May 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">22 May</span> 2014</span>. <q>The United Methodists see Scripture as the primary source and criterion for Christian doctrine. They emphasize the importance of tradition, experience, and reason for Christian doctrine. Lutherans teach that the Bible is the sole source for Christian doctrine. The truths of Scripture do not need to be authenticated by tradition, human experience, or reason. Scripture is self authenticating and is true in and of itself.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Methodist+Beliefs%3A+In+what+ways+are+Lutherans+different+from+United+Methodists%3F&amp;rft.pub=Wisconsin+Evangelical+Lutheran+Synod&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wels.net%2Fwhat-we-believe%2Fquestions-answers%2Fchristian%2Fmethodist-beliefs&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-188"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-188">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMathison2001"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Keith_A._Mathison" title="Keith A. Mathison">Mathison, Keith A.</a> (2001). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=w_PHAGr2TfgC&amp;pg=PA15" rel="nofollow">"Introduction"</a>. <a href="/wiki/The_Shape_of_Sola_Scriptura" title="The Shape of Sola Scriptura"><i>The Shape of Sola Scriptura</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Canon_Press" title="Canon Press">Canon Press</a>. p. 15. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-885767-74-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-885767-74-5"><bdi>978-1-885767-74-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Introduction&amp;rft.btitle=The+Shape+of+Sola+Scriptura&amp;rft.pages=15&amp;rft.pub=Canon+Press&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-885767-74-5&amp;rft.aulast=Mathison&amp;rft.aufirst=Keith+A.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dw_PHAGr2TfgC%26pg%3DPA15&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Humphrey2013-189"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Humphrey2013_189-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHumphrey2013">Humphrey, Edith M. Baker Books. p. 16. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4412-4048-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4412-4048-4"><bdi>978-1-4412-4048-4</bdi></a>. <q>historically Anglicans have adopted what could be called a prima Scriptura position.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Scripture+and+Tradition&amp;rft.pages=16&amp;rft.pub=Baker+Books&amp;rft.date=2013-04-15&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4412-4048-4&amp;rft.aulast=Humphrey&amp;rft.aufirst=Edith+M.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Elwell565-194"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Elwell565_194-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Elwell565_194-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFElwell1984">Elwell, Walter A. <li id="cite_note-195"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-195">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJohnson1990">Johnson, Elliott (1990). <i>Expository hermeneutics : an introduction</i>. <li id="cite_note-196"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-196">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFTerry1974">Terry, Milton (1974). <i>Biblical hermeneutics : a treatise on the interpretation of the Old and New Testaments</i>. Grand Rapids Mich.: Zondervan Pub. House. p. 205.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Biblical+hermeneutics+%3A+a+treatise+on+the+interpretation+of+the+Old+and+New+Testaments&amp;rft.place=Grand+Rapids+Mich.&amp;rft.pages=205&amp;rft.pub=Zondervan+Pub.+House&amp;rft.date=1974&amp;rft.aulast=Terry&amp;rft.aufirst=Milton&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span> (1890 edition page 103, <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Fy9VAAAAMAAJ&amp;focus=searchwithinvolume&amp;q=%22fundamental+principle%22" rel="nofollow">view1</a>, <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Fy9VAAAAMAAJ&amp;focus=searchwithinvolume&amp;q=%22neglect+this+principle%22" rel="nofollow">view2</a>)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-197"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-197">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">e.g., in his <a class="external text" href="https://biblehub.com/commentaries/mhcw/matthew/1.htm" rel="nofollow">commentary on Matthew 1</a> (§III.1). <a href="/wiki/Matthew_Henry" title="Matthew Henry">Matthew Henry</a> interprets the twin sons of Judah, Phares and Zara, as an allegory of the Gentile and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_Christians" title="Jewish Christians">Jewish Christians</a>. For a contemporary treatment, see Glenny, <i><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblicalstudies.org.uk/article_typology_glenny.html" rel="nofollow">Typology: A Summary Of The Present Evangelical Discussion</a></i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-198"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-198">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/2589-7993_eeco_dum_00001220" rel="nofollow">"Evodius of Antioch → Antioch, Church of"</a>. <i>Brill Encyclopedia of Early Christianity Online</i>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1163%2F2589-7993_eeco_dum_00001220" rel="nofollow">10.1163/2589-7993_eeco_dum_00001220</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">14 March</span> 2022</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Brill+Encyclopedia+of+Early+Christianity+Online&amp;rft.atitle=Evodius+of+Antioch+%E2%86%92+Antioch%2C+Church+of&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1163%2F2589-7993_eeco_dum_00001220&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdx.doi.org%2F10.1163%2F2589-7993_eeco_dum_00001220&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Cory2015-199"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cory2015_199-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCory2015">Cory, Catherine (13 August 2015). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=SsZcCgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA20" rel="nofollow"><i>Christian Theological Tradition</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-207"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-207">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eusebius_of_Caesarea" title="Eusebius of Caesarea">Eusebius of Caesarea</a>, the author of <i><a href="/wiki/Church_History_(Eusebius)" title="Church History (Eusebius)">Ecclesiastical History</a></i> in the 4th century, states that St. Mark came to Egypt in the first or third year of the reign of Emperor Claudius, i.e. 41 or 43 AD. <li id="cite_note-McTavish2010-219"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-McTavish2010_219-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMcTavish2010">McTavish, T. J. (2010). <i>A Theological Miscellany: 160 Pages of Odd, Merry, Essentially Inessential Facts, Figures, and Tidbits about Christianity</i>. Thomas Nelson. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4185-5281-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4185-5281-7"><bdi>978-1-4185-5281-7</bdi></a>. <q>The Nicene Creed, as used in the churches of the West (Anglican, Catholic, Lutheran, and others), contains the statement, "We believe [<i>or</i> I believe] in the Holy Spirit, the Lord, the giver of life, who proceeds from the Father and the Son."</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Theological+Miscellany%3A+160+Pages+of+Odd%2C+Merry%2C+Essentially+Inessential+Facts%2C+Figures%2C+and+Tidbits+about+Christianity&amp;rft.pub=Thomas+Nelson&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4185-5281-7&amp;rft.aulast=McTavish&amp;rft.aufirst=T.+J.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-openuni-258"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-openuni_258-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-openuni_258-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Open University, <i><a class="external text" href="https://www.open.ac.uk/Arts/renaissance2/religion.htm" rel="nofollow">Looking at the Renaissance: Religious Context in the Renaissance</a></i> (Retrieved 10 May 2007)</span>

<li id="cite_note-259"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-259">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Some scholars and historians attribute Christianity to having contributed to the rise of the Scientific Revolution:
<ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFHarrison2012">Harrison, Peter (8 May 2012). <a class="external text" href="https://www.abc.net.au/religion/articles/2012/05/08/3498202.htm" rel="nofollow">"Christianity and the rise of western science"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Australian_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="Australian Broadcasting Corporation">Australian Broadcasting Corporation</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">28 August</span> 2014</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Broadcasting+Corporation&amp;rft.atitle=Christianity+and+the+rise+of+western+science&amp;rft.date=2012-05-08&amp;rft.aulast=Harrison&amp;rft.aufirst=Peter&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.abc.net.au%2Freligion%2Farticles%2F2012%2F05%2F08%2F3498202.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation cs2" id="CITEREFNoll"><a href="/wiki/Mark_Noll" title="Mark Noll">Noll, Mark</a>, <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150322013257/https://biologos.org/uploads/projects/noll_scholarly_essay2.pdf" rel="nofollow"><i>Science, Religion, and A.D. White: Seeking Peace in the "Warfare Between Science and Theology"</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>, The Biologos Foundation, p. 4, archived from <a class="external text" href="https://biologos.org/uploads/projects/noll_scholarly_essay2.pdf" rel="nofollow">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 22 March 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">14 January</span> 2015</span></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Science%2C+Religion%2C+and+A.D.+White%3A+Seeking+Peace+in+the+%22Warfare+Between+Science+and+Theology%22&amp;rft.pages=4&amp;rft.pub=The+Biologos+Foundation&amp;rft.aulast=Noll&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbiologos.org%2Fuploads%2Fprojects%2Fnoll_scholarly_essay2.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation cs2" id="CITEREFLindbergNumbers1986"><a href="/wiki/David_C._Lindberg" title="David C. Lindberg">Lindberg, David C.</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ronald_L._Numbers" title="Ronald L. <li id="cite_note-262"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-262">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Because he would not accept the Formula of Concord without some reservations, he was excommunicated from the Lutheran communion. Because he remained faithful to his Lutheranism throughout his life, he experienced constant suspicion from Catholics." John L. Treloar, "Biography of Kepler shows man of rare integrity. Astronomer saw science and spirituality as one." <i>National Catholic Reporter</i>, 8 October 2004, p. 2a. A review of James A. Connor <i>Kepler's Witch: An Astronomer's Discovery of Cosmic Order amid Religious War, Political Intrigue and Heresy Trial of His Mother</i>,  Harper San Francisco.</span>

<li id="cite_note-280"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-280">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFDenova2022">Denova, Rebecca (2 March 2022). <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldhistory.org/christianity/" rel="nofollow">"Christianity"</a>. <a href="/wiki/World_History_Encyclopedia" title="World History Encyclopedia">World History Encyclopedia</a>. <q>Christianity is the world's largest religion, with 2.8 billion adherents.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Christianity&amp;rft.pub=World+History+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.date=2022-03-02&amp;rft.aulast=Denova&amp;rft.aufirst=Rebecca&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.worldhistory.org%2Fchristianity%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-291"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-291">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Johnstone, Patrick, <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=AVzFAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA109" rel="nofollow">"The Future of the Global Church: History, Trends and Possibilities"</a>, p. 100, fig 4.10 &amp; 4.11</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-292"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-292">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Hillerbrand, Hans J., <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=4tbFBQAAQBAJ&amp;lpg=PT3311" rel="nofollow">"Encyclopedia of Protestantism: 4-volume Set"</a>, p. 1815, "Observers carefully comparing all these figures in the total context will have observed the even more startling finding that for the first time ever in the history of Protestantism, <i>Wider Protestants</i> will by 2050 have become almost exactly as numerous as Catholics – each with just over 1.5 billion followers, or 17 percent of the world, with Protestants growing considerably faster than Catholics each year."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-294"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-294">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Some scholars suggest that Pentecostalism is the fastest growing religion in the world:
<ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMillerSargeantFlory2013">Miller, Donald E; Sargeant, Kimon H; Flory, Richard, eds. (9 September 2013). <a class="external text" href="https://oxford.universitypressscholarship.com/view/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199920570.001.0001/acprof-9780199920570" rel="nofollow"><i>Spirit and Power: The Growth and Global Impact of Pentecostalism</i></a>. Oxford University Press Scholarship. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1093%2Facprof%3Aoso%2F9780199920570.001.0001" rel="nofollow">10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199920570.001.0001</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-934563-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-934563-2"><bdi>978-0-19-934563-2</bdi></a>. <q>Pentecostalism is the fastest-growing religious movement in the world</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Spirit+and+Power%3A+The+Growth+and+Global+Impact+of+Pentecostalism&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press+Scholarship&amp;rft.date=2013-09-09&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1093%2Facprof%3Aoso%2F9780199920570.001.0001&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-934563-2&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Foxford.universitypressscholarship.com%2Fview%2F10.1093%2Facprof%3Aoso%2F9780199920570.001.0001%2Facprof-9780199920570&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAndersonBergunderDroogers2012">Anderson, Allan; Bergunder, Michael; Droogers, Andre (9 May 2012). <a class="external text" href="https://california.universitypressscholarship.com/view/10.1525/california/9780520266612.001.0001/upso-9780520266612" rel="nofollow"><i>Studying Global Pentecostalism: Theories and Methods</i></a>. University of California Press Scholarship. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1525%2Fcalifornia%2F9780520266612.001.0001" rel="nofollow">10.1525/california/9780520266612.001.0001</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780520266612" title="Special:BookSources/9780520266612"><bdi>9780520266612</bdi></a>. <q>With its remarkable ability to adapt to different cultures, Pentecostalism has become the world's fastest growing religious movement.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Studying+Global+Pentecostalism%3A+Theories+and+Methods&amp;rft.pub=University+of+California+Press+Scholarship&amp;rft.date=2012-05-09&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1525%2Fcalifornia%2F9780520266612.001.0001&amp;rft.isbn=9780520266612&amp;rft.aulast=Anderson&amp;rft.aufirst=Allan&amp;rft.au=Bergunder%2C+Michael&amp;rft.au=Droogers%2C+Andre&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fcalifornia.universitypressscholarship.com%2Fview%2F10.1525%2Fcalifornia%2F9780520266612.001.0001%2Fupso-9780520266612&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/rearvision/pentecostal/13360182" rel="nofollow">"Pentecostalism—the fastest growing religion on earth"</a>. ABC. 30 May 2021.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Pentecostalism%E2%80%94the+fastest+growing+religion+on+earth&amp;rft.pub=ABC&amp;rft.date=2021-05-30&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.abc.net.au%2Fradionational%2Fprograms%2Frearvision%2Fpentecostal%2F13360182&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://pulitzercenter.org/stories/pentecostalism-massive-global-growth-under-radar" rel="nofollow">"Pentecostalism: Massive Global Growth Under the Radar"</a>. Pulitzer Center. 9 March 2015. <q>Today, one quarter of the two billion Christians in the world are Pentecostal or Charismatic. Pentecostalism is the fastest growing religion in the world.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Pentecostalism%3A+Massive+Global+Growth+Under+the+Radar&amp;rft.pub=Pulitzer+Center&amp;rft.date=2015-03-09&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fpulitzercenter.org%2Fstories%2Fpentecostalism-massive-global-growth-under-radar&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://scholarworks.gsu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://www.google.com/&amp;httpsredir=1&amp;article=1067&amp;context=political_science_theses" rel="nofollow">"Max Weber and Pentecostals in Latin America: The Protestant Ethic, Social Capital and Spiritual Capital Ethic, Social Capital and Spiritual Capital"</a>. Georgia State University. 9 May 2016. <q>Many scholars claim that Pentecostalism is the fastest growing religious phenomenon in human history.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Max+Weber+and+Pentecostals+in+Latin+America%3A+The+Protestant+Ethic%2C+Social+Capital+and+Spiritual+Capital+Ethic%2C+Social+Capital+and+Spiritual+Capital&amp;rft.pub=Georgia+State+University&amp;rft.date=2016-05-09&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fscholarworks.gsu.edu%2Fcgi%2Fviewcontent.cgi%3Freferer%3Dhttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2F%26httpsredir%3D1%26article%3D1067%26context%3Dpolitical_science_theses&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li></ul>
</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-Pew_Research_Center-311"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Pew_Research_Center_311-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Pew_Research_Center_311-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.pewforum.org/2018/10/29/eastern-and-western-europeans-differ-on-importance-of-religion-views-of-minorities-and-key-social-issues/" rel="nofollow">"Eastern and Western Europeans Differ on Importance of Religion, Views of Minorities, and Key Social Issues"</a>. <i>Pew Research Center</i>. 29 October 2018.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Pew+Research+Center&amp;rft.atitle=Eastern+and+Western+Europeans+Differ+on+Importance+of+Religion%2C+Views+of+Minorities%2C+and+Key+Social+Issues&amp;rft.date=2018-10-29&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.pewforum.org%2F2018%2F10%2F29%2Feastern-and-western-europeans-differ-on-importance-of-religion-views-of-minorities-and-key-social-issues%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-312"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-312">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFYang2017">Yang, Fenggang (20 January 2017). <a class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/3711910" rel="nofollow">"Chinese Conversion to Evangelical Christianity: The Importance of Social and Cultural Contexts"</a>. <i>Sociology of Religion</i>. Oxford University Press. <b>59</b> (3): 237–257. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.2307%2F3711910" rel="nofollow">10.2307/3711910</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/3711910" rel="nofollow">3711910</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Sociology+of+Religion&amp;rft.atitle=Chinese+Conversion+to+Evangelical+Christianity%3A+The+Importance+of+Social+and+Cultural+Contexts&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=237-257&amp;rft.date=2017-01-20&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.2307%2F3711910&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F3711910%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft.aulast=Yang&amp;rft.aufirst=Fenggang&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F3711910&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Singapore_Management_University-313"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Singapore_Management_University_313-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Singapore_Management_University_313-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Singapore_Management_University_313-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://cmp.smu.edu.sg/perspectives/2012/06/26/understanding-rapid-rise-charismatic-christianity-southeast-asia" rel="nofollow">"Understanding the rapid rise of Charismatic Christianity in Southeast Asia"</a>. <li id="cite_note-auto10-330"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-auto10_330-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFNews">News, Morning Star. <a class="external text" href="https://www.christianitytoday.com/news/2013/may/christian-converts-in-morocco-fear-fatwa-calling-for-their.html" rel="nofollow">"Christian Converts in Morocco Fear Fatwa Calling for Their Execution"</a>. <i>News &amp; Reporting</i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=News+%26+Reporting&amp;rft.atitle=Christian+Converts+in+Morocco+Fear+Fatwa+Calling+for+Their+Execution&amp;rft.aulast=News&amp;rft.aufirst=Morning+Star&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.christianitytoday.com%2Fnews%2F2013%2Fmay%2Fchristian-converts-in-morocco-fear-fatwa-calling-for-their.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span> <span class="cs1-visible-error citation-comment"><code class="cs1-code">{{<a href="/wiki/Template:Cite_web" title="Template:Cite web">cite web</a>}}</code>: </span><span class="cs1-visible-error citation-comment"><code class="cs1-code">|last=</code> has generic name (<a href="/wiki/Help:CS1_errors#generic_name" title="Help:CS1 errors">help</a>)</span></span>

<li id="cite_note-367"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-367">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Sydney_E._Ahlstrom" title="Sydney E. Ahlstrom">Sydney E. Ahlstrom</a>, characterized <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Denominationalism" title="Denominationalism">denominationalism</a> in America as "a virtual ecclesiology" that "first of all repudiates the insistences of the Catholic Church, the churches of the 'magisterial' Reformation, and of most sects that they alone are the true Church." (<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAhlstromHall2004">Ahlstrom, Sydney E.; Hall, David D. Yale University Press. p. 381. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-300-10012-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-300-10012-9"><bdi>978-0-300-10012-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Religious+History+of+the+American+People&amp;rft.pages=381&amp;rft.edition=Revised&amp;rft.pub=Yale+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-300-10012-9&amp;rft.aulast=Ahlstrom&amp;rft.aufirst=Sydney+E.&amp;rft.au=Hall%2C+David+D.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D5kFF6a1viGcC%26pg%3DPA381&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span>);
<ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1">Nash, Donald A. <a class="external text" href="https://www.webcitation.org/5n7kJH3Yf?url=https://www.crownhillchurch.com/Why_the_Churches_of_Christ_Are_Not_A_Denomination.pdf" rel="nofollow"><i>Why the Churches of Christ are Not a Denomination</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. pp. 1–3. <li id="cite_note-398"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-398">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFPeter2018">Peter, Laurence (17 October 2018). <a class="external text" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-45877584" rel="nofollow">"Orthodox Church split: Five reasons why it matters"</a>. <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a>. <q>The Moscow-based Russian Orthodox Church has at least 150 million followers – more than half the total of Orthodox Christians. ... </li>
<li id="cite_note-402"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-402">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLamport2018">Lamport, Mark A. (2018). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=B6xVDwAAQBAJ&amp;q=oriental+orthodox+50+million&amp;pg=PA601" rel="nofollow"><i>Encyclopedia of Christianity in the Global South</i></a>. Rowman &amp; Littlefield. p. 601. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4422-7157-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4422-7157-9"><bdi>978-1-4422-7157-9</bdi></a>. <q>Today these churches are also referred to as the Oriental Orthodox Churches and are made up of 50 million Christians.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+Christianity+in+the+Global+South&amp;rft.pages=601&amp;rft.pub=Rowman+%26+Littlefield&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4422-7157-9&amp;rft.aulast=Lamport&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark+A.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DB6xVDwAAQBAJ%26q%3Doriental%2Borthodox%2B50%2Bmillion%26pg%3DPA601&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-403"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-403">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.pewforum.org/2017/11/08/orthodox-christianity-in-the-21st-century/" rel="nofollow">"Orthodox Christianity in the 21st Century"</a>. <i>Pew Research Center's Religion &amp; Public Life Project</i>. 8 November 2017. <q>Oriental Orthodoxy has separate self-governing jurisdictions in Ethiopia, Egypt, Eritrea, India, Armenia and Syria, and it accounts for roughly 20% of the worldwide Orthodox population.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Pew+Research+Center%27s+Religion+%26+Public+Life+Project&amp;rft.atitle=Orthodox+Christianity+in+the+21st+Century&amp;rft.date=2017-11-08&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.pewforum.org%2F2017%2F11%2F08%2Forthodox-christianity-in-the-21st-century%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-404"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-404">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.oikoumene.org/en/church-families/orthodox-churches-oriental" rel="nofollow">"Orthodox churches (Oriental) — World Council of Churches"</a>. <i>www.oikoumene.org</i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.oikoumene.org&amp;rft.atitle=Orthodox+churches+%28Oriental%29+%E2%80%94+World+Council+of+Churches&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.oikoumene.org%2Fen%2Fchurch-families%2Forthodox-churches-oriental&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-405"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-405">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBetts1978">Betts, Robert B. </li>
<li id="cite_note-406"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-406">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMeyendorff1989"><a href="/wiki/John_Meyendorff" title="John Meyendorff">Meyendorff, John</a> (1989). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=6J_YAAAAMAAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Imperial unity and Christian divisions: The Church 450-680 A.D.</i></a> The Church in history. </li>
<li id="cite_note-407"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-407">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHindsonMitchell2013">Hindson, Ed; Mitchell, Dan (2013). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=4eE2LdSKiQwC" rel="nofollow"><i>The Popular Encyclopedia of Church History</i></a>. Harvest House Publishers. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7369-4806-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7369-4806-7"><bdi>978-0-7369-4806-7</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Popular+Encyclopedia+of+Church+History&amp;rft.pub=Harvest+House+Publishers&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7369-4806-7&amp;rft.aulast=Hindson&amp;rft.aufirst=Ed&amp;rft.au=Mitchell%2C+Dan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D4eE2LdSKiQwC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-408"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-408">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAppiahGates2005">Appiah, Anthony; Gates, Henry Louis (2005). <i>Africana: The Encyclopedia of the African and African American Experience</i>. Oxford University Press. p. 566. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-517055-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-517055-9"><bdi>978-0-19-517055-9</bdi></a>. <q>It emphasizes the dietary laws and rules of circumcision found in the Old Testament of the Bible, and in addition to the Christian Sunday Sabbath, Ethiopia Christians observe the traditional Jewish Saturday Sabbath, as do the Ethiopian Jews.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Africana%3A+The+Encyclopedia+of+the+African+and+African+American+Experience&amp;rft.pages=566&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-517055-9&amp;rft.aulast=Appiah&amp;rft.aufirst=Anthony&amp;rft.au=Gates%2C+Henry+Louis&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-409"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-409">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFN._Stearns2008">N. Stearns, Peter (2008). <i>The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Modern World</i>. <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. p. 179. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780195176322" title="Special:BookSources/9780195176322"><bdi>9780195176322</bdi></a>. <q>Uniformly practiced by Jews, Muslims, and the members of Coptic, Ethiopian, and Eritrean Orthodox Churches, male circumcision remains prevalent in many regions of the world, particularly Africa, South and East Asia, Oceania, and Anglosphere countries.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+Encyclopedia+of+the+Modern+World&amp;rft.pages=179&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=9780195176322&amp;rft.aulast=N.+Stearns&amp;rft.aufirst=Peter&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-410"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-410">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFIan_Bradley2012"><a href="/wiki/Ian_Bradley" title="Ian Bradley">Ian Bradley</a> (2 November 2012). <i>Water: A Spiritual History</i>. <a href="/wiki/Bloomsbury_Publishing" title="Bloomsbury Publishing">Bloomsbury Publishing</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4411-6767-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4411-6767-5"><bdi>978-1-4411-6767-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Water%3A+A+Spiritual+History&amp;rft.pub=Bloomsbury+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2012-11-02&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4411-6767-5&amp;rft.au=Ian+Bradley&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-411"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-411">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFH._Bulzacchelli2006">H. Bulzacchelli, Richard (2006). <i>Judged by the Law of Freedom: A History of the Faith-works Controversy, and a Resolution in the Thought of St. Thomas Aquinas</i>. <a href="/wiki/University_Press_of_America" title="University Press of America">University Press of America</a>. p. 19. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780761835011" title="Special:BookSources/9780761835011"><bdi>9780761835011</bdi></a>. <q>The Ethiopian and Coptic Churches distinguishes between clean and unclean meats, observes days of ritual purification, and keeps a kind of dual Sabbath on both Saturday and Sunday.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Judged+by+the+Law+of+Freedom%3A+A+History+of+the+Faith-works+Controversy%2C+and+a+Resolution+in+the+Thought+of+St.+Thomas+Aquinas&amp;rft.pages=19&amp;rft.pub=University+Press+of+America&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=9780761835011&amp;rft.aulast=H.+Bulzacchelli&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-412"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-412">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBaumer2006">Baumer, Christoph (2006). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=SQ7ZAAAAMAAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>The Church of the East: An Illustrated History of Assyrian Christianity</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-413"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-413">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFEduardo_Campo2009">Eduardo Campo, Juan (2009). <i>Encyclopedia of Islam</i>. <li id="cite_note-414"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-414">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHunter2014">Hunter, Erica C.D. <li id="cite_note-blackwell1-416"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-blackwell1_416-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-blackwell1_416-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFParryMellingBradyGriffith2017">Parry, Ken; Melling, David J.; Brady, Dimitri; Griffith, Sidney H.; Healey, John F., eds. Oxford, UK: Blackwell Publishing Ltd. pp. 122–3. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1002%2F9781405166584" rel="nofollow">10.1002/9781405166584</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4051-6658-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4051-6658-4"><bdi>978-1-4051-6658-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Church+of+the+East&amp;rft.btitle=The+Blackwell+Dictionary+of+Eastern+Christianity&amp;rft.place=Oxford%2C+UK&amp;rft.pages=122-3&amp;rft.pub=Blackwell+Publishing+Ltd&amp;rft.date=2017-09-01&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1002%2F9781405166584&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4051-6658-4&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdoi.wiley.com%2F10.1002%2F9781405166584&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-ENC3-417"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ENC3_417-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Fahlbusch, Erwin, and Bromiley, Geoffrey William, <i>The Encyclopedia of Christianity, Volume 3</i>. Grand Rapids, Michigan: Eerdmans, 2003. p. 362.</span>

<li id="cite_note-McManners251-418"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-McManners251_418-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">McManners, <i>Oxford Illustrated History of Christianity</i>. pp. 251–259.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Karl-Heussi_1956_pp._317–319-419"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Karl-Heussi_1956_pp._317–319_419-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Karl Heussi, <i>Kompendium der Kirchengeschichte</i>, 11. Auflage (1956), Tübingen (Germany), pp. 317–319, 325–326</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-420"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-420">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFE._Marty2022">E. Marty, Martin (13 August 2022). <a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/The-Protestant-Heritage-1354359/Protestantisms-influence-in-the-modern-world" rel="nofollow">"Protestantism's influence in the modern world"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Protestantism%E2%80%99s+influence+in+the+modern+world&amp;rft.pub=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.date=2022-08-13&amp;rft.aulast=E.+Marty&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Ftopic%2FThe-Protestant-Heritage-1354359%2FProtestantisms-influence-in-the-modern-world&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-421"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-421">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sykes/Booty/Knight. <i>The Study of Anglicanism</i>, p. 219. Some Anglicans consider their church a <a href="/wiki/Branch_theory" title="Branch theory">branch of the "One Holy Catholic Church"</a> alongside of the Catholic, Scandinavian Lutheran and Eastern Orthodox churches, a concept rejected by the Catholic Church, some Eastern Orthodox, and many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evangelical_Anglican" title="Evangelical Anglican">evangelical Anglicans</a> themselves, for more on this, see Gregory Hallam, <i><a class="external text" href="https://www.orthodoxresearchinstitute.org/articles/ecumenical/hallam_orthodoxy_ecumenism.htm" rel="nofollow">Orthodoxy and Ecumenism</a></i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-422"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-422">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Gregory Mathewes-Green, "<a class="external text" href="https://www.westernorthodox.com/branch.html" rel="nofollow">Whither the Branch Theory?</a>", <i>Anglican Orthodox Pilgrim</i> Vol. 2, No. 4. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120519104645/https://www.westernorthodox.com/branch.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 19 May 2012 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-BenedettoDuke2008-424"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-BenedettoDuke2008_424-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBenedettoDuke2008">Benedetto, Robert; Duke, James O. (2008). <i>The New Westminster Dictionary of Church History</i>. Westminster John Knox Press. p. 22. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-664-22416-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-664-22416-5"><bdi>978-0-664-22416-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+New+Westminster+Dictionary+of+Church+History&amp;rft.pages=22&amp;rft.pub=Westminster+John+Knox+Press&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-664-22416-5&amp;rft.aulast=Benedetto&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.au=Duke%2C+James+O.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
