<li id="cite_note-Littell2000-425"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Littell2000_425-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLittell2000">Littell, Franklin H. (2000). <i>The Anabaptist View of the Church</i>. The Baptist Standard Bearer, Inc. p. 79. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-57978-836-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-57978-836-0"><bdi>978-1-57978-836-0</bdi></a>. <q>In reviewing the records, the reader is struck with the Anabaptists' acute consciousness of separation from the "fallen" church—in which they included the Reformers as well as the Roman institution. Some writers have therefore concluded that Anabaptism is not merely a variant form of Protestantism, but rather an ideology and practice quite different in kind from those of both Rome and the Reformers.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Anabaptist+View+of+the+Church&amp;rft.pages=79&amp;rft.pub=The+Baptist+Standard+Bearer%2C+Inc.&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-57978-836-0&amp;rft.aulast=Littell&amp;rft.aufirst=Franklin+H.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-426"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-426">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://mennoniteusa.org/who-we-are/" rel="nofollow">"Who We Are: A Quick Visual Guide"</a>. Mennonite Church US. 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">26 April</span> 2018</span>. <q>Anabaptists: We are neither Catholic nor Protestant, but we share ties to those streams of Christianity. We cooperate as a sign of our unity in Christ and in ways that extend the reign of God's Kingdom on earth.  We are known as "Anabaptists" (not anti-Baptist)—meaning "rebaptizers."</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Who+We+Are%3A+A+Quick+Visual+Guide&amp;rft.pub=Mennonite+Church+US&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fmennoniteusa.org%2Fwho-we-are%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Warren_Wilson_College—Total_Experience_of_the_Spirit-432"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Warren_Wilson_College—Total_Experience_of_the_Spirit_432-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20060903030820/https://www.warren-wilson.edu/~religion/newifo/religions/christianity/index/pentecostal/essay.shtml" rel="nofollow">"Total Experience of the Spirit"</a>. <li id="cite_note-433"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-433">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFClarkeBeyer2009">Clarke, Peter B.; Beyer, Peter (2009). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=rBgn3xB75ZcC&amp;q=protestantism+750+million&amp;pg=PA510" rel="nofollow"><i>The World's Religions: Continuities and Transformations</i></a>. Taylor &amp; Francis. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-135-21100-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-135-21100-4"><bdi>978-1-135-21100-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+World%27s+Religions%3A+Continuities+and+Transformations&amp;rft.pub=Taylor+%26+Francis&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-135-21100-4&amp;rft.aulast=Clarke&amp;rft.aufirst=Peter+B.&amp;rft.au=Beyer%2C+Peter&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DrBgn3xB75ZcC%26q%3Dprotestantism%2B750%2Bmillion%26pg%3DPA510&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-434"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-434">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFNoll2011">Noll, Mark A. (2011). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=1GKBgK00JSsC&amp;q=protestantism+million&amp;pg=PA9" rel="nofollow"><i>Protestantism: A Very Short Introduction</i></a>. OUP Oxford. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-162013-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-162013-3"><bdi>978-0-19-162013-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Protestantism%3A+A+Very+Short+Introduction&amp;rft.pub=OUP+Oxford&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-162013-3&amp;rft.aulast=Noll&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark+A.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D1GKBgK00JSsC%26q%3Dprotestantism%2Bmillion%26pg%3DPA9&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-435"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-435">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This branch was first called Calvinism by Lutherans who opposed it, and many within the tradition would prefer to use the word <i>Reformed</i>. It includes <a href="/wiki/Presbyterianism" title="Presbyterianism">Presbyterians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Congregational_church" title="Congregational church">Congregationalists</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-436"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-436">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.oikoumene.org/en/church-families/evangelical-churches" rel="nofollow">World Council of Churches: Evangelical churches</a>: "Evangelical churches have grown exponentially in the second half of the 20th century and continue to show great vitality, especially in the global South. This resurgence may in part be explained by the phenomenal growth of Pentecostalism and the emergence of the charismatic movement, which are closely associated with evangelicalism. However, there can be no doubt that the evangelical tradition "per se" has become one of the major components of world Christianity. Evangelicals also constitute sizable minorities in the traditional Protestant and Anglican churches. In regions like Africa and Latin America, the boundaries between "evangelical" and "mainline" are rapidly changing and giving way to new ecclesial realities."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-ReferenceA-437"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ReferenceA_437-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ReferenceA_437-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Confessionalism is a term employed by historians to refer to "the creation of fixed identities and systems of beliefs for separate churches which had previously been more fluid in their self-understanding, and which had not begun by seeking separate identities for themselves—they had wanted to be truly Catholic and reformed." (MacCulloch, <i>The Reformation: A History</i>, p. xxiv.)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Pew_Forum_on_Religion_&amp;_Public_Life_/_U.S._Religious_Landscape_Survey-438"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Pew_Forum_on_Religion_&amp;_Public_Life_/_U.S._Religious_Landscape_Survey_438-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://religions.pewforum.org/pdf/report2religious-landscape-study-appendix3.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Classification of Protestant Denominations"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. Pew Forum on Religion &amp; Public Life / U.S. Religious Landscape Survey<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">27 September</span> 2009</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Classification+of+Protestant+Denominations&amp;rft.pub=Pew+Forum+on+Religion+%26+Public+Life+%2F+U.S.+Religious+Landscape+Survey&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Freligions.pewforum.org%2Fpdf%2Freport2religious-landscape-study-appendix3.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-439"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-439">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">McManners, <i>Oxford Illustrated History of Christianity</i>, pp. 91ff.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Religious_Tolerance—Restorationism-440"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Religious_Tolerance—Restorationism_440-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.religioustolerance.org/chrrest.htm" rel="nofollow">"The Restorationist Movements"</a>. Religious Tolerance<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 December</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+Restorationist+Movements&amp;rft.pub=Religious+Tolerance&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.religioustolerance.org%2Fchrrest.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-444"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-444">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>Manuscript History of the Church</i>, LDS Church Archives, book A-1, p. 37; reproduced in <a href="/wiki/Dean_C._Jessee" title="Dean C. <li id="cite_note-445"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-445">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">J. Gordon Melton, <i>Encyclopedia of Protestantism</i>, 2005, p. 543: "Unitarianism – The word <i>unitarian</i> [italics] means one who believes in the oneness of God; historically it refers to those in the Christian community who rejected the doctrine of the Trinity (one God expressed in three persons). Non-Trinitarian Protestant churches emerged in the 16th century in ITALY, POLAND, and TRANSYLVANIA."</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Fahlbusch2008-450"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Fahlbusch2008_450-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFahlbusch2008">Fahlbusch, Erwin (2008). <i>The Encyclodedia of Christianity</i>. <li id="cite_note-FlemingRowan2004-451"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FlemingRowan2004_451-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFlemingRowanChambers2004">Fleming, John A.; Rowan, Michael J.; Chambers, James Albert (2004). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/folkfurnitureofc00flem/page/4" rel="nofollow"><i>Folk Furniture of Canada's Doukhobors, Hutterites, Mennonites and Ukrainians</i></a>. University of Alberta. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/folkfurnitureofc00flem/page/4" rel="nofollow">4</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-88864-418-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-88864-418-3"><bdi>978-0-88864-418-3</bdi></a>. <q>The English Quakers, who had made contact with the Doukhobors earlier, as well as the Philadelphia Society of Friends, also determined to help with their emigration from Russia to some other country—the only action which seemed possible.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Folk+Furniture+of+Canada%27s+Doukhobors%2C+Hutterites%2C+Mennonites+and+Ukrainians&amp;rft.pages=4&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Alberta&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-88864-418-3&amp;rft.aulast=Fleming&amp;rft.aufirst=John+A.&amp;rft.au=Rowan%2C+Michael+J.&amp;rft.au=Chambers%2C+James+Albert&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Ffolkfurnitureofc00flem%2Fpage%2F4&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Ariel2006p208-452"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Ariel2006p208_452-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAriel2006">Ariel, Yaakov (2006). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=oZiScvbS6-cC&amp;pg=RA1-PA208" rel="nofollow">"Judaism and Christianity Unite! The Unique Culture of Messianic Judaism"</a>.  In Gallagher, Eugene V.; Ashcraft, W. Michael (eds.). <i>Jewish and Christian Traditions</i>. Introduction to New and Alternative Religions in America. Vol. 2. Westport, CN: <a href="/wiki/Greenwood_Publishing_Group" title="Greenwood Publishing Group">Greenwood Publishing Group</a>. p. 208. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-275-98714-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-275-98714-5"><bdi>978-0-275-98714-5</bdi></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LCCN_(identifier)" title="LCCN (identifier)">LCCN</a> <a class="external text" href="//lccn.loc.gov/2006022954" rel="nofollow">2006022954</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/315689134" rel="nofollow">315689134</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">9 September</span> 2015</span>. <q>For example, Messianic Jews, without exception, believe that the way to eternal life is through the acceptance of Jesus as one's personal savior and that no obedience to the Jewish law or "works" is necessary in order to obtain that goal....Remarkably, it has been exactly this adherence to the basic Christian evangelical faith that has allowed Messianic Jews to adopt and promote Jewish rites and customs. They are Christians in good standing and can retain whatever cultural attributes and rites they choose.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Judaism+and+Christianity+Unite%21+The+Unique+Culture+of+Messianic+Judaism&amp;rft.btitle=Jewish+and+Christian+Traditions&amp;rft.place=Westport%2C+CN&amp;rft.series=Introduction+to+New+and+Alternative+Religions+in+America&amp;rft.pages=208&amp;rft.pub=Greenwood+Publishing+Group&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F315689134&amp;rft_id=info%3Alccn%2F2006022954&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-275-98714-5&amp;rft.aulast=Ariel&amp;rft.aufirst=Yaakov&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DoZiScvbS6-cC%26pg%3DRA1-PA208&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-453"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-453">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMeltonBaumann2010">Melton, J. <li id="cite_note-Besant_2001-455"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Besant_2001_455-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBesant2001">Besant, Annie (2001). <i>Esoteric Christianity or the Lesser Mysteries</i>. City: Adamant Media Corporation. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4021-0029-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4021-0029-1"><bdi>978-1-4021-0029-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Esoteric+Christianity+or+the+Lesser+Mysteries&amp;rft.place=City&amp;rft.pub=Adamant+Media+Corporation&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4021-0029-1&amp;rft.aulast=Besant&amp;rft.aufirst=Annie&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-456"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-456">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">From the Greek ἐσωτερικός (esôterikos, "inner"). The term <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Esotericism" title="Esotericism">esotericism</a> itself was coined in the 17th century. (Oxford English Dictionary Compact Edition, Volume 1, Oxford University Press, 1971, p. 894.)</span>

<li id="cite_note-459"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-459">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080907075009/https://www.webster.com/dictionary/esoteric" rel="nofollow">"Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary: esoteric"</a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-Hughes1997-460"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Hughes1997_460-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Hughes1997_460-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Hughes1997_460-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><i>The Journal of American History</i>. <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. 1997. p. 1400. <q>Richard T. Hughes, professor of religion at Pepperdine University, argues that the Churches of Christ built a corporate identity around "restoration" of the primitive church and the corresponding belief that their congregations represented a nondenominational Christianity.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Journal+of+American+History&amp;rft.pages=1400&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Barnett2020-461"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Barnett2020_461-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Barnett2020_461-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFBarnett2020">Barnett, Joe R. (2020). <a class="external text" href="https://www.southsidehopkinsville.com/who-are-the-churches-of-christ/" rel="nofollow">"Who are the Churches of Christ"</a>. Southside Church of Christ<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">7 December</span> 2020</span>. <q>Not A Denomination: For this reason, we are not interested in man-made creeds, but simply in the New Testament pattern. We do not conceive of ourselves as being a denomination–nor as Catholic, Protestant, or Jewish—but simply as members of the church which Jesus established and for which he died. And that, incidentally, is why we wear his name. The term "church of Christ" is not used as a denominational designation, but rather as a descriptive term indicating that the church belongs to Christ.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Who+are+the+Churches+of+Christ&amp;rft.pub=Southside+Church+of+Christ&amp;rft.date=2020&amp;rft.aulast=Barnett&amp;rft.aufirst=Joe+R.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.southsidehopkinsville.com%2Fwho-are-the-churches-of-christ%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Nash2020-463"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Nash2020_463-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFNash">Nash, Donald A. <a class="external text" href="https://www.thecra.org/files/WhyNotDenom.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Why the Churches of Christ Are Not A Denomination"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. The Christian Restoration Association<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">7 December</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Why+the+Churches+of+Christ+Are+Not+A+Denomination&amp;rft.pub=The+Christian+Restoration+Association&amp;rft.aulast=Nash&amp;rft.aufirst=Donald+A.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thecra.org%2Ffiles%2FWhyNotDenom.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-HughesRoberts2001-464"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-HughesRoberts2001_464-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHughesRoberts2001">Hughes, Richard Thomas; Roberts, R. L. (2001). <i>The Churches of Christ</i>. Greenwood Publishing Group. p. 63. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-313-23312-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-313-23312-8"><bdi>978-0-313-23312-8</bdi></a>. <q>Barton Stone was fully prepared to ally himself with Alexander Campbell in an effort to promote nondenominational Christianity, though it is evident that the two men came to this emphasis by very different routes.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Churches+of+Christ&amp;rft.pages=63&amp;rft.pub=Greenwood+Publishing+Group&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-313-23312-8&amp;rft.aulast=Hughes&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard+Thomas&amp;rft.au=Roberts%2C+R.+L.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Cherok2011-465"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cherok2011_465-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCherok2011">Cherok, Richard J. (14 June 2011). <i>Debating for God: Alexander Campbell's Challenge to Skepticism in Antebellum America</i>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ACU_Press" title="ACU Press">ACU Press</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-89112-838-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-89112-838-0"><bdi>978-0-89112-838-0</bdi></a>. <q>Later proponents of Campbell's views would refer to themselves as the "Restoration Movement" because of the Campbellian insistence on restoring Christianity to its New Testament form. ... Added to this mix were the concepts of American egalitarianism, which gave rise to his advocacy of nondenominational individualism and local church autonomy, and Christian primitivism, which led to his promotion of such early church practices as believer's baptism by immersion and the weekly partaking of the Lord's Supper.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Debating+for+God%3A+Alexander+Campbell%27s+Challenge+to+Skepticism+in+Antebellum+America&amp;rft.pub=ACU+Press&amp;rft.date=2011-06-14&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-89112-838-0&amp;rft.aulast=Cherok&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard+J.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Crisis_in_Western_Education-466"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Crisis_in_Western_Education_466-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Crisis_in_Western_Education_466-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDawsonOlsen1961">Dawson, Christopher; Olsen, Glenn (1961). <i>Crisis in Western Education</i> (reprint ed.). <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8132-1683-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8132-1683-6"><bdi>978-0-8132-1683-6</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Crisis+in+Western+Education&amp;rft.edition=reprint&amp;rft.date=1961&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8132-1683-6&amp;rft.aulast=Dawson&amp;rft.aufirst=Christopher&amp;rft.au=Olsen%2C+Glenn&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-482"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-482">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCohen1994"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H._Floris_Cohen" title="H. <li id="cite_note-483"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-483">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFerngren2002"><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Gary_B._Ferngren&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gary B. <li id="cite_note-A._Spinello-506"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-A._Spinello_506-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFA._Spinello2012">A. Spinello, Richard (2012). <i>The Encyclicals of John Paul II: An Introduction and Commentary</i>. Rowman &amp; Littlefield Publishers. p. 147. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4422-1942-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4422-1942-7"><bdi>978-1-4422-1942-7</bdi></a>. <q>... The insights of Christian philosophy "would not have happened without the direct or indirect contribution of Christian faith" (FR 76). Typical Christian philosophers include St. Augustine, St. Bonaventure, and St. Thomas Aquinas. The benefits derived from Christian philosophy are twofold....</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Encyclicals+of+John+Paul+II%3A+An+Introduction+and+Commentary&amp;rft.pages=147&amp;rft.pub=Rowman+%26+Littlefield+Publishers&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4422-1942-7&amp;rft.aulast=A.+Spinello&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Gilley-507"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Gilley_507-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGilleyStanley2006">Gilley, Sheridan; Stanley, Brian (2006). <i>The Cambridge History of Christianity: Volume 8, World Christianities C.1815-c.1914</i>. Cambridge University Press. p. 164. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-521-81456-1" title="Special:BookSources/0-521-81456-1"><bdi>0-521-81456-1</bdi></a>. <q>... Many of the scientists who contributed to these developments were Christians...</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Cambridge+History+of+Christianity%3A+Volume+8%2C+World+Christianities+C.1815-c.1914&amp;rft.pages=164&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=0-521-81456-1&amp;rft.aulast=Gilley&amp;rft.aufirst=Sheridan&amp;rft.au=Stanley%2C+Brian&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Steane-508"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Steane_508-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSteane2014">Steane, Andrew (2014). <i>Faithful to Science: The Role of Science in Religion</i>. OUP Oxford. p. 179. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-102513-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-102513-6"><bdi>978-0-19-102513-6</bdi></a>. <q>... the Christian contribution to science has been uniformly at the top level, but it has reached that level and it has been sufficiently strong overall ...</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Faithful+to+Science%3A+The+Role+of+Science+in+Religion&amp;rft.pages=179&amp;rft.pub=OUP+Oxford&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-102513-6&amp;rft.aulast=Steane&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-509"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-509">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFGraves1998">Graves, Daniel (7 July 1998). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150924084347/https://www.rae.org/influsci.html" rel="nofollow">"Christian Influences in the Sciences"</a>. <i>rae.org</i>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://www.rae.org/influsci.html" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 24 September 2015.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=rae.org&amp;rft.atitle=Christian+Influences+in+the+Sciences&amp;rft.date=1998-07-07&amp;rft.aulast=Graves&amp;rft.aufirst=Daniel&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.rae.org%2Finflusci.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-510"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-510">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190617072212/https://www.adherents.com/people/100_Nobel.html" rel="nofollow">"50 Nobel Laureates and Other Great Scientists Who Believe in God"</a>. Archived from the original on 17 June 2019.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=50+Nobel+Laureates+and+Other+Great+Scientists+Who+Believe+in+God&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.adherents.com%2Fpeople%2F100_Nobel.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span><span class="cs1-maint citation-comment"><code class="cs1-code">{{<a href="/wiki/Template:Cite_web" title="Template:Cite web">cite web</a>}}</code>:  CS1 maint: unfit URL (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_unfit_URL" title="Category:CS1 maint: unfit URL">link</a>)</span> Many well-known historical figures who influenced Western science considered themselves Christian such as <a href="/wiki/Nicolaus_Copernicus" title="Nicolaus Copernicus">Nicolaus Copernicus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galileo_Galilei" title="Galileo Galilei">Galileo Galilei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Kepler" title="Johannes Kepler">Johannes Kepler</a>, <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Newton" title="Isaac Newton">Isaac Newton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Boyle" title="Robert Boyle">Robert Boyle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alessandro_Volta" title="Alessandro Volta">Alessandro Volta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Faraday" title="Michael Faraday">Michael Faraday</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Thomson,_1st_Baron_Kelvin" title="William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin">William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin</a> and <a href="/wiki/James_Clerk_Maxwell" title="James Clerk Maxwell">James Clerk Maxwell</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-S._Kroger-511"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-S._Kroger_511-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFS._Kroger2016">S. Kroger, William (2016). <i>Clinical and Experimental Hypnosis in Medicine, Dentistry and Psychology</i>. <li id="cite_note-Nobel_Prize-515"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Nobel_Prize_515-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Baruch A. (1983). <i>Classical Readings in Christian Apologetics</i>. Grand Rapids: Zondervan. p. 275. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-310-45641-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-310-45641-4"><bdi>978-0-310-45641-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Classical+Readings+in+Christian+Apologetics&amp;rft.place=Grand+Rapids&amp;rft.pages=275&amp;rft.pub=Zondervan&amp;rft.date=1983&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-310-45641-4&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-556"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-556">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.chesterton.org/why-i-believe-in-christianity/" rel="nofollow">"Why I Believe in Christianity – Society of Gilbert Keith Chesterton"</a>. 6 December 2010.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Why+I+Believe+in+Christianity+%E2%80%93+Society+of+Gilbert+Keith+Chesterton&amp;rft.date=2010-12-06&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.chesterton.org%2Fwhy-i-believe-in-christianity%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-557"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-557">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHauser,_Chris_(History_major,_Dartmouth_College_class_of_2014)2011">Hauser, Chris (History major, Dartmouth College class of 2014) (Fall 2011). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150714080437/http://issuu.com/apologia/docs/apol11sv25" rel="nofollow">"Faith and Paradox: G.K. Chesterton's Philosophy of Christian Paradox"</a>. <i><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Dartmouth_College_Publications&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Dartmouth College Publications (page does not exist)">The Dartmouth Apologia: A Journal of Christian Thought</a></i>. <b>6</b> (1): 16–20. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://issuu.com/apologia/docs/apol11sv25" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 14 July 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">29 March</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Dartmouth+Apologia%3A+A+Journal+of+Christian+Thought&amp;rft.atitle=Faith+and+Paradox%3A+G.K.+Chesterton%27s+Philosophy+of+Christian+Paradox&amp;rft.ssn=fall&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=16-20&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.au=Hauser%2C+Chris+%28History+major%2C+Dartmouth+College+class+of+2014%29&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fissuu.com%2Fapologia%2Fdocs%2Fapol11sv25&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span><span class="cs1-maint citation-comment"><code class="cs1-code">{{<a href="/wiki/Template:Cite_journal" title="Template:Cite journal">cite journal</a>}}</code>:  CS1 maint: multiple names: authors list (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_multiple_names:_authors_list" title="Category:CS1 maint: multiple names: authors list">link</a>)</span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-chesterton.org-558"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-chesterton.org_558-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.chesterton.org/why-i-believe-in-christianity/" rel="nofollow">"Christianity"</a>. 6 December 2010.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Christianity&amp;rft.date=2010-12-06&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.chesterton.org%2Fwhy-i-believe-in-christianity%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Howson2011-559"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Howson2011_559-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHowson2011">Howson, Colin (2011). <span class="cs1-lock-limited" title="Free access subject to limited trial, subscription normally required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/objectingtogod00hows" rel="nofollow"><i>Objecting to God</i></a></span>. Cambridge University Press. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/objectingtogod00hows/page/n104" rel="nofollow">92</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-139-49856-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-139-49856-2"><bdi>978-1-139-49856-2</bdi></a>. <q>Nor is the agreement coincidental, according to a substantial constituency of religious apologists, who regard the inflationary Big Bang model as direct evidence for God. John Lennox, a mathematician at the University of Oxford, tells us that 'even if the non-believers don't like it, the Big Bang fits in exactly with the Christian narrative of creation'. ... William Lane Craig is another who claims that the Biblical account is corroborated by Big Bang cosmology. Lane Craig also claims that there is a prior <i>proof</i> that there is a God who created this universe.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Objecting+to+God&amp;rft.pages=92&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-139-49856-2&amp;rft.aulast=Howson&amp;rft.aufirst=Colin&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fobjectingtogod00hows&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

Toronto, Ont.: Musson Book Co. <i>N.B</i>.: The series statement is given in the more extended form which appears on the book's front cover.</li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1">Robinson, George (2000). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/essentialjudaism00robi" rel="nofollow"><i>Essential Judaism: A Complete Guide to Beliefs, Customs and Rituals</i></a></span>. New York: Pocket Books. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-671-03481-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-671-03481-8"><bdi>978-0-671-03481-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Essential+Judaism%3A+A+Complete+Guide+to+Beliefs%2C+Customs+and+Rituals&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Pocket+Books&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-671-03481-8&amp;rft.aulast=Robinson&amp;rft.aufirst=George&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fessentialjudaism00robi&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFRüegg,_Walter1992">Rüegg, Walter (1992). <i>"Foreword. The University as a European Institution," in: A History of the University in Europe. Vol. 1, Universities in the Middle Ages</i>. Cambridge University Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-521-36105-2" title="Special:BookSources/0-521-36105-2"><bdi>0-521-36105-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=%22Foreword.+The+University+as+a+European+Institution%2C%22+in%3A+A+History+of+the+University+in+Europe.+Vol.+1%2C+Universities+in+the+Middle+Ages&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1992&amp;rft.isbn=0-521-36105-2&amp;rft.au=R%C3%BCegg%2C+Walter&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFTucker,_KarenWainwright,_Geoffrey2006">Tucker, Karen; Wainwright, Geoffrey (2006). <i>The Oxford history of Christian worship</i>. Oxford [Oxfordshire]: Oxford University Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-513886-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-513886-3"><bdi>978-0-19-513886-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+history+of+Christian+worship&amp;rft.place=Oxford+%5BOxfordshire%5D&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-513886-3&amp;rft.au=Tucker%2C+Karen&amp;rft.au=Wainwright%2C+Geoffrey&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFVerger,_Jacques1999">Verger, Jacques (1999). <a class="external text" href="https://openlibrary.org/works/OL822497W" rel="nofollow"><i>Culture, enseignement et société en Occident aux XIIe et XIIIe siècles</i></a> (1st ed.). Presses universitaires de Rennes in Rennes. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-2-86847-344-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-2-86847-344-8"><bdi>978-2-86847-344-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Culture%2C+enseignement+et+soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9+en+Occident+aux+XIIe+et+XIIIe+si%C3%A8cles&amp;rft.edition=1st&amp;rft.pub=Presses+universitaires+de+Rennes+in+Rennes&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft.isbn=978-2-86847-344-8&amp;rft.au=Verger%2C+Jacques&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fopenlibrary.org%2Fworks%2FOL822497W&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFWagner,_Richard2004">Wagner, Richard (2004). <i>Christianity for Dummies</i>. For Dummies. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7645-4482-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7645-4482-8"><bdi>978-0-7645-4482-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Christianity+for+Dummies&amp;rft.pub=For+Dummies&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7645-4482-8&amp;rft.au=Wagner%2C+Richard&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li>

(2004). <i>The Complete Idiot's Guide to Christianity</i>. Indianapolis, Ind: Alpha Books. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-59257-176-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-59257-176-5"><bdi>978-1-59257-176-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Complete+Idiot%27s+Guide+to+Christianity&amp;rft.place=Indianapolis%2C+Ind&amp;rft.pub=Alpha+Books&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-59257-176-5&amp;rft.au=Webb%2C+Jeffrey+B.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChristianity"></span></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Garry_Wills" title="Garry Wills">Wills, Garry</a>, "A Wild and Indecent Book" (review of <a href="/wiki/David_Bentley_Hart" title="David Bentley Hart">David Bentley Hart</a>, <i>The New Testament:  A Translation</i>, Yale University Press, 577 pp.), <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Review_of_Books" title="The New York Review of Books">The New York Review of Books</a></i>, vol. LXV, no. 2 (8 February 2018), pp. 34–35.  Discusses some pitfalls in interpreting and translating the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>.</li></ul>

class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Patriarchates_in_Christianity" title="Template:Patriarchates in Christianity"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Patriarchates_in_Christianity" title="Template talk:Patriarchates in Christianity"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Patriarchates_in_Christianity&amp;action=edit"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Patriarchates_in_Christianity" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Patriarchate" title="Patriarchate">Patriarchates</a> in <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Christianity</a></div></th></tr><tr><td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2"><div id="Traditional_ecclesiastical_jurisdictions_of_primates_in_Christianity,_sorted_according_to_earliest_apostolic_legacy_and_branched_where_multiple_denominational_claimants:_bold_blue_=_Catholic_Church,_light_blue_=_Eastern_Orthodox_Church,_bold/light_green_=_Oriental_Orthodoxy,_italic_blue_=_Nestorianism">Traditional ecclesiastical jurisdictions of <a href="/wiki/Primate_(bishop)" title="Primate (bishop)">primates</a> in <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Christianity</a>, sorted according to earliest <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_succession" title="Apostolic succession">apostolic</a> legacy and branched where multiple denominational claimants:<br/>
<b>bold blue</b> = <b><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a></b>, <span style="color:#000040;">light blue</span> = <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>, <span style="color:#808000;"><b>bold/</b>light green</span> = <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodoxy" title="Oriental Orthodoxy"><span style="color:#808000;">Oriental Orthodoxy</span></a>, <i>italic blue = <a href="/wiki/Nestorianism" title="Nestorianism">Nestorianism</a></i></div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" title="Early Christianity">Early<br/>Christianity</a><br/>(<a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_late_antiquity" title="Christianity in late antiquity">Antiquity</a>)<br/><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047488">.mw-parser-output .nobold{font-weight:normal}</style><span class="nobold">(30–325/476)</span></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Pentarchy" title="Pentarchy">Pentarchy</a><br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(five<br/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apostolic_See" title="Apostolic See">apostolic<br/>sees</a>)</span></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Patriarch</a> of <a style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><b><a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a></b>  (since <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_1st_century" title="Christianity in the 1st century">1st cent.</a>)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarch_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople">Patriarch</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarchate_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople">Constantinople</a> <br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(<a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon" title="Council of Chalcedon">451</a>)</span></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Patriarch_of_Antioch" title="Patriarch of Antioch">Patriarch</a> of <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Antioch" title="Church of Antioch">Antioch</a> <br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(<a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_1st_century" title="Christianity in the 1st century">1st cent.</a>)</span></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Other</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_patriarchs,_archbishops_and_bishops_of_Carthage" title="List of patriarchs, archbishops and bishops of Carthage">Patriarch</a> of <a href="/wiki/Archdiocese_of_Carthage" title="Archdiocese of Carthage">Carthage</a> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_2nd_century" title="Christianity in the 2nd century">2nd cent.</a>–1076)</span></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

<ul><li><b><a href="/wiki/Patriarchate_of_Aquileia" title="Patriarchate of Aquileia">Patriarchate of Aquileia</a></b> (568–1751)</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Patriarch_of_Grado" title="Patriarch of Grado">Patriarchate of Grado</a></b> (725–1451)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Orthodox_Church" title="Bulgarian Orthodox Church">Patriarchate of Bulgaria</a> (since 919)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Georgian_Orthodox_Church" title="Georgian Orthodox Church">Patriarchate of Georgia</a> (since 1010)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Serbian_Patriarchate_of_Pe%C4%87" title="Serbian Patriarchate of Peć">Serbian Orthodox Patriarchate of Peć</a> (since 1346)</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Patriarchate_of_Venice" title="Patriarchate of Venice">Patriarchate of Venice</a></b> (since 1451)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_modern_era" title="Christianity in the modern era">Early Modern era</a> <br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(1517–1789) </span></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><b><a href="/wiki/Patriarchate_of_the_West_Indies" title="Patriarchate of the West Indies">Patriarchate of the West Indies</a></b> (since 1524)</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Latin_Patriarchate_of_Ethiopia" title="Latin Patriarchate of Ethiopia">Latin Patriarchate of Ethiopia</a></b> (1555–1663)</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Patriarchate_of_the_East_Indies" title="Patriarchate of the East Indies">Patriarchate of the East Indies</a></b> (since 1572)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Patriarchate of Moscow</a> (since 1589)</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Patriarchate_of_Lisbon" title="Patriarchate of Lisbon">Patriarchate of Lisbon</a></b> (since 1716)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_modern_era" title="Christianity in the modern era">Late Modern era</a> <br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(since 1789)</span></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Romanian_Orthodox_Church" title="Romanian Orthodox Church">Patriarchate of Romania</a> (since 1925)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_abunas_of_Ethiopia" title="List of abunas of Ethiopia"><span style="color:#808000;">Ethiopian Orthodox Patriarchate of Ethiopia</span></a> (since 1959)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Orthodox_Church_%E2%80%93_Kyiv_Patriarchate" title="Ukrainian Orthodox Church – Kyiv Patriarchate">Patriarchate of Kyiv</a> (1992–2018; since 2019)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_abunas_of_Eritrea" title="List of abunas of Eritrea"><span style="color:#808000;">Eritrean Orthodox Patriarchate of Eritrea</span></a> (since 1994)</li></ul>

<ul><li><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P_christianity.svg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/16px-P_christianity.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/24px-P_christianity.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/32px-P_christianity.svg.png 2x" width="16"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Christianity" title="Portal:Christianity">Christianity portal</a></li></ul>
